summary:
• Sky Sports pundit Paul Merson and Tottenham’s Andros Townsend have an ongoing spat.  
• It began when Merson wrote that Townsend’s England selection meant “it opens it up to anybody.”  
• Townsend replied by scoring England’s equaliser against Italy and tweeting “Not bad for a player that should be ‘nowhere near the squad’.”  
• Although Merson later admitted he had been wrong, he reignited the row on Sunday, tweeting “Did you miss the coach? #RubberDub #7minutes” after Townsend was only a 83rd-minute substitute in Spurs’ 0-0 draw at Burnley.

• FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane says Chelsea have submitted a formal summer bid (about £4 m) for 22-year-old striker Yoshinori Muto.  
• If signed, Muto would be loaned to Chelsea’s partner club Vitesse Arnhem next season and become the first Japanese player on Chelsea’s books.  
• Ogane insists the move is unrelated to Chelsea’s £200 m, five-year shirt-sponsorship deal with Japanese firm Yokohama Rubber.  
• Muto profile: 37 FC Tokyo games, 16 goals; 11 Japan caps, 1 goal; economics graduate from Keio University; J-League Best XI after a 13-goal debut season and has 3 goals in 4 matches this year.  
• The forward calls Chelsea’s interest “an honour” but says he has not decided whether to join. Chelsea may stage a two-week pre-season tour in Japan.

A Finnish study of more than 12,000 healthy two-year-olds, reported in Pediatrics, compared their height and weight with antibiotic prescription records. By age two, 20 % of boys and 10 % of girls were overweight or obese, and infants given antibiotics in the first six months—or repeatedly before age two—were significantly more likely to be in this group. Boys showed the strongest effect and were also slightly taller than unmedicated peers. Although the research does not prove causation, the authors suggest antibiotics may kill gut bacteria that normally limit calorie absorption or curb appetite, thereby promoting weight gain. Lead author Dr Antti Saari warns that early and frequent antibiotic use could be fueling the global childhood-obesity epidemic and stresses more judicious prescribing. Previous work links infant antibiotics to eczema and digestive problems, and health officials already fear overuse is undermining the drugs’ effectiveness against infections.

During last week’s Changing of the Guard at Buckingham Palace, a young Queen’s Guard slipped on a manhole cover—probably because of the metal protectors on his boot soles—fell against his sentry box, dropped his rifle and quickly scrambled back to his feet. The mishap, witnessed by hundreds of tourists, was filmed by holiday-maker David Meadwell, 50, from Newcastle-upon-Tyne, whose family was watching the ceremony. While the crowd gasped, the guard resumed his duties and his colleagues marched on unaffected. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on “a young man falling over while doing his job.” The Changing of the Guard draws thousands of visitors daily at 11:30 a.m. in summer (every other day in winter) and, despite its pageantry, the guards are fully operational soldiers.

A&E Networks announced that A&E, Lifetime and History will simulcast a new, “original” and “contemporary” remake of the 1977 miniseries “Roots” in 2016. The original drew more than 100 million viewers and told the story of Kunta Kinte, an African captured and enslaved in America, and his descendants. The remake will rely more heavily on Alex Haley’s book, consult African- and African-American-history scholars for authenticity, and be executive-produced by LeVar Burton (who played Kinte in 1977) and Mark Wolper, son of the original producer. Network executives say the project aims to introduce the saga to a new generation amid today’s racial climate.

Former royal footman Christopher Lawler, now 64, says that on his first day working at Clarence House in January 1978 four male staff—one a senior aide—pinned him to a chair, groped him and tried to force him into an orgy. He broke free, was threatened to stay silent, complained, and quit that day. Haunted by the attack, he renewed his complaint last year amid wider child-abuse inquiries; the palace allegedly ignored him for months before passing the allegation to Scotland Yard. Police are now investigating. A retired aide in his 80s has been interviewed and denies involvement, while the Royal Household says it will cooperate fully with the probe.

Jesse and Melissa Meek of Happy Valley, Oregon revealed they are expecting a baby by posting a parody of The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air theme on YouTube. Rapping in their car, the video tells how they conceived after two months of trying and ends with a sonogram shot. Created to inform far-flung relatives, it took five takes and has since drawn over 1.7 million views—far more attention than the couple anticipated. They may release a follow-up once they learn the baby’s gender. Jesse, a great-great-grandson of pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek, had earlier learned of the pregnancy from a message on their dog. A similar Fresh Prince pregnancy video was made by a Pennsylvania couple last year.

Heritage Auctions sold more than 150 Gone With the Wind artifacts in Beverly Hills. The top lot, a gray jacket-and-skirt outfit worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O’Hara in several key 1939 scenes, realized $137,000; once slate blue-gray, it has faded with age. The items came from former Universal Studios hair-and-makeup chief James Tumblin, who began collecting in the 1960s after buying the discarded dress for $20 and eventually amassing 300,000 pieces. Other notable sales included Leigh’s straw hat ($52,500), Clark Gable’s Rhett Butler suit trousers and jacket ($55,000), and a black bonnet shared by Leigh and Olivia De Havilland ($30,000). Gone With the Wind, adapted from Margaret Mitchell’s 1936 novel, marked its 75th anniversary last year; cast member Hattie McDaniel was the first African-American to be nominated for and win an Academy Award.

A two-year-old boy was accidentally dropped about 10–12 ft into the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo’s cheetah pit after his parents reportedly dangled him over the railing around 3 p.m. Saturday. His parents pulled him out before responders arrived; he sustained only minor bumps, bruises and a leg injury and is in stable condition at MetroHealth Medical Center. The cheetahs never approached. Multiple witnesses told zoo staff the child had been held over the edge, and the zoo intends to file child-endangerment charges against the mother. The cheetah exhibit was closed following the incident.

• A fixed Gatso speed camera on Wellington Road, Handsworth, Birmingham, has mysteriously been swivelled to face a house’s front door.  
• The device used to enforce the 30 mph limit but has been inactive for over two years, along with about 300 other obsolete fixed cameras switched off across the West Midlands in March 2013.  
• Since 2013, speed checks have relied on a few mobile units, motorway cameras and traffic-officer patrols.  
• Birmingham City Council, now aware of the camera’s new position, will send an engineer and may remove it; this site will not be part of the planned pilot introducing updated digital cameras.  
• The homeowners were unavailable for comment.

Usain Bolt has been selected to run for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on 2–3 May. The six-time Olympic champion says he is “fit, healthy and ready” and is eager to uphold Jamaica’s strong relay tradition. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle welcomed his availability, and the rest of the Jamaican squad will be named soon.

• Neymar and Dani Alves showed support for Barcelona’s basketball team by attending the Euro-League El Clásico with Neymar’s sister Rafaella.  
• Barcelona beat Real Madrid 85-80, though Madrid remain top of their division on points difference.  
• Days earlier Neymar captained Brazil to a 1-0 win over Chile at the Emirates, enduring heavy tackles, including an apparent stamp by Gary Medel.  
• Before the international break Barcelona’s football side won their own El Clásico to go four points clear in La Liga; they face Celta Vigo next as they pursue a possible treble.

Italy is facing a sharp rise in Mediterranean migrant crossings.

• Rescues: Between Friday and Monday 8,480 people were saved; on Monday alone the coast guard fielded SOS calls from 20 boats.

• Suspected disaster: Survivors told Save the Children that a vessel with 550 passengers capsized about 80 miles off Libya, leaving roughly 400 missing. The Italian coast guard is investigating but has found no wreckage, bodies or survivors to confirm the claim.

• Trends: More than 10,000 migrants reached Italy in the first quarter of 2015, with about 2,000 rescued during the first weekend of April. A single day last week saw 978 rescues.

• Origins and risks: Migrants mainly come from West Africa, Somalia and Syria, transiting through Libya. At least 480 have died this year, often due to bad weather, overcrowded smuggler boats and crews abandoning vessels.

• Alexis Sanchez was pursued by several top clubs after Barcelona agreed to sell him, with both Arsenal and Liverpool keen.  
• He ultimately chose Arsenal, joining for about £32 million and has already scored 19 goals this season.  
• Arsène Wenger says only Sanchez can explain why he picked the Emirates over Anfield, but is delighted to have him.  
• Wenger suspected Liverpool’s interest could have been part of their Suarez-to-Barcelona negotiations.  
• He rates Sanchez among the best for work-rate, fighting spirit and ability to lift a game when it goes flat.  
• Ahead of Arsenal’s league meeting with Liverpool, Wenger downplayed rumours of a summer move for Liverpool’s Raheem Sterling and praised Brendan Rodgers for reshaping his side after losing Suarez and coping with Daniel Sturridge’s injuries, noting they scored 100+ league goals last season.

• Sir Bradley Wiggins, 2012 Tour de France winner and four-time Olympic champion, will attempt to break cycling’s UCI Hour Record on 7 June at London’s Lee Valley VeloPark (Olympic Velodrome), turning 35 on 28 April.  
• The current record is 52.491 km, set by Australia’s Rohan Dennis in February after recent UCI rule changes; previous marks were Jens Voigt’s 51.115 km and Matthias Brändle’s 51.852 km, while Briton Alex Dowsett will make his own bid on 2 May.  
• Wiggins ended his Team Sky road career at Paris-Roubaix, will ride the inaugural Tour de Yorkshire, and then focus on the Hour as part of his return to track racing and his build-up for a hoped-for eighth Olympic medal (team pursuit) at Rio 2016.  
• The attempt will be televised live on Sky Sports before a hoped-for sell-out crowd of 6,000; tickets (£29–£49) go on sale online via Sky Tickets from 19 April.  
• Calling the Hour Record “a holy grail,” Wiggins aims to set a distance that will stand “for some time” and urges people to test how far they can ride in an hour.

Serena Williams’ Fed Cup weekend underlined problems as the clay-court season begins.  

• Singles: Williams battled past Italy’s Sara Errani 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3, extending her head-to-head to 8-0 but admitting the struggle was “a big eye-opener” that showed she is “totally not as ready for the claycourt season” as she thought.  

• Doubles: Williams and Alison Riske were routed 6-0 6-3 by Errani/Flavia Pennetta, sealing Italy’s 3-2 victory and dropping the United States to Fed Cup World Group II.  

• Reactions: Williams says she must adjust from hard courts and “be ready to hit a thousand shots.” U.S. captain Mary Joe Fernandez vows the team will “keep plugging away” to regain World Group status, noting the depth of American players.  

• Context: Williams, 33, owns 19 Grand Slam singles titles, including two French Opens (2002, 2013), but Roland Garros remains her toughest major.

River Plate vice-president Matias Patanian says the club “dreams” of re-signing Radamel Falcao and that “the doors are open,” though he concedes a deal would be complicated.  
Falcao, 29, started at River in 2001, debuted in 2005 and scored 34 goals in 90 games before leaving in 2009. Now on loan at Manchester United, he has managed only four Premier League goals, leaving his future with United or parent club Monaco uncertain. Despite club struggles, he has just scored three times in two matches for Colombia, drawing level with the country’s all-time record of 24 goals.

X-Factor 2012 finalist Ella Henderson, 19, has been named the official face of Batiste’s 2015 “Ready For It” dry-shampoo campaign—her first brand endorsement. Shot against vibrant city backdrops, the ads show Henderson’s long hair in several styles and will run internationally, including a TV spot that features her single “Mirror Man.” The partnership, arranged by the MILES agency, was welcomed by both Henderson, who says she already uses Batiste, and her management CEO Mark Hargreaves, who called the artist–brand fit “natural” and looks forward to a big 2015.

• Aaron Siler, 26, was shot and killed by Kenosha police officer Pablo Torres on March 14 after a vehicle/foot chase; police say Siler had armed himself and was wanted on a felony warrant.  
• Torres is on leave while the state Division of Criminal Investigation reviews the shooting; the case is still open.  
• Ten days earlier Torres shot and wounded Terry Knight, 66, in a separate incident; that shooting has been ruled justified by the district attorney.  
• A police-union-funded billboard showing Torres and his dog with the message “Thank you for your support, Kenosha” has been put up in the city.  
• Siler’s family and friends call the billboard “disrespectful” and want it removed; the Kenosha Professional Police Association says it meant only to thank the community for its support during recent events.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed Monday in Negur, Sistan-Baluchestan, during a clash with militants who had crossed in from Pakistan; Iranian forces killed three attackers. The Sunni militant group Jaish al Adal—active in Pakistan’s Balochistan and opposed to Iranian influence—claimed responsibility. Iran asked Pakistan to pursue the surviving assailants, citing past failures to curb such militants, while Pakistan condemned the “terrorist” attack, launched an investigation and vowed to apprehend any perpetrators who fled back across the border. The same group killed 14 Iranian guards in a 2013 attack near Saravan.

During a Japanese Upper House Budget Committee session, former pro-wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki asked whether Japan’s Air Self-Defense Force (ASDF) had ever scrambled jets against extraterrestrial UFOs or was studying alien visitors. Defense Minister Gen Nakatani replied that, although fighters are sent aloft whenever unidentified objects threaten Japanese airspace, the ASDF has never encountered anything originating beyond Earth—only birds or other terrestrial objects. Inoki, famous for founding New Japan Pro Wrestling and his 1976 bout with Muhammad Ali, says he once saw a UFO himself but is unsure aliens exist. The exchange echoes a 2007 discussion in which another defense minister mused about constitutional issues arising from a hypothetical alien invasion.

At Hefei Xinqiao International Airport, 35-year-old passenger Jin Pai stood on a toilet rim because he thought the seat was dirty. The porcelain fixture tipped over and shattered, inflicting deep cuts to his left leg and buttocks that required dozens of stitches in hospital. Embarrassed, he phoned friends instead of calling for help, later telling police he had been sitting, not squatting—apparently to avoid compensation. Authorities treated the incident as an accident and reminded travelers that toilets are meant for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, PA, was arrested after a 15-year-old girl discovered a hidden bathroom camera. Police traced the device to Rebbie and found 41 videos, 34 showing victims— including the girl— showering; some contained close-ups of children’s genitalia. The girl reported that from ages 9 to 13 Rebbie repeatedly entered her bedroom and molested her. Rebbie admitted filming several juveniles and said he bought the camera to record the girl. He is charged with aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. The footage spans three to four years. Rebbie is held on $500,000 bail pending a May 1 preliminary hearing.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama’s new photo series, published in a book whose title translates to “Daughter and Salaryman,” pairs teenage daughters standing calmly in casual clothes with their fathers—dressed in business suits—caught mid-leap beside them. The playful portraits let normally serious “salaryman” dads reveal a fun, heroic side, even if some older fathers look a bit strained in flight. Shot against various Japanese landmarks, the quirky images have attracted considerable online attention, though little additional information about the project is available.

• England have dismissed managing director Paul Downton; attention is now on the County Championship.

• Kevin Pietersen, dropped from England by Downton in 2014 after the Ashes whitewash, is with Surrey and hopes the vacancy will aid a Test recall.

• At Surrey’s team-photo session at the Kia Oval, Pietersen alternated between quiet reflection and joking with photographers and team-mates.

• Surrey face Oxford MCCU on Sunday and open their Championship campaign against Glamorgan on 19 April, matches Pietersen intends to use to press his England claims.

Relegation-threatened Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt have dismissed Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. Owner Angelo Massone first sacked him on Wednesday, reinstated him a day later, then fired him again after Saturday’s 2-0 defeat to FC Botosani, which left Ceahlaul 16th and six points from safety. Ze Maria, 41, a former Inter/Parma right-back capped 25 times by Brazil, had taken over from Florin Marin in January as the club’s third coach of the season. He will be succeeded by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

• Nabil Dirar, Radamel Falcao’s ex-Monaco team-mate, says the striker now regrets leaving Monaco for his season-long loan at Manchester United.  
• Falcao was unhappy in France, yet Dirar believes he would have played regularly and featured in the Champions League had he stayed.  
• Since joining United last summer, Falcao has scored only four goals after his serious knee injury, and the club is unlikely to pay the £46 million needed to make the move permanent.

A very tall man in a fluoro-orange sweatshirt and a distinctive cartoon mask robbed the Union St dairy in east Christchurch around 12:30 pm on Saturday. He threatened the owner’s 30-year-old daughter, ripped out the till, smashed the cash register, and escaped with about $1,500. No weapon was seen. Police are still searching for him and urge anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers (0800 555 111) or message police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, 24, a math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, is accused of sexual misconduct with two 15-year-old students.  

• First arrest: March 19. Granado admitted kissing a boy and letting him touch her breasts during April of the previous year. She was released on bail and placed on administrative leave.  

• Second arrest: Monday (after rumors surfaced). A different 15-year-old says Granado had sex with him in her car on January 18–19 near a Dallas school. She was jailed again and freed on a $50,000 bond.  

Police say the second accusation emerged from school rumors; her plea to the new charges is unknown. The school district states she remains banned from campus while the investigation continues.

• Location: Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, where a river-side crocodile sanctuary meets a public marina.  
• Incident: A large American crocodile seized and killed the black, red-collared pet dog of the local bike-shop owner when the dog approached the water’s edge.  
• Witness: New Zealander tourist Tim Weston filmed and photographed the crocodile; he said the reptile held the dog “for ages” and was still on display hours later.  
• Video impact: The footage, posted to the Bogged Facebook page, has been watched more than 500,000 times and provoked horrified social-media reactions.  
• Context: Crocodiles up to 6 m long are common around Puerto Vallarta’s mangroves, marina and golf course because urban development overlaps their natural habitat.

• Hull City lost 2-0 to Southampton (Ward-Prowse penalty, late Pelle goal) and sit just two points above the relegation zone.  
• Manager Steve Bruce, who initially targeted 10 wins but has only six, believes 8–9 victories will now suffice; six matches remain, four against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham and Manchester United.  
• Bruce blames the struggle on long-term injuries (Diame, Chester just back; Dawson, Jelavic out for half the season; Snodgrass all season) but is “convinced” Hull will survive.  
• Southampton’s win lifts them to fifth. Ronald Koeman will remind players of penalty-taker rules after Mane tried to take Ward-Prowse’s assigned kick.

Ian Guffick, a 31-year-old teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, let 11-year-old pupils alter their completed SATs papers and personally changed some answers himself. The breach, discovered in June after a tip-off and local authority investigation, led the Department for Education to annul all of the school’s 2014 SATs results. A National College for Teaching and Leadership panel ruled his actions were dishonest and unacceptable professional conduct, though short of fraud. Acting for the Education Secretary, Paul Heathcote imposed a prohibition order banning Guffick from teaching for at least two years. Guffick admitted the misconduct, expressed remorse and has 28 days to appeal.

• Manchester United goalkeeper Anders Lindegaard spent a sunny day in Cheshire with his wife, Swedish-Albanian model Misse Beqiri, sharing the moment on Instagram.  
• The couple began dating in 2012, married in a beach ceremony in Mauritius last year, and have a son together.  
• Beqiri, who has over 17,000 Instagram followers, frequently posts modelling photos online.  
• On the field, Lindegaard has made only 19 Premier League appearances since joining United from Aalesunds in 2010; with David de Gea and Victor Valdes ahead of him he is now third-choice and has been told he can leave, though a January move to FC Midtjylland fell through.

Thirteen 10-foot, glowing blue letters that spelled “Yankee Stadium,” installed in 1976 and removed after the ballpark’s final game in 2008, were offered at Sotheby’s on Wednesday by their owner, Yankees Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson. Although expected to fetch $300,000–$600,000, the lot drew no real bids—only a token $260,000 paddle raise by a Sotheby’s employee—so the letters went unsold. Jackson, who had bought them “on a lark,” had hoped a new owner would display them. In the same sale, a late-1960s New York Mets bullpen car, estimated at $20,000–$30,000, surprisingly sold for $112,500.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has spoken to Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe after photos showed Sterling using nitrous oxide and the pair smoking shisha pipes. He reminded them of their responsibilities but imposed no formal discipline and wants the issue closed. Sterling will lead the attack against Aston Villa in Sunday’s FA Cup semi-final at Wembley because Daniel Sturridge is injured. Steven Gerrard returns from a three-match ban, though Rodgers has not said if he will start. Rodgers is focused on reaching his first FA Cup final with Liverpool, noting that past near-misses in the league and Capital One Cup are part of the team’s development.

• After helping Germany beat Georgia 2-0 in Sunday’s Euro 2016 qualifier, Arsenal playmaker Mesut Özil returned to London and tweeted a “Home Sweet Home” photo relaxing with his dog.  
• Özil had missed Arsenal’s previous match against Newcastle through illness, amid dismissed reports of a Berlin nightclub visit, but is expected to start against Liverpool at the Emirates this weekend.  
• Signed for £42.5 million in 2013, the midfielder has produced four assists and three goals since returning from injury in January and says the busy English schedule suits him, insisting he now “fits in perfectly.”

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu says the club is “very happy” with coach Luis Enrique and has no intention of replacing him. Enrique, hired last summer on a contract running to 2016, has impressed as Barça sit six matches from the La Liga title and remain in contention for a treble. Bartomeu praised Enrique’s focus and work ethic, noting his preparation between the PSG and Valencia games. Barcelona underlined their form by beating Valencia 2–0, with goals from Luis Suárez and Lionel Messi.

• Vice-captain Jordan Henderson has agreed a new Liverpool contract running to summer 2020, worth about £100,000 a week; his previous deal had 14 months left.  
• The 24-year-old becomes the third key player after Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho to extend under Brendan Rodgers.  
• Signed from Sunderland for £16 m in 2011, Henderson has blossomed, registering 13 assists and seven goals this season and is a leading candidate to succeed Steven Gerrard as captain when Gerrard joins LA Galaxy.  
• While up to 10 players may depart, Liverpool chief Ian Ayre says he still expects Raheem Sterling—talks on hold until summer—to remain at Anfield long term.

Filipe Luis says he intends to see out the three-year Chelsea contract he signed last July, despite Atletico Madrid’s interest in re-signing him after his limited starts at left back. Fresh from Brazil’s friendly wins over France and Chile, he shifts focus to Chelsea’s Premier League title run-in. Manager José Mourinho is urging the squad to stay fully focused through the remaining nine tough league matches.

• Wasps No 8 Nathan Hughes was originally sent off and given a three-match ban for his knee accidentally striking George North’s head as North scored for Northampton on 27 March.  
• The incident left North unconscious – his third knockout in two months – and doctors told him to rest for at least a month.  
• Despite the disciplinary panel calling Hughes “reckless,” widespread criticism followed; figures such as James Haskell, Andy Goode, Austin Healey and Joe Marler all condemned the sanction.  
• Wasps appealed, and on Friday the appeal panel, chaired by Jeremy Summers, reviewed new evidence, ruled the clash accidental with “no act of foul play,” overturned the red card and cancelled the ban.  
• Hughes, who missed Wasps’ Champions Cup quarter-final loss to Toulon during the suspension, is now free to play but is not selected for Saturday’s game against London Welsh; his likely return is versus Exeter on 26 April.

Unusually vivid red sunsets seen in Washington, Oregon and British Columbia were produced by smoke from large grass-burning fires in southeastern Siberia that spread out of control on April 14, destroying dozens of villages. Atmospheric winds carried the smoke across the Pacific, and its particles filtered out shorter-wavelength light, letting reds and oranges dominate, especially at sunrise and sunset. As the smoke thins, air quality will improve and the intense coloration will fade.

St. Louis mom Becky Schoenig’s new 2015 Ford Fusion was stolen from her driveway, but police recovered it on April 1 after tipster Mick Sexton recognized the car. Thieves had “pimped” the vehicle with red-spray-painted rims, red side detailing and orange steering-wheel accents. Amused, Schoenig posted a Facebook photo thanking the thieves for upgrading her ride, though she now must have it cleaned to remove strong cigarette and marijuana odors. Owner of The Hot Pot restaurant, she is honoring Sexton with a new smoothie, the “Sexton on Wheels” (banana, pineapple, peach, coconut cream). Friend Marlene Trice says Schoenig loves making people laugh.

Manchester City’s squad have performance-based contracts designed to keep the club within Financial Fair Play rules.  
• Each senior player stands to lose about £500,000, a total of roughly £12 million, if the team fail to reach next season’s Champions League group stage.  
• Sunday’s derby defeat to Manchester United left City fourth; if Liverpool beat Newcastle they will sit only four points behind. The top three qualify automatically, while fourth must survive a play-off.  
• Since starting 2015 level with Chelsea, City have lost seven matches and exited both the FA Cup and Champions League, prompting manager Manuel Pellegrini to admit they have “thrown [the season] into the garbage.”  
• Upcoming league games: West Ham, Aston Villa, Tottenham, QPR, Swansea, Southampton.  
• Missing the Champions League would also hinder City’s pursuit of elite signings such as Juventus midfielder Paul Pogba, while United manager Louis van Gaal is confident of attracting top talent after moving four points clear of City.

Manchester United’s Under-18s beat Manchester City 1-0 in a ‘mini-derby’ played at Altrincham’s Moss Lane before about 1,000 spectators. 

Key points:
• Callum Gribbin, an England U-17 midfielder, won and scored the decisive free-kick just before the hour.  
• United, coached by Paul McGuinness, used a three-centre-back system with wing-backs, mirroring recent first-team tactics.  
• United striker Marcus Rashford missed two first-half chances; City’s Marcus Wood went close with a chip.  
• Cameron Borthwick-Jackson hit the woodwork for United, while late City efforts from Aaron Nemane and Javairo Dilrosun failed to level.  
• Thirteen of the 22 starters were English, 10 of them Mancunian.  
• The victory puts United two points behind Middlesbrough with a game in hand in the Barclays U18 Premier League play-off series; injury-hit City have lost both of their play-off matches.  
• The match showcased several promising local talents amid wider concerns about opportunities for home-grown players aged 18-21.

After England’s 1-1 draw with Italy, England and Manchester City goalkeeper Joe Hart marked his 50th cap and praised 37-year-old Italian counterpart Gianluigi Buffon, who reached his 147th international appearance. Hart called Buffon an inspirational “legend of the game,” said he continues to study Buffon’s example, and expressed his own desire to keep improving and add many more caps for England.

Chipotle will enter the $70 billion food-delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app. Delivery for online and mobile orders will start in 67 cities, carrying a 9 % Chipotle service charge plus Postmates fees that begin at about $5, varying by distance and demand. After long resisting third-party services, the chain has now approved Postmates, whose independent drivers use their own cars. Other major brands exploring or using delivery include Starbucks (also with Postmates), Taco Bell, McDonald’s and Burger King. Recent high-profile Chipotle customers mentioned are presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Marco Rubio.

Bill and Denise Richard, whose 8-year-old son Martin was the youngest person killed in the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings and whose daughter Jane was badly injured, have publicly asked the U.S. Justice Department to drop the death penalty for convicted bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. In a Boston Globe front-page piece titled “To end the anguish, drop the death penalty,” they say a life sentence without parole and no appeals would spare their family—and Boston—years of painful proceedings. Tsarnaev was found guilty last week on all 30 charges; the sentencing phase starts Tuesday and is expected to last four weeks. The Richards, speaking only for themselves, argue that ending the pursuit of execution would help everyone “turn the page” on the attack that killed three people and wounded more than 200; Tsarnaev’s brother Tamerlan was killed during a 2013 police shootout.

A mystery billionaire spent around £400 million and three years turning a Boeing 747-8—normally configured for up to 600 passengers—into an opulent private jet for himself and several dozen guests. Designed by Greenpoint Technologies, the aircraft features:  
• Multiple hotel-style lounges and a central “state room.”  
• A dining room linked to a full kitchen for a private chef.  
• A conference room for in-flight meetings.  
• A master suite with large bed, sofa and armchair, plus an office/guest bedroom.  
• An “aeroloft” on the top deck containing eight full-size beds.  
The lavish interior replaces standard seating with décor more akin to a luxury hotel.

SpaceX successfully launched an uncrewed Dragon cargo ship atop a two-stage Falcon 9 from Cape Canaveral toward the International Space Station, carrying about 4,300 lb (1,950 kg) of supplies and an “ISSpresso” coffee maker. The ascent worked, but the first-stage booster’s experimental landing on an ocean “droneship” failed when the rocket touched down too hard and toppled—SpaceX’s second such miss after a similar January attempt. Re-landing boosters is central to Elon Musk’s plan to cut launch costs by up to 100-fold through reuse. Dragon is scheduled to dock with the ISS in a few days, remain about five weeks while astronauts unload cargo and reload more than 3,000 lb of experiments and trash, then splash down in the Pacific off California. This marks SpaceX’s sixth ISS resupply run; Tuesday’s liftoff followed a weather-scrubbed attempt on Monday.

• A new “Elvis Presley’s Graceland Wedding Chapel” is opening inside Las Vegas’ Westgate Hotel (the former Las Vegas Hilton, where Elvis performed 830+ shows).  
• NBC’s Today show is running a contest for Elvis-devoted couples; entrants send photos/video explaining why they should win.  
• The winning couple (announced next Monday) will be the chapel’s first wedding on Thursday, April 23.  
• Their prize: the ceremony, Priscilla Presley as official witness, a free reception, a two-night hotel suite, round-trip airfare, and tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show.  
• Priscilla, who helped design the chapel, stresses the venue is “first-class” and forbids Elvis impersonators.  
• The chapel is part of the first permanent display of Graceland artifacts outside the singer’s Memphis home.

• Liverpool beat Newcastle 2-0 at Anfield on Monday.  
  – Raheem Sterling scored in the 9th minute.  
  – Joe Allen added a second with 20 minutes left.

• The match was the 47th appearance of the season for both Jordan Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet, the joint-most for any player in Europe’s top five leagues this campaign.

• Vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes the win puts Liverpool in position to catch Manchester City for a Champions League spot; City are four points ahead after recently losing 4-2 to Manchester United.

• Joe Allen admitted Newcastle might have had a strong penalty claim when Dejan Lovren challenged Ayoze Perez.

• Henderson says Liverpool must “keep going, keep winning,” noting the team has rebounded after poor results against Manchester United and Arsenal.

Roma ended a seven-match, four-month home drought by beating Napoli 1-0 in Serie A.  
• Goal: Miralem Pjanić finished a counter-attack in the 25th minute after moves from Juan Iturbe and Alessandro Florenzi.  
• Heroics: Keeper Morgan De Sanctis made several key second-half saves, especially from Dries Mertens and Manolo Gabbiadini.  
• Table impact: Roma stay second and move four points clear of Lazio; Napoli’s winless run stretches to five games and they remain fifth.  
• Absences/returns: Roma were without injured Francesco Totti and Gervinho; Napoli introduced Lorenzo Insigne for his first action since a November knee injury.  
• Incidents: Heavy security and a ticket ban for Campania residents followed last year’s cup-final violence, but the match passed without trouble.  
• Controversy: Napoli had a possible penalty waved away when Kostas Manolas challenged Jonathan De Guzmán.

Doncaster Rovers’ drab season continued with a 0-0 home draw against Fleetwood Town, leaving the League One club stuck in mid-table. The match was so uneventful that the club’s media team could only compile a 27-second highlight video—14 seconds of actual play showing the kick-off, a goal-kick and the final whistle.

Roland Giroux has trained his blood parrot cichlid—a hybrid of the midas and redhead cichlids first bred in Taiwan in 1986—to enjoy physical contact. In a video he cups the fish in his aquarium, gently massages it, and the fish repeatedly swims back for more, even following his hand to the water’s surface when he withdraws. Giroux removed two former tank-mates after they bullied the cichlid, began hand-feeding it frozen blood worms, and now plays with and strokes the fish for about 15 minutes every day; the fish becomes frustrated if this routine is skipped.

• Ben Stokes returns to Kensington Oval, scene of last year’s self-inflicted broken wrist, reminded to channel his aggression constructively.

• Regarded as a fiery, imaginative cricketer—evident in past confrontations with Mitchell Johnson and, most recently, West Indian Marlon Samuels—Stokes was counselled by England coach Peter Moores after the Samuels clash and responded well.

• A minor back niggle is the only threat to his selection for the Barbados Test; England are keen to play him (and Chris Jordan) even though including a second spinner, Adil Rashid, is also under consideration.

• Coaches must manage Stokes carefully: preserve his natural exuberance while ensuring it translates into runs and wickets rather than unfocused aggression, accepting that such a player will inevitably experience both highs and lows.

• Wales’ Euro 2016 Group B qualifier against Belgium on 12 June at Cardiff City Stadium (capacity 33,000) has sold out.  
• Wales and Belgium each have 11 points from five matches; Belgium lead the group only on goal difference.  
• A 3-0 win in Israel has heightened Welsh hopes of securing their first major-tournament place since the 1958 World Cup.  
• The FA of Wales reported “overwhelming demand” for tickets.  
• Despite speculation about moving to the 74,500-seat Millennium Stadium, UEFA’s 120-day venue rule—and the Welsh players’ preference—keeps the match at the smaller Cardiff City Stadium.

England U-17 coach John Peacock has announced an 18-man squad for the UEFA European Championship in Bulgaria next month. Defending champions England qualified with a perfect record and will face Italy (7 May, Burgas), Holland (10 May) and the Republic of Ireland (13 May) in Group D.

Squad  
Goalkeepers: Paul Woolston, Will Huffer  
Defenders: Danny Collinge, Reece Oxford, Easah Suliman, James Yates, Jay DaSilva, Tayo Edun  
Midfielders: Trent Arnold, Daniel Wright, Herbie Kane, Tom Davies, Marcus Edwards, Nathan Holland, Chris Willock  
Forwards: Layton Ndukwu, Stephy Mavididi, Ike Ugbo

Key points  
• First call-ups: Arsenal’s Stephy Mavididi and Chris Willock.  
• Recalls: Liverpool duo Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold.  
• Other notable names: Chelsea pair Jay DaSilva and Ike Ugbo, West Ham’s Reece Oxford.

Manchester City have opened talks with Anderlecht about 14-year-old playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, viewed as one of the club’s top youth talents. The Belgian prospect, who previously turned down Barcelona’s La Masia at age 12 to focus on his studies and is also on Arsenal and Barcelona’s radar, is being targeted by Manuel Pellegrini as a long-term acquisition, with City negotiating a compensation package with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock.

• Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old Mexican transgender escort who advertised working in London, Paris and Miami, was found dead on 28 March in a £400,000 flat in Romily Court, Fulham, south-west London.

• She died from head and neck injuries consistent with strangulation and beating.

• A 23-year-old man has been arrested in connection with her death and released on bail; he must return for further police questioning.

• Detective Chief Inspector Rebecca Reeves and Scotland Yard are appealing for anyone who had contact with Santillan on the Friday or Saturday before her death to come forward, pledging to do “everything” to solve the case.

Dawn, who has endured seven miscarriages and buried her baby Daniel James, had saved £207 toward a £500 gravestone. She suspected her house-mate and long-time friend Jamie—a convicted burglar—of stealing the money. On ITV’s The Jeremy Kyle Show, a lie-detector test confirmed Jamie took it; he had also sent Dawn a Facebook message confessing and blaming his girlfriend Carol. The revelation left Dawn devastated, causing her to break down and leave the stage in tears, saying she felt utterly betrayed.

ISIS has freed more than 200 Yazidi captives—figure given as 217-228—most of them women, children, the ill or the elderly. Arab tribal leaders helped arrange the release; the motive remains unknown. Peshmerga forces received the group and took them to the Kurdish regional capital, Irbil. The Yazidis, a Kurdish-descended religious minority of about 500,000 in northern Iraq, were massacred, raped, enslaved and driven from their towns (notably Sinjar) when ISIS swept through the region last summer, prompting international airdrops, rescues and U.S.-led airstrikes.

Tottenham striker Harry Kane, who has enjoyed a breakthrough season for club and country, is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards. Ahead of Sunday’s ceremony, Copa90 has released an animated video—“Harry Kane – PFA Player of the Year?”—that strings together still photographs to showcase his 2014-15 highlights: a long-range goal against Chelsea, a header versus Arsenal, his England-debut strike, and his 20th Premier League goal against Newcastle. Kane is competing for the top prize against players such as Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

• Jamie Carragher says Brendan Rodgers should remain Liverpool manager despite a third straight season without a trophy and an expected finish outside the top four (seven points behind fourth-placed Manchester City with a game in hand).  
• He argues one game should not decide Rodgers’ future, believes many of last summer’s signings have yet to settle, and insists correct recruitment is vital for a trophy push and Champions League return next season.  
• Rodgers is under pressure after the FA Cup semi-final loss to Aston Villa and another trophyless campaign.  
• Carragher received a Beacon Award in London for his 23 Foundation’s coaching work in eight Merseyside schools; he hopes to inspire youngsters from deprived areas such as his hometown of Bootle.

• Four-year-old James Hayward, travelling with his parents from East Midlands Airport to Lanzarote, had a brightly-coloured Nerf-style toy gun in his hand luggage.  
• Airport security spotted the plastic, sponge-dart gun on X-ray, frisked the child and confiscated the £6 toy, saying government rules ban items that resemble prohibited weapons; they offered to mail it to the family’s home.  
• James’s father, Phil Hayward, called the action “ludicrous” and “over-zealous,” but chose not to argue to avoid missing the flight.  
• After their 10-day holiday the family bought James a replacement toy gun online.  
• East Midlands Airport later apologised for the inconvenience, stressing that passenger safety and compliance with Department for Transport regulations come first.

A 31-year-old man calling himself “Rich” from Humpty Doo in Australia’s Northern Territory posted a Gumtree ad seeking a girlfriend or wife.  

What he offers:  
• Accommodation plus possible company car, phone, laptop  
• Free gym membership and other “benefits”  
• He says he is athletic, 175 cm, heavily tattooed, well-off, owns property, loves travel, the outdoors, cars and bikes, and neither drinks, smokes nor takes drugs.  

What he wants:  
• A pet-loving, attractive, fit woman who preferably doesn’t drink or smoke  
• Someone honest, loyal, reliable, handy around the house, a good cook, “great in bed,” outdoorsy yet able to be a “princess” when required  

He adds that “all reasonable offers will be considered,” but ex-partners need not apply. Daily Mail Australia was unable to reach him for comment.

• FA chairman Greg Dyke proposes raising the Premier League’s “home-grown” quota from 8 to 12 players per 25-man squad and redefining “home-grown” as three years’ training in England before age 18 (currently before 21).  
• The Premier League opposes the plan, but five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson and Steve McClaren—have written a joint letter backing Dyke.  
• They argue that the diminishing number of English players in top-flight line-ups (only 36.8% in the latest round of Premier League fixtures) is hurting the national team and risks further decline against leading football nations.  
• While acknowledging their own past shortcomings, the ex-managers say emerging talents such as Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling and Harry Kane show England can still produce quality players; what is lacking is first-team opportunity.  
• They urge “everyone in the English game” to support Dyke’s reforms to strengthen the player pool and end England’s long wait for major tournament success.

In the upcoming Poldark episode, Demelza, who was scarcely showing last week, is suddenly eight-months pregnant and then gives birth within minutes of screen time, allowing Ross Poldark to cradle their new baby daughter early in the instalment. Viewers note the implausibly compressed timeline—echoing an earlier rapid pregnancy for Elizabeth—and joke on Twitter that “if you are pregnant in Poldark times expect to have it in the next 10 minutes.” Although Ross originally married his red-haired former kitchen maid out of duty, he now tells her she makes him a better man, confirming his affection despite widespread female admiration for the brooding Cornish hero.

Leicester City remain bottom of the Premier League but sit just three points from safety after successive wins, the latest a 3-2 victory at West Brom sealed by Jamie Vardy’s stoppage-time goal. Ahead of hosting Swansea on Saturday, manager Nigel Pearson says survival is “in our own hands,” telling his players to ignore rivals’ results, avoid over-optimism, and concentrate solely on winning their remaining fixtures.

Varvara, a North Pacific gray whale tracked by Oregon State University scientists, completed the longest mammal migration ever recorded—about 14,000 miles (22,500 km). She left her feeding grounds near Russia’s Sakhalin Island, crossed the Pacific, and traveled down the U.S. West Coast to Baja, Mexico, visiting three eastern gray-whale breeding areas. Her journey beats the prior 10,190-mile record held by a humpback whale. The trip suggests Varvara, previously thought to be an endangered western gray whale, may actually be an eastern gray, raising questions about the true size of the already small western gray-whale population (estimated at 150).

• Overnight, a stretch of seabed on the east coast of Hokkaido’s Shiretoko Peninsula, near the town of Rausu, rose out of the water.  
• The uplifted strip is about 1,000–1,640 ft long, roughly 100 ft wide, and up to 30–50 ft above sea level; marine life such as seaweed and sea urchins remains attached.  
• Geologists attribute the event to a nearby landslide triggered by melting ice and snow, which pivoted the underwater ground upward.  
• Residents felt no tremors or sound, and officials say the incident differs from an earthquake and is unrelated to the recent 7.8-magnitude quake in Nepal.  
• Authorities do not expect the new landform to expand further.

PSG right-back Gregory van der Wiel says he will not leave the club this summer. Despite a recent dispute with coach Laurent Blanc after being dropped for the Chelsea Champions League match, he told L’Equipe he loves the club, city and team-mates, wants a new contract and is ready to play when called upon. PSG are still being linked with Barcelona defender Dani Alves, so the club—not Van der Wiel—may ultimately decide his future.

• Carlos Tevez, still under contract at Juventus until 2016, has told the Italian champions he wants to leave this summer.  
• Boca Juniors president Daniel Angelici says the striker can re-join Boca only after he terminates his Juventus deal, adding that an agreement is “close.”  
• Tevez began at Boca (1996 youth intake, 26 league goals in 76 games) and has long planned to finish his career there.  
• Despite leading Serie A with 17 goals and chasing a second league title and European honours, Juventus have accepted his wish to depart and are seeking replacements.  
• Argentina coach Tata Martino insists a switch to Boca would not affect Tevez’s international prospects.

Bayern Munich crushed Porto 6-1 at the Allianz Arena, overturning a 3-1 first-leg deficit to reach the Champions League semi-finals. They led 5-0 by half-time with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Müller, Xabi Alonso and two from Robert Lewandowski. During the jubilant night, Bayern manager Pep Guardiola tore the left leg of his grey trousers, revealing his underwear and joking he would need a new pair for the next match; he also discarded his blazer later in the game.

A three-car collision on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2 km south of Fernvale, injured ten people—four of them children—on Wednesday afternoon.  
• A 40-year-old man (chest/shoulder injuries) and a 5-year-old boy (chest pain) were airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital, followed shortly by a 27-year-old woman (arm injuries) and a 6-year-old girl (abdominal pain).  
• Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for assessment; one man suffered hand lacerations and two females were uninjured.  
• Fire crews freed a trapped occupant using hydraulic cutters before the Rescue 500 helicopter began evacuations.  
• The highway has been closed for several hours with diversions in place south of Fernvale.

• Arsenal meet leaders Chelsea at the Emirates at 4 p.m. on Sunday; Arsenal are 10 points behind with six Premier League games left.  
• Mesut Özil, 26, showed off a new Apple Watch (priced £299–£13,500, on sale Friday) on Instagram, likening it to Knight Rider’s Michael Knight; he has four goals in 25 games and is set to start the match.  
• Jack Wilshere, 23, is back from five months out and was on the bench for the FA Cup semi-final; ex-Gun Ray Parlour calls him the club’s future but says injuries remain the key concern.

• Mark Clattenburg, 40, has been appointed referee for Sunday’s Manchester United-Manchester City derby at Old Trafford.  
• This season he has shown only two Premier League red cards and both were to United players (Tyler Blackett v Leicester, Luke Shaw v West Ham).  
• His other recent dismissal involving the clubs was City captain Vincent Kompany, sent off for Belgium v Israel on 31 March; that ban rules Kompany out of Belgium-Wales in June.  
• Despite past claims that he favours United, Clattenburg is still regarded, with Michael Oliver, as one of the league’s leading referees.  
• Assistants on Sunday: Simon Beck and Jake Collin; fourth official: Jonathan Moss.  
• Context of the derby: City’s 2-1 loss to Crystal Palace left them a point behind United; the match could decide who finishes second to likely champions Chelsea. United enter on five straight league wins, while City have slipped from title contention to fourth place chasers.

• Federal MP Bob Katter issued a statement accusing the Queensland Government of assuming MP Billy Gordon would resign because they saw him as “a little black puppet on a string.”

• Gordon had just quit the Queensland Labor Party after allegations of domestic violence and for hiding past criminal convictions, but he chose to stay in parliament as an independent, jeopardizing the Government’s narrow majority.

• Katter argued that in similar federal cases resignations were not expected, suggested racism motivated expectations of Gordon’s exit, and said his own Lebanese background informed his comments.

• The phrase “black puppet” triggered social-media criticism; Katter defended it as a deliberate reference to perceived racial overtones and insisted Gordon would not become a government puppet like past independents Tony Windsor or Rob Oakeshott.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Downers Grove, Illinois, was born with cerebral palsy but refuses to be limited by it. After years of bullying and public stares, she began posting upbeat dance videos—including one set to Taylor Swift’s “Shake It Off”—to challenge stereotypes about disability and show she can do what any other teenager does. Doctors once doubted she would walk; today she dances, drives, attends college, and has started motivational speaking in Chicago-area schools. Her goal is to make people “think before judging” and to improve how television, film, and fashion portray people with disabilities.

• Orlando City have asked Manchester United about signing 26-year-old striker Javier Hernandez, whose Mexican nationality and Latin-American appeal would suit the MLS club’s large Hispanic fanbase; Kaka captains the Adrian-Heath-coached side.  
• United want about £8 million; the player, frustrated during his loan at Real Madrid, has only one year left on his contract and is also being tracked by Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio and Inter Milan.  
• Separately, United have improved their contract offer to 19-year-old midfielder Andreas Pereira, yet Paris SG, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven and Feyenoord have sounded out his father Marcos after the teenager rejected the club’s initial proposal; Pereira was on the bench against Aston Villa.

Around 12:15 a.m. Saturday at a 76 Station in South Los Angeles, at least three people argued with a man pumping gas, tried to carjack him at gunpoint, then poured gasoline on his white Dodge Charger—occupied by two passengers—and set it on fire. No one was hurt, but the car was destroyed. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is treating the case as arson, using surveillance footage in the search for the still-at-large suspects.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor from Lamoni, Iowa, has surrendered his state license after admitting to:  
• Accepting sex as payment for chiropractic services.  
• Performing exorcisms on patients.  
• Advising some patients to stop taking medication he had prescribed.

Under a signed agreement with the Iowa Board of Chiropractic, Manuel cannot seek reinstatement of his license for at least ten years and must prove the cited problems no longer exist before practicing again. Although only three patients rated him on HealthGrades.com, he received perfect satisfaction scores. Manuel has not worked at his former practice for some time, and the listed clinic address is a house on a residential street.

• A Russian SU-27 fighter intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane Tuesday over the Baltic Sea, in international airspace north of Poland.  
• The Pentagon says the jet’s high-speed, close-quarter maneuvers were “unsafe and unprofessional,” and it will lodge a formal diplomatic complaint.  
• Moscow claims the U.S. aircraft was approaching Russia with its transponder off; U.S. European Command says that claim is false.  
• A similar close pass between the same aircraft types occurred a year ago over the Sea of Okhotsk.  
• Encounters between Russian and U.S. aircraft are frequent in Northern Europe and near Alaska.

On the night of March 27 in the parking lot of the Marriott Springhill Suites near Salt Lake City’s airport, a thief broke the rear-side window of an FBI agent’s vehicle, tied a rope to the hard-cased sniper rifle inside, and—apparently using another vehicle’s momentum—ripped the padlocked, chained case out of the truck safe and through the window.  

• Stolen: the sniper rifle (still missing), plus the agent’s gear bag, backpack, clothing and tools (most bags and clothing later found at a nearby Residence Inn).  
• Evidence: two skid marks, rope fragments, the case’s broken handle, and a window frame pulled from the door.  
• Security details: rifle had been “secured properly”; hotel has no surveillance cameras; serial number entered into the National Crime Information Computer.  
• Context: theft occurred about a week before President Obama’s Utah visit; Secret Service was notified.  
• Motive/targeting: police do not know whether the agent’s car was specifically targeted.

In July 2012 on Mugga Way, Red Hill (Canberra), 71-year-old Luigi Costa allegedly stomped on, stabbed and cut the throat of his neighbour, Terrence Freebody. Forensic psychiatrist Prof. Paul Mullen told the jury Costa’s behaviour, triple-0 calls and a faeces trail showed moment-to-moment mood swings and confusion caused by dementia compounded by alcohol. Mullen believes Costa did not understand his actions or their consequences; he rejects the prosecutor’s claim that Costa faked memory loss. Costa’s mental state is central because proof of severe impairment could allow a not-guilty verdict.

Everton beat Burnley 1-0 at Goodison Park, with Kevin Mirallas scoring in the 29th minute. Earlier, a 10th-minute penalty—won after David Jones fouled Aaron Lennon—was taken by Ross Barkley instead of regular taker Leighton Baines (15 goals from 16 spot-kicks). Barkley’s effort was saved by goalkeeper Tom Heaton. Manager Roberto Martinez defended the choice, saying Barkley had every right to step up and that several players, including Romelu Lukaku if present, can take penalties according to how they feel; Baines accepted the decision. The incident recalled January’s West Brom match when Mirallas overruled Baines and also missed.

• Two Holland America Line passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the ms Ryndam at 11:30 a.m. Thursday while the ship was docked in San Juan, Puerto Rico.  
• The cruise line says the incident appears to be a murder-suicide; the FBI and local authorities are investigating.  
• Cleaning staff discovered the bodies, the cabin was secured, and the cruise line is fully cooperating.  
• The ship had departed Tampa, Florida, on March 29 for a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise.

Patrick Kluivert, former Netherlands striker and 2014 World Cup assistant, is now coaching Curaçao. His team eliminated Montserrat 4-3 on aggregate (2-1 home win, 2-2 away draw), clinched by an 87th-minute goal from substitute Charlton Vicento, and advanced to CONCACAF’s second 2018 World Cup qualifying round. Curaçao will play Cuba on June 8 and 16. Kluivert’s mother is Curaçaoan, and he previously reached World Cup semi-finals in 1998 (player) and 2014 (assistant).

Esteban Cambiasso, a midfielder who collected 15 trophies with Inter Milan and further honours at River Plate and Real Madrid, says that helping relegation-threatened Leicester City stay in the Premier League would feel “like winning a cup.”  

• Leicester sit bottom, seven points from safety with eight matches left and no win since January; West Ham are next opponents.  
• Cambiasso, on a one-year deal signed last summer, has become a key player and believes survival is still achievable, stressing that saving the club is now his primary objective.  
• He is enjoying life in the East Midlands and may extend his stay, but first wants “a few more points” to complete what he would regard as another trophy-level achievement.

• Gemma, 23, has two children (both under five, each by a different father).  
• When each baby was four months old she gave them to her 52-year-old mother, Debbie, who has raised them ever since.  
• Debbie says Gemma is unfit to parent because she drinks heavily, parties, takes the legal high M-Kat, is unemployed and has a history of stealing (including an iPad belonging to one of the children, confirmed by a lie-detector test on The Jeremy Kyle Show).  
• Fearing more theft and neglect, Debbie is threatening to bar Gemma from her house and from all contact with the children.  
• The children call Debbie “mum”; she says Gemma must stop drinking, drug use and partying if she wants any role in their lives.

Eden Hazard put Chelsea 1-0 up against Manchester United after a move that began when John Terry tackled Radamel Falcao from behind, winning the ball near halfway. Cesc Fabregas picked up the loose ball, fed Oscar, whose back-heel set up Hazard to score. During the Sky Sports half-time analysis, pundits Graeme Souness, Thierry Henry and Jamie Redknapp all said Terry’s challenge was a foul—Souness calling it “a forearm smash,” Henry saying he would want the free-kick “all day long,” and Redknapp adding that, even if Falcao might have stayed up, the tackle “shouldn’t have gone unpunished.”

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott, her husband, the tour manager and the driver safely escaped when the band’s bus caught fire Thursday morning on Interstate 30 near Dallas after a rear tire blew. Bystander Michael Barnett filmed the blaze and posted it on CNN iReport, while Scott shared Instagram photos showing the charred vehicle and noting that everything in the back lounge burned except her Bible. Bandmates Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood were not aboard, and the group is still scheduled to play Sunday’s 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas.

• Dr Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is testing satellites covered with mirrors that turn sunlight into laser light via semiconductors and beam it to ground-based solar panels, potentially supplying household heat, making solar power practical even in Scotland, and restoring electricity to disaster areas.  
• Early Scottish trials succeeded; larger-scale trials are planned for Portugal.  
• The beams are weak—“not powerful enough to blind a pigeon”—yet control of the satellites could still raise security concerns.  
• A separate Tokyo proposal would mount a low-power laser on the ISS to nudge centimeter-scale space debris into Earth’s atmosphere for burn-up; it, too, is unsuitable as a weapon.

Stephen Munden, 54—a convicted paedophile with autism, learning difficulties and a “fanatical obsession” with young girls—absconded from a Winchfield psychiatric hospital near Hook, Hampshire, at about 6:15 p.m. on Tuesday. Munden is 5 ft 8 in, heavy-set, with dark hair and may now be clean-shaven. He was under a hospital order imposed last August after he sexually touched a three-year-old on a bus and admitted ten offences involving indecent child images; police also found children’s clothes, books and dolls in his home. Detectives have launched an urgent search and are appealing for any sightings or information on his whereabouts.

A Los Angeles court ruled that V. Stiviano must return more than $2.6 million in gifts she received from former Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling. Shelly Sterling’s suit alleged that her husband used joint funds to buy Stiviano a Ferrari, two Bentleys, a Range Rover, a $1.8 million duplex, and smaller items. Shelly’s attorney called the verdict a family victory and a precedent for spouses seeking repayment of “ill-begotten” gifts. Stiviano argued the gifts were legitimate. The case follows Donald Sterling’s 2014 downfall and NBA ban after a leaked recording captured him making racist remarks to Stiviano about her social-media photos with African-Americans, including Magic Johnson.

Thierry Henry, speaking as a Sky Sports pundit after Arsenal’s 0-0 draw with Chelsea, said Arsenal cannot win the Premier League without major summer reinforcements.  
Key points:  
• Arsenal must buy four first-team players to strengthen the spine of the side: a goalkeeper, centre-back, holding midfielder and a “top, top” striker.  
• Henry doubts Olivier Giroud can lead a title-winning attack, despite Giroud’s 14 league goals, and urges Arsène Wenger to sign a higher-calibre forward.  
• He cites Chelsea’s title-deciding purchases of Courtois, Matic, Fàbregas and Costa as the model Arsenal should follow.  
• Arsenal sit third in the league, level on points with Manchester City and with a game in hand; their remaining fixtures are Hull (A), Swansea (H), Man United (A), Sunderland (H) and West Brom (H).

Maurice Van Ryn, a wealthy NSW businessman and Bega Cheese executive, has pleaded guilty to 12 child-sex offences, the most serious being persistent sexual abuse of a child. In a victim-impact statement to Sydney’s District Court, one of his female victims described:

• Years of abuse that she initially believed might be normal because she was a child and “didn’t know it was against the law.”  
• Keeping the abuse secret until learning Van Ryn had been arrested, after which she came forward.  
• Ongoing trauma: depression since age 14, hospitalisation for self-harm, a suicide attempt, fear of future relationships, shame about others finding out, and anxiety over Van Ryn’s eventual release.

Van Ryn sat quietly in the dock and did not look at her while she spoke. The sentencing hearing continues.

Arsenal’s 19-year-old midfielder Serge Gnabry, sidelined since the March 2014 Champions League tie with Bayern Munich due to a serious knee injury, has now completed his second full 90-minute outing in a week for the club’s Under-21s (a 1-0 loss to Reading). The Germany U-21 international, who had impressed for the first team before his setback, says he feels “better and better,” is over the injury, and is targeting a first-team return.

Jacob Phillips, 23, an accountancy graduate working for Liam Gallagher’s Pretty Green label, died after falling about 70 ft from a cliff in Penarth, South Wales. On a December night out in Cardiff, he and friends Padraig Crowley and Rory Robinson took a taxi but lacked the money to pay. They got out under the pretext of using an ATM, then ran. Taxi driver Dave Sidaway followed but stopped when he could not see ahead. In the darkness Phillips jumped a fence on the disused Northern Promenade (The Dardanelles) and, unaware of the sheer drop just beyond, plunged to his death. His body was discovered the next morning by a dog walker. Cardiff Coroner’s Court recorded accidental death, noting he was disorientated and could not have known the danger. Phillips had returned to Wales from Reading to spend Christmas with his mother.

• Summer 2014 saw HM Passport Office overwhelmed by 3.6 million applications, leaving more than 500,000 passports stuck in the system.  
• Thousands of travellers paid £30 per passport for fast-track upgrades, and many still missed their holidays.  
• Ministers rejected a Home Affairs Committee call for blanket refunds, arguing it would “create a precedent.”  
• Only 2,191 compensation claims were approved between April 2014 and January 2015—virtually unchanged from the previous year—paying out £203,066 in total (average £92.68; highest £5,463).  
• The agency cannot say how many claims were rejected due to a complaints-database failure.  
• Meanwhile, HM Passport Office recorded a £42.3 million surplus (April–October 2014) and paid managers £1.8 million in bonuses for 2013-14 (average £499; highest £3,500).  
• Victims such as Mathew Bean and Hayley Kirkham, who lost about £1,500 on a missed Morocco trip, received nothing.  
• Home Affairs Committee chair Keith Vaz called the situation “astonishing.”

A three-bedroom, semi-detached “time-warp” house in Horfield, Bristol, untouched since it was built in the 1930s, is being auctioned on 30 April at the County Ground with a guide price of £200,000–£250,000. Inside it still retains:

• Original stained-glass windows (ships in the hall, coats of arms in the living room).  
• Wood-panelled hallway with a shelf displaying period food tins.  
• Mint-green-and-black 1930s bathroom with original tiles, wooden floor and fixtures.  
• 1930s kitchen cupboards, brick open-face fireplace, dated sink and oil-fired central heating.

While the house has gained double glazing, auctioneers note that the cost of modernising it may deter developers, making it most attractive to buyers who value its intact period features.

Colin Kaepernick, originally Alex Smith’s backup, took over as the 49ers’ starting quarterback midway through the 2012 season after Smith’s concussion. A later project, drawing on alternative rock, trip-hop, hip-hop, electronica, dub, reggae and pop, released a self-titled debut album in 2001 that achieved worldwide success. Richards, the state’s second female governor, was known for her outspoken feminism and sharp one-liners; she lost her 1994 re-election bid to George W. Bush.

Aristotle (384–322 BC) was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist from Stagira in northern Classical Greece. After Plato’s death, Aristotle left Athens and, in 343 BC, became tutor to Alexander the Great at the request of Philip II of Macedon.

James VI and I (James Stuart, 19 June 1566 – 27 March 1625) ruled Scotland as James VI from 24 July 1567 and England and Ireland as James I from 24 March 1603 until his death. Scotland and England stayed separate sovereign states—with distinct parliaments, laws, and judiciaries—while he governed them in personal union. James pressed for a single Anglo-Scottish parliament, fulfilled most goals in Scotland, but in England he faced serious problems, notably the 1605 Gunpowder Plot and continual clashes with the English Parliament.

The Free State of Saxony is a land-locked German federal state that borders Brandenburg, Saxony-Anhalt, Thuringia, Bavaria, Poland (Lower Silesian and Lubusz Voivodeships) and the Czech Republic (Karlovy Vary, Liberec and Ústí nad Labem regions). It ranks 10th in size (18,413 km²) and 6th in population (about 4 million) among Germany’s 16 states, and its history stretches back more than 1,000 years. Saxony also hosts one of Germany’s 13 official wine regions; together with nearby Saale-Unstrut it is among Europe’s northernmost wine-growing areas and one of only two such regions situated in the former East Germany.

Morse code conveys text via on-off tones, lights or clicks that trained listeners can read without equipment. Character lengths are inversely related to their frequency in English, boosting speed. • Early Earth’s atmosphere and oceans formed through volcanic outgassing; this first atmosphere was nearly oxygen-free and toxic to today’s life.

Human trafficking is the trading of people for forced labour, sexual slavery, or other commercial sexual exploitation. The passage discusses two historical figures named Francis I:

Nicknamed “Francis of the Large Nose,” “the Grand Colas,” and the “Knight-King,” he actively waged wars against Emperor/King Charles V. After military setbacks, he forged a controversial alliance with Sultan Suleiman the Magnificent. The Italian War of 1536–1538 was one of his conflicts against Charles V.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost nation on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia. Home to about 92.7 million people, it is the world’s 14th-most and Asia’s 9th-most populous country. It borders China to the north; Laos to the northwest; Cambodia to the southwest; Thailand across the Gulf of Thailand to the southwest; and the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia across the South China Sea to the east and southeast. James VI and I (James Stuart) was born on 19 June 1566 and died on 27 March 1625. He became King of Scotland as James VI on 24 July 1567, and, after the union of the crowns, King of England and Ireland as James I on 24 March 1603, ruling all three kingdoms until his death. Scotland and England remained separate sovereign states—each with its own parliament, laws, and judiciary—while he governed them in personal union. James strongly promoted the idea of a single parliament for England and Scotland but encountered significant conflicts with the English Parliament during his reign.

Danielle Cormack (born 26 December 1970) is a New Zealand stage and screen actress. An original core cast member of the soap Shortland Street, she is also known for playing:

• Ephiny in Xena: Warrior Princess  
• Cynthia Ross in The Cult  
• Shota in Legend of the Seeker  
• Kate Leigh in Underbelly: Razor  

Her work includes the film Separation City (2009) and the Australian series Rake. Her most prominent recent role was Bea Smith in the Foxtel prison drama Wentworth, which she led for four years until leaving in 2016.
Rob Sheridan (born October 11, 1979) is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer best known for his extensive work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade has starred or co-starred in the films Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2, among others. Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser is a 2015 American comedy directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett, born on August 16, 1958, is an American actress.

“Artpop” drew generally mixed critical reviews but proved commercially strong: it debuted at #1 on the U.S. Billboard 200 with 258,000 first-week sales, becoming Gaga’s second straight U.S. chart-topper. The album sold 757,000 copies (U.S.) and 2.3 million worldwide, ranking as 2013’s ninth best-seller.
In 2006 the Red Hot Chili Peppers released Stadium Arcadium, their fifth and final album with guitarist John Frusciante; he later confirmed his departure from the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, during her tenure as Prime Minister, introduced the policies later labeled “Thatcherism.” Despite ongoing debate over those policies, she remains a controversial yet widely acclaimed figure, often regarded as one of the most influential and greatest politicians in British history.

Michael Andrew “Duff” McKagan (born February 5, 1964) is an American musician, singer, songwriter and author who also writes weekly columns on various subjects for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor who, beyond his acting roles, has provided narration for commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia (officially València) is the capital of the Valencian Community (also called the Valencian Country), an autonomous community of Spain. It is Spain’s third-largest city after Madrid and Barcelona, with about 800,000 residents in the city proper and a metropolitan population of roughly 1.7–2.5 million, making its metro area the country’s third largest.
Buffy Summers is a character who was played by Kristy Swanson in the film version and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
“Make It or Break It” officially ended with an April 26 2012 announcement that its third season would be its last; the series finale aired on May 14 2012.

Speech recognition is an interdisciplinary branch of computational linguistics that uses methods from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering to convert spoken language into text. Its applications range from voice dialing, call routing, and home-automation control to speech search, data entry, document preparation, speech-to-text tools, and aircraft Direct Voice Input. Recent advances stem from deep-learning techniques, reflected in a surge of research and adoption by firms such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC.

Richard Alf (January 26, 1952 – January 4, 2012) was an American businessman and former comic-book store owner who co-founded San Diego Comic-Con International and became its chairman in 1970. The event began in 1970 as the Golden State Comic Book Convention, created by Shel Dorf, Richard Alf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry; it was later renamed the San Diego Comic Book Convention.
“Fist of Legend” is a remake of the 1972 film “Fist of Fury,” which originally starred Bruce Lee.

• Victor Dubuisson (France) shot 67 to join overnight leader Jaco Van Zyl (South Africa) on 16-under par.  
• Rory McIlroy carded a third consecutive 67 and is 15-under alongside Kiradech Aphibarnrat (Thailand).  
   – McIlroy three-putted the 3rd and 10th for his first bogeys of the week, then birdied the 11th and holed an eagle after a 229-yard 4-iron.  
   – He believes a lower round is possible tomorrow as he seeks his first win since May.  
   – Returning from a summer ankle ligament rupture, McIlroy leads the Race to Dubai by 271,214 points over Danny Willett with three events left after the Turkish Open.  
• Chris Wood sits at -13 and Richard Bland at -12 after sharing second place overnight.

• Al-Wefaq leader Sheikh Ali Salman says any new “national dialogue” must come with firm, public concessions from Bahrain’s rulers and be led by someone who can speak for the royal family, preferably reform-minded Crown Prince Salman bin Hamad al-Khalifa.  
• The ruling court is split: the crown prince favours negotiation, while hard-liners grouped around long-serving Prime Minister Sheikh Khalifa bin Salman al-Khalifa resist talks, fearing further opposition demands.  
• Salman recalls that on 14 March 2011 the opposition and crown prince agreed a seven-point roadmap toward a constitutional monarchy, but the deal collapsed when GCC troops entered Bahrain hours later.  
• Though many younger protesters now distrust formal politics, Salman insists dialogue with reformists inside the Sunni monarchy, continued peaceful demonstrations, and the release of 13 jailed opposition figures are essential; without those prisoners “the dialogue will fail.”  
• He urges stronger, public pressure from the US and UK: hopes new US Secretary of State John Kerry will be more proactive than Hillary Clinton, and criticizes Britain for relying on private appeals that Bahrain’s government ignores.

Christopher Hogwood, pioneering conductor and scholar of the early-music movement, has died at his Cambridge home after several months of illness. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to follow.  

Key points  
• Founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, which he led on six continents for about 30 years.  
• Under his direction the AAM made 200+ recordings, including the first complete Mozart symphony cycle on period instruments and the acclaimed 1980 Handel Messiah (named by BBC Music Magazine among the top 20 recordings ever).  
• Worked with leading orchestras worldwide; earlier roles included keyboard player/musicologist with the Academy of St Martin-in-the-Fields and founding member of the Early Music Consort of London.  
• Artistic director of the King’s Lynn Festival and Boston’s Handel and Haydn Society; taught at Harvard, was honorary professor at Cambridge, and professor-at-large at Cornell.  
• Educated at Cambridge (keyboard studies with Rafael Puyana, Mary Potts, Zuzana Ruzickova and Gustav Leonhardt).  

Tributes from colleagues such as Christopher Purvis, Richard Egarr, Dame Emma Kirkby and David Thomas praise his generosity, scholarship and lasting influence on historically informed performance.

• In the year to 31 March 2016 Scotland recorded 57 homicide victims, five fewer than the previous year, marking the lowest annual total since 1976 and about half the level of nine years earlier.  
• Only one 2015-16 homicide case remained unsolved at the end of the period.  
• Sharp instruments were used in 51 % of killings (29 cases), nearly all involving knives (26).  
• Police identified 31 % of accused persons (20 people) as being under the influence of alcohol or alcohol plus drugs; most others had unknown status.  
• Justice Secretary Michael Matheson welcomed the fall but said continued prevention, education, and enforcement—particularly around alcohol misuse—are essential.  
• Labour justice spokesperson Claire Baker urged caution, noting past upward revisions of homicide data, a 45-year high in sexual crime, and a 27 % rise in attempted murder and serious assault.
