• The previous year’s homicide count for 2014-15 was revised from 59 to 62 after three deaths were reclassified.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 at Sunderland, becoming the first team the Black Cats have beaten in this Premier League season. Dan Gosling’s opener—Bournemouth’s first goal in three games—was overturned by strikes from Victor Anichebe and a Jermain Defoe penalty, and the Cherries could not equalise despite Sunderland being reduced to ten men after Steven Pienaar’s dismissal. Manager Eddie Howe said confidence is not the problem, pointing to the six goals his side scored against Hull recently, but lamented missed chances and stressed the need to move on.

• Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott insists that “stopping the boats” is the only way to prevent migrant deaths at sea; Australia intercepts boat-arriving migrants, detains them offshore and resettles them elsewhere.  
• A New York Times editorial labelled this policy “brutal,” “inhumane,” and of “dubious legality,” urging Europe not to copy it.  
• Citing the photo of drowned Syrian child Alan Kurdi, Abbott replied that Australia has ended such tragedies by halting “illegal boats.”  
• In a separate controversy, Abbott said Islamic State is “worse than the Nazis” because it flaunts its atrocities; Australian Jewish leaders condemned the comparison, noting the Nazis’ systematic genocide. Abbott later affirmed his remarks while saying he was not “ranking evil.”

• The U.S. accuses Russia and the Syrian government of escalating attacks on civilians, especially in Aleppo, and of striking hospitals and blocking aid, including the 19 September convoy attack.  
• After warning Moscow to halt the bombing, Washington has now suspended the U.S.–Russia negotiations meant to sustain the cease-fire, withdrawn staff sent for a planned Joint Implementation Centre, but will continue basic military “de-confliction” talks.  
• Russia “regrets” the U.S. decision, denies bombing the aid convoy, and counters that Washington failed to ease Aleppo’s humanitarian crisis or separate jihadist factions from moderate rebels.  
• Since the truce collapsed two weeks ago, Aleppo—Syria’s largest northern city—has faced heavy air-strikes; its main trauma hospital was hit for the third time in a week, hundreds (including children) have been killed, and about 250,000 civilians remain trapped.

Policy Exchange’s report “Ending Expensive Social Tenancies” proposes that councils sell social‐housing properties worth more than the regional average each time they fall vacant.  

Key points:  
• About 22 % of the UK’s 3.78 million social homes (816,000 dwellings) are “expensive”; roughly 3.5 % (28,500) become vacant each year.  
• Annual sales could raise £5.5 bn gross, or £4.5 bn after clearing existing debt.  
• Receipts could fund construction of 80,000–170,000 new social homes a year, cut the 1.8 million-strong waiting list by c.500,000, and create the largest social-house-building programme since the 1970s.  
• The Prime Minister’s office backs councils that choose this approach, saying it would use stock “more efficiently”.  
• Labour and housing groups oppose a compulsory sell-off, arguing it would expel low-income families from mixed communities and worsen segregation.  
• Polling cited by the think-tank claims 73 % of the public, including social tenants, oppose allocating council houses valued above the local average.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, was found dead at his Swansea home after developing a widespread rash days after asthma treatment. Swansea is the centre of a measles outbreak that has reached 942 cases and led to 83 hospitalisations since November. Lab tests confirm he had measles, but it is not yet known if the disease caused his death; an inquest and further tests are pending. His family say no close relatives, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter, have measles, and they are unsure how he caught it.

Vincent Hudson, 54, of Loweswater Avenue in Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offence involving a boy under 16 that is alleged to have occurred in 2001. He is scheduled to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates’ Court.

Gateshead 1–1 Guiseley (National League)

• Gateshead entered the game unbeaten in nine league matches; Guiseley in five.  
• Guiseley struck first on 15 minutes: a long throw reached James Hurst, who fed Jake Lawlor for a simple finish.  
• Key first-half moments: Gateshead’s Liam Hogan blocked Jordan Preston’s goal-bound effort; Guiseley keeper Jonny Maxted denied Wes York just before half-time.  
• Gateshead equalised on 62 minutes when substitute Derek Asamoah slipped, allowing Wes York to curl a shot into the top-right corner from the edge of the box.  
• Final score: Gateshead 1, Guiseley 1.

Bristol Sport Ltd plans to redevelop the current football ground by replacing two stands to boost capacity, instead of building a new Ashton Vale stadium stalled by a town-green bid. The scheme was approved by Bristol City Council in November. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown says the Section 106 agreement will be signed imminently, after which a six-week judicial-review window applies; if no review arises by March, construction will begin in May.

• Lancashire’s shale-gas driller Cuadrilla has halted “fracking” after a 1.5-magnitude earthquake on Friday—the second (after a 2.3-magnitude tremor on 1 April) within two months near its Preese Hall, Poulton-le-Fylde site.  
• Cuadrilla will study British Geological Survey (BGS) data and consult authorities before deciding whether to restart; the review will take several weeks.  
• BGS instruments show both quakes occurred about 2 km deep and within roughly 2 km of the well, sharing “similar location and mechanism”; the latest was felt by at least one resident.  
• BGS notes that injecting pressurised water into rock, as in shale-gas extraction, can induce earthquakes and is monitoring operations as a precaution.  
• While U.S. fracking has drawn environmental criticism, a recent Commons energy committee report urged U.K. ministers to back the practice, citing the possibility of controlling risks through strict regulation and good industry practice.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old Liverpool city-centre bagpiper, was tried on three fraud charges for busking in April 2015 with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes. The jury at Liverpool Crown Court convicted him on one count—deeming the banner misleadingly suggested he was collecting money for the charity—but acquitted him of the other two counts. Carpenter, who said the banner was a tribute and that he was only busking, had previously been allowed by the campaign’s chairman to display the banner provided it was not used for fundraising. Sentencing is due in January.

Ipswich Town beat Queens Park Rangers 3-0.

• Goals  
  – Grant Ward’s mishit shot opened the scoring.  
  – Keeper Alex Smithies sliced a clearance straight to Luke Varney, who rolled in the second.  
  – Cole Skuse’s long-range effort fell to Tom Lawrence, who finished calmly for the third.

• Chances  
  – Ipswich, goalless in seven of their previous ten league games, could have scored more: Christophe Berra headed wide from six yards, Skuse volleyed straight at Smithies, and several further shots were saved.  
  – QPR’s only real threat was Sandro’s late header against the post.

• Context  
  – The win lifts Mick McCarthy’s side four places to 14th, dropping Ian Holloway’s Rangers to 15th.  
  – QPR have one win in six away matches.

• Manager reaction  
  – McCarthy: Smithies’ error “set us up,” and Varney “epitomised everything I want.”  
  – Holloway: the second goal was “a calamity,” but defenders should have helped; the team must become “mentally tougher.”
Wells, 23, scored 373 runs in last season’s T20 Blast at an average of 28.69 and a strike-rate of 138.66, and says the club’s elite-performance environment shows it is moving in the right direction.

The Reds, sitting fifth in National Two South, earned a second consecutive victory by defeating third-placed Chinnor 29-12. Coach Churcher credited front-row players Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey and Craig Williams, noting the front five made over 70 tackles. The Reds’ next eight fixtures include seven lower-ranked sides and leaders Old Elthamians. Churcher says the team still needs improvement: the Chinnor match was a gritty, not complete, performance and must be built upon.

Police in India have arrested 28-year-old Nazrul (alias Nazu), a Bangladeshi national, at a Kolkata railway station for allegedly raping a 74-year-old nun during a 14 March attack on a convent school in Ranaghat. He is the sixth of eight identified suspects; two remain at large. All five earlier arrestees have named Nazrul as the rapist. Authorities acted on a tip that he would return from Bangladesh, where he had fled after being seen on CCTV. Earlier, Milon Sarkar was arrested and labelled the gang’s leader, though his exact role is unclear. The assault, which also involved theft and ransacking of the convent, sparked nationwide outrage and street protests.

The passage describes an interactive video presented by Robert Opie, founder of London’s Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising.  
Key points:  
• Opie explains why consumer buying habits change, highlighting three drivers: the spread of domestic freezers, the introduction of washing powder and the influx of cheaper imports.  
• Interactive sections show how ownership and rankings of leading UK brands are shifting.  
• Viewers are advised the video works best full-screen and may not function on older browsers; a non-interactive version and related reading links (on Chinese ownership, food-freezing tips, a UK brand survey and the museum itself) are provided.

Two phone scams occurred a week apart.  

• 15 September: a 71-year-old Sandyhills woman was duped by a caller pretending to be from BT.  
• 22 September: a Stranraer woman lost money after a caller, also posing as BT technical support, remotely accessed her computer.  

Police Constable Siobhan Pellett warned that scammers easily obtain remote access and steal large sums, urging the public never to give banking details over the phone because legitimate firms do not request them.

John Duffy, 37, has left Swinton Lions to become head coach of third-placed Championship club Featherstone on a one-year deal. The Scotland assistant coach will debut in Saturday’s final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Chairman Mark Campbell praised Duffy’s achievements at Swinton, where he is succeeded by former assistant Stuart Littler. Duffy previously enjoyed a 16-year playing career with Leigh, Widnes and Salford.

At 12:50 GMT on Sunday, an RNLI crew from Porthcawl, accompanied by a medic and a coastguard search-and-rescue helicopter, went to Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve. They found a rider unconscious on wet sand with head injuries and severe cold. After initial treatment, she was flown to Cardiff’s University Hospital of Wales.

• At a UN‐organised World Radiocommunication Conference in Geneva, delegates from 160+ countries agreed to reserve a dedicated radio frequency for satellite reception of ADS-B signals from aircraft.  
• This will let satellites, not just ground radars, receive the signals, enabling real-time, global flight tracking and closing the roughly 70 % of airspace now lacking coverage.  
• The move was spurred by the March 2014 disappearance of Malaysia Airlines flight MH370, which carried 239 people and highlighted gaps in existing tracking systems.  
• ITU officials hailed the decision as a rapid response to that incident, while ICAO has set November 2016 for airlines to adopt new rules requiring position reports at least every 15 minutes, or more frequently in emergencies.

Julian Hernandez, missing from Alabama since age five in August 2002, has been found alive at 18 living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland, Ohio. A college-application problem led to a 30 October FBI tip; the FBI, Alabama police, and the National Center for Missing & Exploited Children confirmed his identity. Bobby Hernandez, 53, was arrested for the abduction and for tampering with records used to obtain an Ohio driver’s license in 2012. He is held in Cuyahoga County Jail on $250,000 bail. Julian’s mother has been informed.

• A fire on 2 March at Recovered Fuels Shipping Ltd’s Duncan Street site kept firefighters on-scene for several days, disrupted train services and caused travel delays.  
• Although Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) found the operator, Asset and Land Group, “broadly compliant” with fire-safety law during nine inspections in the past year, it had warned the Environment Agency (EA) in February about potential fire risks.  
• Following the blaze, the EA first suspended the firm from accepting waste and has now decided to revoke its environmental permit; the company may appeal until 7 August, after which it must cease operations at the site and remove all waste.  
• Recovered Fuels Shipping Ltd could not be reached for comment, and the fire’s cause remains unknown.

• The pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia has submitted two bills to the Russian Duma in response to the Ukraine/Crimea crisis.  

1. Territorial-accession bill  
   – Would let Russia absorb a neighbouring area if its population or leaders request it via referendum or appeal, without needing a treaty with the parent state.  
   – Framed for cases where a neighbouring state is “disintegrating.”  
   – Mirrors Russia’s post-2008 moves in Abkhazia and South Ossetia.  

2. Fast-track passport bill  
   – Removes fees, prior Russian residence, proof of funds and the need to renounce Ukrainian citizenship.  
   – Allows Ukrainians to apply in Russian missions until 1 August and get passports in two months (instead of a year).  
   – Justified as protection for “Russian-speaking” Ukrainians against the “brown threat.”  

• Crimea is central: separatist sentiment is high, many residents—especially in Sevastopol, home of the Black Sea Fleet—already hold Russian passports.  
• Russian MPs, including well-known figures, have travelled to Crimea to promote the measures.

McLaren, once one of Formula 1’s most successful outfits (182 wins, 12 drivers’ and 8 constructors’ titles, 23 % win rate), now measure success in starting on the third- or fourth-row and scoring a few points.  

Key history and decline  
• Highs: titles in 1974 (Fittipaldi), 1976 (Hunt); domination under Ron Dennis—1984-85, the legendary Honda era of 1988-91 (15 wins from 16 in ’88 with Senna/Prost); and renewed success with Mercedes engines and Mika Häkkinen in 1998-99.  
• Near-misses & scandals: lost the 2007 constructors’ crown and were fined $100 m for the Ferrari “spy-gate” affair; endured “lie-gate” with Hamilton in 2009. Hamilton’s 2008 drivers’ title is their most recent.  
• Slide: performance dipped sharply from 2013 when the chassis faltered; today the car is good but the returning Honda power-unit is weak.

Present situation  
Ron Dennis has retaken control, believes the team’s chassis is already one of the best and that Honda will deliver a competitive engine next year. Fernando Alonso re-joined in 2015 on faith that McLaren-Honda offers his best route to a third title.  

Outlook  
Dennis insists McLaren will be the team that ends Mercedes’ dominance and will win “championships, plural,” yet for now the team survives mainly on belief as it waits to see if history’s cycle of slump-then-revival repeats once more.

• Victim: Thomas “Tommy” Baker, 44, from Everton.  
• Incident: Shot in the head and chest on 27 January while getting into his car outside Phoenix Gym at Stanley Meat Market, Old Swan, Liverpool; died later in hospital.  
• Suspects: Three Liverpool men (two aged 29, one aged 32) arrested and held for questioning.  
• Investigation details: Police believe gunmen waited about an hour outside the gym; they are seeking a silver VW Polo that sped away via Balmoral Rd, Molyneux Rd and Queens Rd. CCTV witnesses near the market are urged to come forward.

Five ways people are taking Christmas celebrations online and on-screen:

1. Everyday Church Online  
   • UK-based web church launched in September; worshippers from 61 nations log in to chat and watch recorded sermons.  
   • Christmas series uses a Star Wars theme – “The Hope Awakens” – streamed all day.

2. Guardians of Ancora mobile game  
   • Free fantasy Bible game for 8- to 11-year-olds (Android, iPhone, Kindle).  
   • 45,000 players in four months; new Christmas quests lead children to the nativity story.

3. Viral nativity videos  
   • “The Digital Story of Nativity” (Viral.de, 2010) retells the story through social-media updates; nearly six million views.  
   • Churches Advertising Network’s “Christmas Starts with a Baby’s Giggle” has about 250,000 views; cinema release refused for being “too religious”.

4. Manga Bible adaptations  
   • Next Manga has distributed 3 million books and 5 million booklets; now releasing app and e-book versions.  
   • Nativity volume “Manga Messiah” is in 33 languages; 25,000 Arabic copies sent to Syrian and Libyan refugees.

5. Social-media outreach  
   • Churches use Facebook, Twitter and Instagram to prompt brief spiritual reflections.  
   • Commentators say Jesus “would definitely be on Twitter,” highlighting the medium’s importance for modern ministry.

An eight-day inquiry in Ebbw Vale is considering a plan to take 250 ha (600 acres) of common land for a proposed circuit, with backers, including Blaenau Gwent Council, offering 320 ha (800 acres) of replacement land. Expert views diverge: Natural Resources Wales doubts the substitute land’s equal ecological value yet does not oppose the scheme; the developers’ ecology report predicts a biodiversity “net gain,” a claim challenged by Gwent Wildlife Trust. After the hearing, the Planning Inspectorate for Wales will issue a recommendation, and Welsh Government ministers will make the final decision.

• On 1 April the Russian newspaper Novaya Gazeta reported that more than 100 men suspected of being gay had been detained in Chechnya, at least three killed, and others tortured with electric shocks and beatings at a prison near Argun.  
• The Russian LGBT Network, in contact with victims, confirmed the arrests, is helping people escape, and warns it will take the case to the International Criminal Court if Russia fails to act.  
• Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov dismissed the allegations as “lies,” and his spokesman claimed “there were no gay people in Chechnya.”  
• In response to the article, Chechen Muslim clerics met on 3 April, declared the report an insult to their faith and Chechen men, and vowed “retribution” against the “instigators.” Mufti Salah-haji Mezhiev publicly endorsed that threat.  
• Novaya Gazeta interprets the clerics’ statement as a call for violence against journalists and has appealed to Russian authorities for protection while pledging to continue its investigations.  
• Previous Novaya Gazeta reporters Anna Politkovskaya and Natalia Estemirova—both probing Chechen abuses—and opposition politician Boris Nemtsov were murdered; Chechen involvement has been alleged but not resolved.

• Investing Solutions is a south-London lettings agency that specialises in housing single homeless men aged 35+, making high profits by renting shared houses, claiming housing benefit for each individual tenant, and passing a lower single rent to the private landlord.

• Example: for one two-tenant house it claimed £2,114 a month in benefit while the landlord received £1,150, giving the agency about £11,600 gross profit a year.

• Over the last two years it has taken more than £2 million in housing-benefit payments from Wandsworth Council alone and is among the UK’s largest housing-benefit recipients.

• The charity Fresh Start Housing, formed by the same founder (Samir Patel) and sharing the same premises, refers homeless clients from other charities to Investing Solutions as well as to private landlords; together they have housed 788 people since 2010.

• A tenant, Nigel McCann, described multiple properties supplied by Investing Solutions as unfit—cold, damp, rat-infested and full of rubbish—and said “it’s all about the money, it’s not about the people.”

• Crisis called the charity/letting-agent link “a new low,” while both organisations insist they act legally and that most rent is passed to landlords; Patel said Fresh Start is independent with its own trustees.

• Local authorities say they are responsible for safeguarding public money through inspections and enforcement.

Great Britain’s men lost their final warm-up to the Netherlands.  
• GB led most of the first three quarters (up 35–24 in Q2, ahead again after three straight Ben Gordon threes in Q3) but the Dutch opened the fourth with a 10-0 run, moved in front 71–60 and never relinquished it.  
• Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and Ben Gordon 13 for GB; Worthy De Jong had 18 for the visitors.  
• Coach Joe Prunty, who will trim his roster before the six-game EuroBasket qualifying programme, said the team must “complete on every play” and praised Gordon’s third-quarter burst.  
• GB begin their qualifiers in mid-week away to Hungary.

• Floyd Mayweather submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) just before the deadline asking to use 8oz gloves – lighter than the 10oz gloves normally required for 154-lb bouts.  
• The NAC will publicly debate the request on 16 August; its priority is fighter safety and it has never before approved 8oz gloves at 154 lbs.  
• Conor McGregor, accustomed to 4oz UFC gloves, supports the switch, declaring he will attack Mayweather “with bricks.”  
• McGregor, 29, will make his boxing debut against the 40-year-old Mayweather in what could be the richest fight ever, despite criticism from figures such as Oscar De La Hoya and Gennady Golovkin.  
• NAC executive director Bob Bennett approved the matchup after reviewing extensive information, noting McGregor’s size, age, durability and his knockdowns of Nate Diaz, plus Mayweather’s lack of knockouts since 2007.  
• Bennett recommended McGregor’s team hire a boxing referee; they enlisted Hall-of-Famer Joe Cortez, who later described one sparring session with Paulie Malignaggi as “out of control,” leading Malignaggi to leave the camp.

Fleet Street, the symbolic centre of British journalism since the Daily Courant launched there in 1702, once packed almost every national newspaper into a half-mile radius of smoke-filled newsrooms, rumbling printing presses and perpetually busy pubs. Reporters Gavin Sherriff (32 years on Fleet Street) and Darryl Smith (25 years) of the Dundee-based Sunday Post are the last journalists still working on the street; their London office closes on Friday. They recall faulty phones, typewriters, jacket-only bars such as El Vino and a hard-drinking, male-dominated culture described by former staffers Robin Esser and Liz Hodgkinson, when newspapers supplied about 85 % of the public’s news. Fleet Street’s decline began after Rupert Murdoch moved his titles to Wapping in 1986; by 1988 most papers had relocated to adopt cheaper computerised printing, and former newspaper buildings became supermarkets, offices and sandwich shops. With the Sunday Post’s departure, Fleet Street’s journalistic era formally ends. Sherriff plans to write his memoirs; Smith will work as a freelance.

• J.K. Rowling says abusive tweets have “crossed my personal line,” but the mix of supportive messages “reminds me how big the world is and how many more decent people there are than not.”  
• She was heavily criticised online after donating £1 million to the Scottish independence No campaign (and gave the same amount to Labour in 2008).  
• Rowling says she has been called “a traitor” and has blocked some abusive Twitter users she believes back the SNP, insisting she will not hide such behaviour to protect any party’s image.  
• She also notes many courteous SNP supporters with whom she shares political views, and jokes she would “bring marshmallows” if her books were ever burned.  
• The SNP has just won 56 of Scotland’s 59 Westminster seats, becoming the UK’s third-largest party.

• University of Edinburgh researchers have followed 4,300 Edinburgh youngsters since 1998.  
• Key findings:  
  – Poverty doubles a child’s chance of police action for the same offence committed by a better-off peer.  
  – Household poverty independently heightens the risk of offending and of becoming a crime victim.  
  – Prior police contact is the strongest predictor of being out of education, employment or training by 18.  
  – Poor youths are about five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision.  
  – Boys are three times more likely than girls to commit violence; among girls, poverty doubles the risk.  
• Professor Lesley McAra warns that juvenile-justice contact can reinforce the poverty-violence cycle.  
• A related AQMeN study shows Scotland’s overall crime fall has bypassed the poorest areas: the heaviest crime remains concentrated in communities with high deprivation, chronic health problems and unemployment.  
• The Scottish government acknowledges falling national crime rates and cites anti-poverty initiatives, but researchers question whether current policies are reducing entrenched inequality.

• Karl Haugh (25) was fatally stabbed in a laneway in the Marian Estate, Kilkee, in the early hours of Sunday.

• Robbie Walsh, Island View, Kilrush, has been charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr Haugh. He is remanded in custody until 14 August.

• Det. Sgt. Padraig Frawley told Ennis District Court that three people, including Walsh, entered the estate around 01:00, searched for Haugh, and a fight involving weapons (knives, golf clubs) broke out. Haugh suffered a stab wound to the back and died at Limerick University Hospital at 06:00.

• A knife handle and blood-stained blade were recovered at the scene.

• Two other men arrested were released without charge; files are being prepared for the Director of Public Prosecutions.

• The court heard there is community tension in Kilkee following the killing.

In May 2014 Sinn Féin MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted that former UDR soldier Tom Elliott MP had “harassed and shot” people during his 1982-92 service. Elliott, who has a clear Ministry of Defence record, learned of the tweet from Ann Travers and Arlene Foster; Flanagan deleted it within an hour. In the High Court Flanagan accepted the allegation was “untrue and wholly without foundation” and was ordered to post a public Twitter apology, with damages still to be set by Mr Justice Stevens. Stormont’s MLA indemnity insurer has declined to cover Flanagan’s liability, a decision he is contesting separately. Elliott said the outcome vindicates him, though it took 19 months to achieve.

Hawick Knitwear, established in 1874 and employing over 230 staff, has raised weekly sweater production from about 7,500 to 9,500 to meet unexpectedly strong demand. Sales have surged for both its long-standing private-label business and the Hawick Knitwear-branded range launched in January. The firm, purchased by managing director Benny Hartop in November last year, supplies customers across nine European countries plus the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. Hartop credits the company’s dedicated workforce for the growth and expects the positive trend to continue.

• December, outside Bedford Road Lower School, Kempston: lollipop lady Sylvia Blackburn, 72, was hit by a VW Golf and suffered serious head injuries; she now receives residential care.  
• Driver Brian Wright, 55, of Kempston, is on trial at Luton Crown Court charged with causing serious injury by dangerous driving; he admits hitting her but pleads not guilty, saying the low, setting sun blinded him.  
• Prosecutors say his car ran a red light while Blackburn, in proper attire, was helping a woman and her six-year-old cross; traffic from the opposite direction had already stopped.  
• Wright expressed remorse in court, prompting a brief adjournment by Judge Michael Kay QC.  
• The sun was about ten minutes from setting at the time; the trial is ongoing.

NATO’s exercise “Dynamic Mongoose” pits ten allied surface ships, ASW helicopters, a research vessel and a French Atlantique patrol aircraft against Germany’s U-33 submarine, rehearsing how to protect a command ship and tanker from an unseen under-sea threat.  The drill is prompted by a rise in Russian submarine patrols near Sweden, Finland and the UK: Moscow now fields about 60, increasingly quiet, highly-skilled boats that analysts call the world’s most challenging adversaries.  The exercise highlights the difficulty of finding a submarine—likened to searching for a needle in a haystack—and showcases emerging tools such as unmanned underwater drones that can provide cheap, persistent surveillance.  It also exposes a major British weakness: since retiring its Nimrod fleet, the UK has no maritime patrol aircraft and must borrow cover from allies, a “key vulnerability” that could let Russian subs shadow the UK’s nuclear deterrent.  Britain’s forthcoming defence review is expected to address this gap.

• UN officials now warn that South Sudan’s conflict risks turning into genocide or ethnic cleansing.  
• Fighting that reignited in Juba in July has spread to the formerly calm Equatoria region, driving 340,000 people—about 2,500 a day—across the border into Uganda, the largest refugee flow recorded anywhere in 2016.  
• Refugees report systematic ethnic attacks: Dinka-dominated forces kill, rape or knife civilians perceived as Equatorian or Nuer; men and boys are executed, women and girls raped.  
• Towns such as Yei, only 80 km from Uganda, have emptied as families walk for days through bush and informal crossings like Busia to reach safety.  
• Uganda, assisted by aid agencies, gives each family a 30-metre plot and tarpaulin and has turned the former village of Bidi Bidi into a settlement of over 250,000 people, but water, schooling and other services are straining.  
• UNHCR urges international pressure on South Sudan’s leaders, calling the ongoing civilian slaughter “unrelenting.”

• 38-year-old McKenzie, a former Norwich and Peterborough footballer who turned pro boxer in 2013, will fight Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on 12 November for the English super-middleweight title.  
• He is unbeaten in nine bouts (8 wins, 1 draw).  
• McKenzie is the son of former British and European champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

Bridgwater Community Hospital will be rebuilt for £33 million, partly funded by the coalition’s £330 million NHS facilities programme and the balance by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. Scheduled for completion in autumn 2014 on land at Bowers Lane (subject to planning approval), the new complex will replace the cramped 1813 building and include 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray facilities and space for mobile scanners. Local staff cite significant benefits for patient comfort and integrated care. Three of Somerset’s 13 community hospitals have already been replaced and work has begun on Taunton’s Jubilee Building.

A man was shot in the chest at about 13:35 GMT outside a house on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, Sheffield, while in or near a black Mercedes. Armed officers attended, he was taken to Northern General Hospital and died. The victim, believed to be from a nearby family gathering, was helped by relatives after the shot. The incident follows several recent shootings elsewhere in Sheffield: a 25-year-old man wounded in Shiregreen on Monday, shots into an elderly couple’s Southey Green home earlier this month, and two January house shootings in High Green.

Three self-declared “activist” hacker groups dominate the cyber side of the Ukraine-Russia conflict.

1. Ukrainian Cyber Troops  
   • Pro-Kyiv, led by programmer Yevhen Dokukin.  
   • Break-ins: two Russian Interior Ministry servers and a Rostov police e-mail account (35 GB of data later indicating wounded Russian soldiers in Ukraine).  
   • Methods: DDoS attacks that disable rebel websites, hacks on PayPal/WebMoney accounts used by separatists, take-overs of CCTV cameras for troop-tracking, and printer hijacks that broadcast pro-Ukrainian messages and insults at Vladimir Putin.  
   • Ukrainian officials deny using the group’s data for targeting despite media claims.

2. Cyber Berkut  
   • Pro-Russian, anti-Western group named after Ukraine’s former Berkut riot police.  
   • Aim: derail Ukraine’s military effort, which it calls a U.S.-driven “genocide.”  
   • Operations: defaced Ukrainian government sites during U.S. Vice-President Joe Biden’s visit; claims theft of Biden-team documents on U.S. aid; hacked Kyiv billboards to brand Ukrainian leaders “war criminals”; says it disrupted October parliamentary e-vote counting, leaked defence-ministry loss data, blocked President Poroshenko’s site and published an unverified “admission” of MH17’s downing.

3. Anonymous International (b0ltai / Shaltay Boltay)  
   • Russian leak collective known for releasing Kremlin documents; source of material (hacking vs. insiders) unclear.  
   • Ukraine-related leaks include a fighter’s letter saying locals oppose separatists and e-mails of rebel commander Igor Girkin (Strelkov).  
   • Its website is now blocked in Russia.

Across the conflict, these groups expose documents, crash or hijack online services and public displays, and claim influence over information and military operations, though each insists it acts independently of state security agencies.

Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick, former First Minister Alex Salmond, long-serving Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and ex-Conservative leader Annabel Goldie all delivered farewell speeches as they prepare to stand down before the 5 May Scottish election.

Key points:
• Marwick twice became emotional—during McNeil’s powerful address on parliamentary scrutiny and again after Salmond’s valedictory remarks.  
• Salmond celebrated Holyrood’s growing powers, maintained Scotland is “not divided, but diverse,” argued the Scotland Bill still falls short of referendum-time promises, and ended with “goodbye…for now,” adding characteristic humour about Cheltenham and wishing candidates luck.  
• McNeil urged the parliament to strengthen accountability by learning from Westminster’s committee system.  
• Goldie offered a light-hearted farewell, saying she would miss Finance Secretary John Swinney’s “faux indignation.”

Wales’s Older People’s Commissioner, Sarah Rochira, is gathering first-hand accounts from residents, relatives and friends to inform a review of quality of life in Welsh residential care homes. Testimony will shape recommendations for care providers and public bodies, highlighting both good practice and problems such as “unacceptable variations” in standards. The review assesses physical and psychological health, social relationships and the care-home environment, and will also take evidence from staff, providers and public agencies. Care Forum Wales backs the review’s aims but criticises the advisory panel for lacking anyone with direct experience of running or living in a care home.

Harbro Group, a Turriff-based animal-feed manufacturer and retailer, grew pre-tax profit by £800,000 to £3.5 million in the year to June 2016, even though turnover slipped by £1 million to just over £100 million. International sales rose in Europe and new overseas markets. The firm supplies feeds for beef, sheep, dairy, pig and poultry producers and runs 19 Country Store outlets across Scotland selling farming and rural goods. While acknowledging an unpredictable agricultural outlook and still-unclear Brexit effects, the board expressed confidence in the business’s positioning.

• A man in his 70s was found dead in a house on Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday afternoon; police are treating it as murder.  
• A second man, in his 80s, was taken to hospital.  
• Detectives urgently want to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin (also known as Ian John Baker).  
  – White, about 6 ft tall, straight greying collar-length hair, average build.  
  – Believed to have been wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter-length trousers, and a dark-, light-blue and white checked short-sleeved shirt.  
  – Public warned not to approach him.  
• Det Ch Insp Martin Brunning said the inquiry is in its early stages; extra patrols are in place and anyone with information should contact police or Crimestoppers.

• IMF First Deputy Managing Director David Lipton told the National Association for Business Economics that the Fund’s latest assessment shows a “weakening baseline,” putting the world economy at a “delicate juncture.”  
• His warning follows data showing Chinese exports fell about 25 % year-on-year.  
• Because of the deteriorating outlook, the IMF is expected to cut its April global-growth forecast below the current 3.4 %.  
• A prolonged slowdown would particularly hurt companies and sectors that have relied on strong Chinese demand.

• At a council scrutiny meeting, leaders reviewed serious problems with the new Cowes chain ferry, launched 14 May.  
• Since entering service it has broken down, run aground, damaged cars and was temporarily suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency over training concerns.  
• Council leader Dave Stewart called the start “frustrating and disappointing,” announced that the crossing will be free until 2 July to acknowledge difficulties and gather feedback, and said external auditors will review the whole project.  
• Local trader Angie Booth warned that months of lost business threaten livelihoods and asked whether firms will get compensation like affected motorists.  
• Transport councillor Ian Ward replied that compensation is being considered, described the vessel as a prototype with expected “teething problems,” and said electrical faults are fixed, ramp extensions are being built to stop vehicle scraping, and grounding issues have been solved through improved seamanship.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred at about 07:30 GMT on Thursday on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott. A 32-year-old man died at the scene, and a 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road between Thursley and Liphook remained closed until early evening for police investigation.

Matching Models, a London-based agency that supplies “beautiful and talented” temporary staff, posted a job advert for a personal assistant who must have “a classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup.”  

• Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) branded the advert “appalling, unlawful and demeaning,” said it will demand an explanation of the firm’s hiring practices, and warned the agency to “act like a business in the 21st Century.”  
• Women’s rights groups (Fawcett Society) called the ads “straight out of the 1970s” and likely illegal under the UK Equality Act 2010, which forbids discriminatory job criteria.  
• Another Matching Models advert seeks a “sexy female driver” for a Knightsbridge businessman, offering £40-50k. Employment lawyer James Lynas says such wording is “clearly unlawful”; rejected male applicants or older women could sue for unlimited compensation.  
• Founder Nathalie Jansen defends the requirements, saying clients value appearance: an elderly client wants a “Jackie O”-style assistant with a small cup size for a Dior outfit; an Indian businessman requested “blonde, blue-eyed Greek” staff for his plane.  
• Company statement claims first impressions matter, even if it seems “politically incorrect.” Clients listed include MTV, Louis Vuitton, Coca-Cola, Renault F1 and Harrods.  

Critics say the agency’s practices breach equality law and perpetuate sexist, discriminatory hiring.

• A shooting took place at the hostel of the private Pragati Residential School in Bangalore.  
• The suspected gunman, Mahesh, an office assistant at the school, allegedly entered 18-year-old Gautami’s room on Tuesday evening, fatally shot her in the head, and seriously wounded another student, Sirisha (now out of danger).  
• Mahesh was arrested on Wednesday after a manhunt and has been remanded in custody until 12 April; his motive is still unknown.  
• Such incidents are very rare in Indian educational institutions; India has strict gun-control laws, though firearms are sometimes used to settle disputes.  
• A previous comparable case occurred in 2007, when a 14-year-old boy was shot dead by classmates near Delhi.

GLAAD’s “Where We Are on TV” study of scripted broadcast, cable and streaming series airing or confirmed for June 2016–May 2017 found:

• 278 regular or recurring LGBT characters.  
• Transgender representation grew from 7 to 16 characters.  
• Over 25 lesbian or bisexual women were written off or killed, including Poussey Washington (Orange Is the New Black) and Bea Smith (Wentworth).  
• Broadcast TV reached a record share of Black characters, boosted by shows such as Empire, Luke Cage and How to Get Away with Murder.  

President Sarah Kate Ellis welcomed the progress but cautioned that raw numbers “are only part of the story.”

Conservative MP David Mackintosh (Northampton South) has withdrawn as a candidate before a local party meeting that was expected to deselect him. BBC reports show about £10.25 million of public funds loaned by Northampton Borough Council—while Mackintosh was its leader—to Northampton Town FC for stadium and land development has gone missing; the partially built stand and the loan are under police investigation for alleged financial irregularities. Mackintosh, who denies wrongdoing, said it has been an honor to serve since 2015 but it is time for constituents to have a new MP.

Former Balch Springs (Dallas-area) police officer Roy Oliver, 37, was fired and indicted after he shot into a car of teenagers leaving an under-age drinking party in April, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards. Video showed the car driving away, contradicting police claims it had reversed toward officers. Oliver faces one murder charge and four counts of aggravated assault (for the four surviving teens, including two of Edwards’s brothers), carrying a possible 5- to 99-year prison term. He is free on bail, no trial date is set, and a conviction would be the first murder conviction of a Dallas-county officer since 1973.

• Melania Trump and 10-year-old Barron will remain in New York until his school year ends; no exact moving date has been given.  
• The plan drew social-media criticism—only Martha Washington (house not built) and Anna Harrison (husband died) avoided living in the White House—but some praised the decision as sensible for a school-age child.  
• Historian William Seale notes that keeping children in place for school is “more typical than not” and cites precedents: Frances Cleveland spent little time in the White House; John Tyler’s children and Dolley Madison’s son stayed away initially; other presidents’ children (e.g., Chelsea Clinton, Malia and Sasha Obama) did move in immediately.  
• First-lady duties are officially ceremonial but have often expanded; active public models include Lou Hoover, Eleanor Roosevelt and Michelle Obama, while Nancy Reagan was initially reluctant.  
• Melania has stressed that Barron is her priority and has hinted only at a cyber-bullying initiative, suggesting she may not adopt a full-time public role; Ivanka Trump could potentially assume some hostess responsibilities, a role previously filled by relatives such as Martha Jefferson Randolph and Angelica van Buren.  
• White House families tailor life to their children—e.g., Chelsea Clinton’s homework in the Oval Office and the Obamas’ nightly 6:30 family dinners—showing that a “normal” domestic routine can be preserved even in the presidential residence.

A 72-year-old man was found dead at a sheltered housing complex in Inverness on 27 October. The Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service has asked Police Investigations and Review Commissioner Kate Frame to examine Police Scotland’s initial response to the man’s call. Police Scotland says it is fully cooperating, and PIRC will submit its findings to COPFS in due course.

Forecasters have issued a yellow wind warning, predicting easterly gusts of up to 75 mph (120 km/h), with heightened impact west of the mountains. Travel disruption on roads and at sea is likely across Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion and Powys. Overnight winds already toppled a tree in Menai Bridge, Anglesey, forcing the closure of Telford Road for most of Monday while cleanup continues.

Belfast Giants edged Nottingham Panthers 4–3.  
• Giants’ scorers: Derrick Walser (short-handed), Mike Forney (power-play), Mike Radja, James Desmarais.  
• Panthers’ scorers: Jeff Dimmen, Andy Bohmback, David Ling.  
The sides meet again Saturday in the second game of their double-header.  
League standings: Nottingham 28 points, Sheffield 27, Belfast 25.

Chinese Grand Prix – key points

1. Result
   • 1st Nico Rosberg (Mercedes) – his third win in three races, giving him a 36-point championship lead.  
   • 2nd Sebastian Vettel (Ferrari).  
   • 3rd Daniil Kvyat (Red Bull) ahead of team-mate Daniel Ricciardo (4th).  
   • 5th Kimi Raikkonen (Ferrari).  
   • Felipe Massa finished ahead of Lewis Hamilton; exact positions are not given, but Hamilton trailed Massa.

2. Lewis Hamilton
   • Started from the back, broke his front wing in a first-corner collision and made five pit-stops (three in the first six laps).  
   • Car sustained floor and barge-board damage, leaving him unable to climb higher than Massa.  
   • Now 36 points behind Rosberg with 18 races remaining.

3. First-lap incidents
   • Vettel and Raikkonen collided when the Finn moved across his team-mate while avoiding Kvyat’s inside lunge; both Ferraris needed new front wings.  
   • Hamilton was turned into by Felipe Nasr while swerving around Raikkonen’s damaged car.  
   • Safety car deployed on lap 4.

4. Vettel-Kvyat confrontation
   • In the pre-podium room Vettel accused Kvyat of a “torpedo” move; Kvyat said taking such risks put him on the podium.

5. Race dynamics
   • Ricciardo led off the line but suffered a left-rear puncture on lap 3 (contact/debris) and fell behind.  
   • Mercedes kept Rosberg out during the safety-car period; once racing resumed he pulled clear unchallenged.  
   • Ferrari’s choice of soft tyres late on let Raikkonen pass Hamilton, whose Mercedes was on mediums.

6. Historical note
   • No driver who has won the first three races of a season, as Rosberg has, has ever failed to take that year’s world title.

Former Germany international Thomas Hitzlsperger told Die Zeit he is gay, saying he wants to spark debate on a subject “simply ignored” in German football. He is the first high-profile player with Bundesliga and Premier League experience to come out. The move drew wide support:

• Players: Lukas Podolski, Arne Friedrich, Gary Lineker and Joey Barton hailed his courage.  
• Officials: Ex-DFB president Theo Zwanziger and Bundesliga president Reinhard Rauball called it a landmark against homophobia.  
• Others: Bayern Munich, John Amaechi, Chancellor Angela Merkel’s spokesman Steffen Seibert and politician Volker Beck offered praise.

The announcement is viewed as a watershed in a sport long marked by homophobia: captain Philipp Lahm had advised secrecy in 2011, and only lower-league player Marcus Urban had previously come out (2007). Zwanziger expressed hope that sexuality will soon be a non-issue in German football.

Steve Sidwell, 34, has played 32 Championship games this season, helping Brighton & Hove Albion win promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years. With his one-year contract expiring this summer, the midfielder—who previously had a 19-match loan spell at Brighton in 2015-16 and has top-flight experience with Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham and Stoke—wants a new deal, saying his performances merit it. Brighton’s victory over Wigan sealed promotion; they lead Newcastle by four points and aim to secure the Championship title in their remaining two fixtures.

Blackpool 1-1 Colchester United (Press Association report)

• 12’: Nathan Delfouneso beat his marker and crossed for Jamille Matt to score from close range, giving Blackpool the lead.  
• 17’: Sam Slocombe made a fine save from Matthew Briggs, but Colchester equalised from the ensuing corner when Kurtis Guthrie forced the ball in after a scramble.  
• First-half stoppage time: Slocombe denied George Elokobi at point-blank range, and Guthrie then headed against the bar.  
• 75’: Blackpool nearly won it but Tom Aldred headed wide when unmarked from a corner.  
• Injury time: Colchester substitute Sean Murray was sent off for a reckless tackle on Jim McAlister, leaving the visitors with ten men.  

Final score: Blackpool 1, Colchester United 1.

Reid, 29, made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues during their relegation-hit League One campaign last season. Having previously played for Charlton, Bradford and Preston, he could debut for Colchester United (the U’s) in Wednesday’s EFL Cup first-round match against Championship side Aston Villa. Colchester opened their season with a 3-1 defeat at Accrington on Saturday.

• PC Keith Palmer’s murder outside Parliament in March has heightened the push for a permanent UK police memorial.  
• The memorial will stand at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire, honouring more than 1,400 officers and staff killed on duty over the past 250 years.  
• Design features include a brass screen; leaf-shaped cut-outs bearing individual names will be given to relatives as personal keepsakes.  
• Total cost: £4 million. Funding so far: £1 million pledged by the government and a £1.5 million public appeal launched by the UK Police Memorial Trust, chaired by Sir Hugh Orde.  
• The project aims to be completed by 2019, providing a national place of remembrance for fallen police personnel.

Manchester United’s 1-0 victory at Sunderland keeps them 15 points clear at the Premier League summit with eight games to play. Sir Alex Ferguson notes:  

• United have won 25 of their first 30 league matches, taking 50 of the last 54 available points, and can still surpass Chelsea’s 95-point record from 2005.  
• Their next league fixture is the Manchester derby, which they will enter with a 15-point cushion over City.  
• Ferguson plans to rotate for Monday’s FA Cup replay at Chelsea after injuries to Rafael, Anderson and goalkeeper David De Gea, and with Wayne Rooney fatigued from England duty. Ryan Giggs, Javier Hernández and Rio Ferdinand are among those likely to return.  
• He praised the team’s first-half display and “determined defending” under second-half pressure from Sunderland.

• Google chairman Eric Schmidt told the BBC the firm has paid what UK law requires—about £10 million in corporation tax from 2006-2011—and will simply follow whatever rules the government sets.  
• He argues that taxes should be assessed where a company carries out its economic activity and bears risk, and he urges politicians, not companies, to reform the system if they want higher payments.  
• Google routes most UK sales through Ireland, a practice that has drawn criticism for reducing its UK tax bill.  
• Margaret Hodge, chair of Parliament’s Public Accounts Committee, proposes a new committee able to examine big firms’ tax affairs in secret to improve oversight.  
• EU leaders have agreed on automatic information exchange between tax authorities to curb multinational tax avoidance.

NHS Improvement wants the NHS to cut last year’s £3.6 bn agency staff bill by £1 bn this financial year.  
• An October pay cap—no more than 55% above standard shift rates, with only senior managers exempt—has saved about £600 m so far.  
• Trusts remain roughly 10% short of their savings goal, and total pay-bill effects (bank staff and overtime) are still unclear.  
• Later this year the regulator will publish league tables and the 20 top-earning agency staff per trust after finding quotes far above the cap (e.g., £130/hr for a surgeon vs £76 cap; £70/hr for a junior doctor vs £35 cap).  
Chief executive Jim Mackey warns the NHS cannot keep paying “hugely expensive” agency rates.

• Longford Town Centre, once planned as a major retail hub, now symbolizes Ireland’s post-boom crash.  
• Local retailer Matt O’Brien reports sales about 30 % below boom levels but says trade has begun to pick up after diversifying into childrenswear and dress hire.  
• Opposition party Fianna Fáil claims the Fine Gael–Labour government is neglecting the midlands: money for water-meter installation should fund broadband, and the IDA has brought no potential investors to Longford in over four years.  
• The government counters with the planned €200 m Center Parcs holiday resort in Ballymahon, expected—if it secures planning permission—to open in 2019 and create about 1,000 jobs; local TD James Bannon highlights the region’s natural attractions.  
• Traders still seek additional help, such as scrapping street-parking charges, and believe that while recovery signs are emerging, further action is required to revive the local economy.

• Tournament format & dates  
  – Eight teams play each other twice; the top four go into the play-offs.  
  – League games run 25 April-22 May, followed by Qualifier 1 (24 May), Eliminator (25 May), Qualifier 2 (27 May) and the Final on 29 May in the same stadium.

• Current statistical leaders  
  – Runs: David Warner 294, Virat Kohli 267, AB de Villiers 249.  
  – Sixes: Warner 12, de Villiers 12, Kohli 8.  
  – Highest individual scores: Quinton de Kock 108, Warner 90*, Gautam Gambhir 90*.  
  – Wickets: Mitchell McClenaghan 9, Bhuvneshwar Kumar 8, Mustafizur Rahman 7.

• England involvement  
  – Eoin Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad)  
  – Jos Buttler (Mumbai Indians)  
  – Sam Billings (Delhi Daredevils)  
  – Kevin Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants)

• Fixtures  
  – Daily matches are scheduled from 25 April through 22 May, with two-match days on weekends; all start at 15:30 BST unless listed otherwise (10:30 BST for early games).  
  – Full scorecards, fixtures and results are available via BBC Sport.

DEFRA reports that use of plastic carrier bags in England has risen by about 200 million since 2013. Because most are not recycled, they are often discarded, accumulating in landfills and waterways and harming the environment. Starting in October, shops in England will charge 5 pence per plastic bag to promote reuse—a policy already in place in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland, where it has cut bag consumption. Campaigners expect the English charge to achieve similar environmental benefits.

Strong winds on Friday triggered a yellow “be aware” warning across Wales:

• Damage: Part of a school roof at Rhosgadfan, near Caernarfon, was torn off.  
• Power: Hundreds of homes lost electricity.  
• Transport:  
  – Train services faced speed limits and delays, especially Llandudno Junction–Holyhead (Arriva Trains Wales).  
  – Irish Ferries cancelled six fast crossings between Holyhead and Dublin, moving passengers to slower cruise ferries.  
  – Speed/lane restrictions were imposed on the A55 Britannia Bridge and the M48 Severn Bridge (later lifted).  
• Closures: The National Trust shut Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle.  
• Weather data: Friday’s highest gusts were recorded at Mona on Anglesey; winds eased by evening.  
• Events: Rhyl’s Boxing Day Dip is postponed to 27 December.  
• Context: The disruption coincided with one of the busiest Christmas-getaway travel days.

Michael B. Jordan says he is “super excited” to join Ryan Coogler’s film Black Panther, re-teaming with his Creed director and set for release in February 2018. He looks forward to working with Lupita Nyong’o—Oscar-winner for 12 Years a Slave and the voice of Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens—and with Chadwick Boseman, now portraying Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War. Jordan, who played the Human Torch in last year’s Fantastic Four reboot, would not reveal his exact role but promised “a different spin” on it.

Alexandra Palace’s disused 1875 theatre and the adjoining BBC studios are to be restored as part of a £26.6 million east-wing project that will create a new cultural hub. Financial backing includes £18.8 million from the Heritage Lottery Fund, £6.8 million from Haringey Council and a final £1 million to be raised by the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust by summer 2017. Plans call for the theatre—still containing much of its original décor and machinery—to reopen in 2018 for drama, cinema, comedy and live music, while the glazed east court becomes a public and exhibition space.

James Milner, 30, formerly of Manchester City, earned 61 England caps after debuting in 2009. He was selected for two World Cups and two European Championships, though he featured for only three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner is England’s most-capped Under-21 player with 46 appearances since 2004, and his sole senior international goal came in the 5-0 World Cup-qualifying win over Moldova in 2014.

Marcy Smith’s home in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, was destroyed when rubbish she had burned in the wood stove ignited a fast-moving fire. Her son David, the only one awake while FaceTiming his father, spotted the flames, woke his mother and sister, and got them outside; their pets died but all three people survived. The smoke alarm never sounded, and the family escaped wearing only pyjamas. Neighbours have since provided clothing, shoes and even a bicycle, while Smith continues to praise David for saving their lives.

Reports say an energy-drink company is weighing a £200 million bid for West Ham United. The club has been owned mainly by David Sullivan and David Gold since 2010, when their purchase valued it at £105 million; together they now hold over 85 percent. Since the move to London Stadium in August, the club has attracted interest from Qatari and Chinese investors as well. Sullivan has said a minority stake could be sold to reduce debts, but he and Gold intend to pass overall control to their children.

At a fan-voted film awards ceremony in Los Angeles—emphatically “not the Oscars,” as Jillian Bell joked—The Fault in Our Stars dominated, taking best movie while Shailene Woodley claimed best female performance, the Trailblazer Award and best kiss with Ansel Elgort, dedicating her wins to author John Green. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for American Sniper, honoring Chris Kyle. Other major prizes went to Zac Efron (best shirtless performance), Channing Tatum (best comedic performance, 22 Jump Street) and Meryl Streep (best villain, Into the Woods), with additional trophies for Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen and Rose Byrne. Kevin Hart accepted the comedic genius award with his children, and Robert Downey Jr received the Generation Award from his Avengers co-stars. Previews teased upcoming releases including Pitch Perfect 2, Trainwreck and Avengers: Ultron.

• Cammy Smith, 21, was loaned by Aberdeen (“the Dons”) to Dundee United in July and has scored five goals for United this season.  
• Since debuting for Aberdeen in 2012, the Scotland U-21 forward has netted four times in 89 games.  
• St Mirren manager Jack Ross calls Smith “a brilliant acquisition,” praising his maturity and attacking ability and noting he hadn’t expected to be able to sign him while he was at Dundee United.  
• Bottom-of-the-table Championship side St Mirren host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council says warmer weather lets its Jetpatcher machines start work. The council aims to fill about 145 potholes a day for the next four months, and additional crews will repair rain-damaged drainage and clear gutter debris.

• December 2016, EnQuest’s Thistle oil platform (125 mi NE of Shetland): six Wood Group contractors, including rigging supervisor Steve Innes, were exposed to alpha-radiation (NORM) while removing pipework during a shutdown.  

• Exposure was “less than 1 %” of the level that must be formally reported to the Health & Safety Executive (HSE); EnQuest nonetheless informed HSE. Incident was not RIDDOR-reportable and HSE opened no investigation.  

• Workers say they had no proper PPE, learned of the hazard late, and now fear cancer; Innes reports ongoing blood tests and difficulty finding further work. He accuses EnQuest of breaching its duty of care.  

• EnQuest says normal controls were in place, has added “additional precautionary steps,” and stresses the exposure was low-level.  

• Wood Group temporarily removed its staff for medical checks, joined EnQuest’s investigation, and reiterates its safety commitment.  

• Unite union calls the workers’ treatment “terrible” and urges transparency; HSE confirms awareness but no probe.

• In 2007 Singapore’s Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) paid US $650,000 (£420,000) to New York gallery Art of the Past for a bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari.  
• The gallery’s manager, Aaron Freedman, later confessed to trafficking and possessing stolen Indian antiquities; allegations surfaced in a 2012 court case.  
• The bronze is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, though conclusive proof is lacking.  
• After the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) formally requested its return in May, ACM and Singapore’s National Heritage Board agreed to repatriate the sculpture.  
• ACM had bought 30 objects from Art of the Past; none of the others are currently considered stolen, but ASI was allowed to inspect them.  
• ACM plans to pursue legal action to recover compensation for being defrauded.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck at 15:48 local time, 15.5 km deep, with its epicentre in Garfagnana about 35 km north of Lucca. Shaking was felt from Lucca to Milan, Florence, Bologna and Modena. No injuries or major damage were immediately reported, though phone and power outages occurred in the Garfagnana area; schools were evacuated as a precaution. Several weaker aftershocks followed. Italy, a quake-prone country, recently suffered deadly events: a magnitude-6 sequence in the same region last May killed more than 20, and the 2009 L’Aquila quake killed almost 300, after which six scientists and a former official were convicted for giving overly reassuring risk statements. Geophysicist Alessandro Amato called the latest tremor “medium-strong,” “fairly shallow,” and unexpected.

On 8 September 2016, 62-year-old Sheffield grandfather Austin Grant, who had questioned whether South Yorkshire’s climate was suitable, finally saw fruit growing on his plant—still attached and not yet ripe—and said he was “literally jumping for joy.”

Rockstar has postponed Grand Theft Auto V for PC from 27 January to 24 March, saying the extra weeks are needed “for testing and polish.” Online heists will reach consoles before the new PC launch. Released screenshots highlight higher detail, 1080p at 60 fps, up to 4K resolution and triple-monitor support; minimum PC specs are now available. GTA V originally set records on 17 September 2013, earning $1 billion in three days.

• 76-year-old artist Michael Simpson has won the £25,000 biennial John Moores Painting Prize at Liverpool’s Walker Art Gallery for his 7-ft-high work Squint (19).  
• Simpson had been shortlisted once (1991) and long-listed three other times; he called finally winning “very nice indeed.”  
• Squint (19) portrays a medieval “leper squint” (a hole in church walls that let outcasts watch services). It is part of a larger series, and its comparatively modest size influenced Simpson’s choice to enter it.  
• Judge Ansel Krut praised the painting as “quite extraordinary,” technically subtle and emotionally resonant.  
• Simpson plans to spend the prize money on canvases, stretchers and high-quality paints.  
• Founded in 1957, the John Moores Painting Prize is one of Britain’s oldest art awards; past winners include David Hockney and Peter Doig, and its current patron Sir Peter Blake won the junior prize in 1961.

Early Thursday, masked gunmen carried out near-simultaneous attacks on the Istanbul offices of two pro-government newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, which stand about 20 km apart. At Yeni Safak, four masked assailants opened fire and started a fire that firefighters quickly put out; windows in both buildings were shattered and numerous spent bullet casings were recovered. No casualties were reported. Police have sealed off both sites and are hunting the attackers, but no group has claimed responsibility. The two papers back President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s AK Party; their attacks follow last September’s assault on the daily Hurriyet.

A 24-year-old former Burton player, still contracted to the Stags but recently on loan at Crawley (3 goals in 23 games), will move to Marcus Bignot’s Mariners on a free transfer, officially joining on 1 January as Bignot’s first signing.

Arsène Wenger, under contract at Arsenal until the summer, brushed aside talk of taking the England job, praising interim manager Gareth Southgate—who has overseen a 2-0 win over Malta, a 0-0 draw with Slovenia, and now faces Scotland (11 Nov) and Spain (15 Nov) to earn the post permanently. Wenger said competence matters more than “big names” and that Southgate has the chance to prove himself.

Turning to Arsenal issues, Wenger confirmed:
• Right-back Héctor Bellerín, linked with Barcelona and Manchester City, will be offered an improved deal despite having almost three years left on his current contract; Wenger sees his long-term future at Arsenal.  
• Midfielder Aaron Ramsey’s hamstring injury will keep him out for another one or two matches.

A man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT Thursday. Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are jointly investigating, and the company is fully cooperating.

A charter change will move the freight vessels Hellier and Hildasay from sub-contractor Seatruck back to main operator Serco Northlink early next month, ending a dispute over pay for Northern Isles seafarers. The RMT union said some crew had earned under £4 an hour; Seatruck claimed the UK minimum wage did not apply to its mainly non-UK staff, and rejected Serco Northlink’s offer to make up the shortfall. Transport Minister Humza Yousaf said the new arrangement will guarantee every crew member at least the minimum wage once financial and regulatory details are finalised. Serco Northlink, holder of a six-year £243 million Scottish-government-subsidised contract awarded in 2012, runs three ferries and two cargo ships on the route.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May, six days after a confrontation at Poole’s Rockley Park holiday site. On 7 May, Jamie Mitchell, 35, intervened in an argument between Dickie and Mitchell’s mother, Samantha, 57, after all three had been drinking in the park bar. Mitchell and Dickie fought outside but were separated by bystanders. Mitchell later pleaded guilty to common assault, and he and his mother admitted trying to pervert the course of justice by initially lying to police about what happened. A jury at Winchester Crown Court delivered its verdict, prompting Mitchell to shout “yes” and shake visibly. Both defendants will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, the reclusive British songwriter dubbed “The Invisible Man,” has died in London aged 66 after a short, aggressive battle with cancer; a private funeral has been held. Born in Cleethorpes, he moved from a frozen-food factory job to keyboardist for disco group Heatwave, penning their 1970s hits Boogie Nights, Always & Forever and Groove Line. Producer Quincy Jones then recruited him for Michael Jackson’s solo work: Temperton wrote Off the Wall, Rock With You and Burn This Disco Out for the album Off the Wall, and Thriller, Baby Be Mine and The Lady in My Life for the follow-up Thriller, which went on to sell 32 million copies in the US. His songs were also recorded by Anita Baker, Donna Summer, Aretha Franklin, The Brothers Johnson and others. Temperton won a 1990 Grammy (Birdland on Jones’s Back on the Block) and earned two 1986 Oscar nominations for The Color Purple. Tributes came from Nile Rodgers, LaToya Jackson, Mark Ronson, Chaka Khan and broadcaster Gilles Peterson.

• An international team including Swansea University’s Dr Neil Loader and Prof Alayne Street-Perrott has identified more than 450 large, geometric earthworks (geoglyphs) in Acre state, western Brazilian Amazon, dating to about 2,000 years ago.  
• The ditched enclosures had been hidden under bamboo rainforest until modern deforestation exposed them.  
• Excavations yield few artefacts, their layouts are not defensive, and researchers believe they served as occasional ritual gathering places rather than villages.  
• Soil, phytolith, charcoal and carbon-isotope studies show the geoglyphs were built amid tall forest, so they were not visible above the canopy.  
• Evidence of diverse, economically valuable plant species accumulated over 6,000 years indicates sustained human agroforestry—selecting and managing useful trees (e.g., palms) instead of large-scale forest burning.  
• This prehistoric “supermarket” management may still shape the biodiversity of Acre’s modern forests.

Nick Kyrgios, 21, defeated world No 29 Sam Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to reach the Shanghai Masters second round. Ranked a career-high No 12 after winning the Japan Open on Sunday, he is closing on the top 10. Kyrgios said he felt tired and “a bit bored” after late travel, poor sleep and the long trip to Shanghai’s Qi Zhong Stadium. At the same event last year he was fined $1,500 for calling the tournament a “circus.”

Scientists, doctors and cancer charities say the human-papilloma-virus (HPV) vaccine should be offered to Welsh boys as well as girls to curb rising HPV-linked head-and-neck cancers.  
Key points:  
• HPV is sexually transmitted; since 2008 Welsh girls aged 12-13 have been routinely vaccinated to prevent cervical cancer, with 85 % uptake.  
• Cases of HPV-related head and neck cancer are increasing; three-quarters are in men, average age 55, most of whom are non-smokers.  
• Groups including Tenovus Cancer Care, BMA Cymru and Cardiff University’s HPV team will deliver a letter urging the Welsh government to “vaccinate boys now.”  
• The Welsh government says it will wait for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before altering the programme.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old pupil at West Calder High School, died from the rare blood cancer gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. Since his diagnosis in August, he chronicled his illness on the Facebook page “Jak’s Journey,” run with help from family and girlfriend, gaining over 28,000 followers. Despite declining health, Jak briefly attended a school prom held for him on Saturday, where he was greeted by ex-Rangers captain Barry Ferguson; his family collected his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy for overcoming adversity. Earlier medical news on 23 January confirmed the cancer had spread and treatment was stopped. Jak’s posts, visits from sports stars and the public’s response inspired fundraising for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research, including a charity football match at Livingston FC’s Energy Assets Arena. His mother Allison announced his death on his Facebook page, calling him “simply the best.”

Africa Cup of Nations, Group D – Port-Gentil

• Egypt beat Uganda 1-0; substitute Abdallah El Said scored in the 89th minute from Mohamed Salah’s pass.  
• Uganda’s Joseph Ochaya had a 52-minute effort ruled out for offside; Uganda finished without a shot on target.  
• The match was largely uneventful on a deteriorating pitch, with Egypt struggling to break a disciplined Ugandan defence until the late winner.  
• Standings impact:  
  – Ghana (earlier 1-0 winners over Mali) are already in the quarter-finals.  
  – Egypt face Ghana on Wednesday with first place in the group at stake.  
  – Uganda, at their first finals since 1978, are eliminated.  
  – Mali can still qualify only if they beat Uganda and Ghana defeat Egypt by two goals or more.

Lancashire County Council, working with Mersey­travel and West Lancashire Borough Council, plans to re-establish a railway station in Skelmersdale. After Network Rail compared possible sites, the council chose land covering the disused Glenburn Sports College (which it owns) and the unused Westbank campus of Skelmersdale College. The site offers good road links, room for future expansion, and could support two direct trains per hour to Liverpool. The council will now move to acquire the land. Skelmersdale’s original station closed in 1956, leaving the new-town (designated in 1961) as one of the largest in north-west England without a station.
Police searching a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning discovered plants in an “elaborate grow house” and arrested a man in his late 40s at the scene.

In Hamelin, Lower Saxony, a 28-year-old Kurdish-German woman was found late Sunday with severe injuries after being dragged by the neck through several streets. She underwent emergency surgery and was airlifted to a specialist clinic. Her 38-year-old ex-partner, also a Kurdish-German from nearby Bad Muender, later surrendered to police and is in custody. The motive remains unknown, and authorities have sealed the area and appealed for witnesses.

A study using data on 4,600 Australian employees (2013-14 workplace relations survey) compared full-time men with full-time women and part-timers with part-timers, while controlling for employer size, industry, parenthood and qualifications. It found:  

• Women ask for pay rises as often as men.  
• When they do, men are about 25 % more likely than women to receive one.  
• There is no evidence that women avoid asking because of fear of upsetting managers or violating gender stereotypes; thus the popular “reticent female” explanation is unsupported.  
• The results point to an element of discrimination against women.  
• Age matters: among workers under 40, women and men request and obtain raises at the same rate, suggesting newer cohorts may be narrowing the gap.

Oxford City Council has spent funds investigating new burial sites but has found none that meet requirements for size, ground conditions, water-table levels, or legal covenants. The two existing cemeteries with space—Wolvercote and Botley—are expected to reach capacity in 2018 and 2021 respectively. Once full, only reopened family plots, a few reserved plots, and ash interments will be possible. The city last added burial space in 1932, and the council is still looking for solutions but says suitable land within Oxford has effectively run out.

Visitors to this year’s Hebridean Celtic Festival in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis (19–22 July) can use a new app with augmented-reality features that activate when pointed at festival signs or posters, delivering videos, band interviews and other material to phones and tablets. Acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries and Dougie MacLean. Director Caroline Maclennan says the constantly updated service will enhance on-site enjoyment and let people worldwide access information, interviews and ticket sales while sampling the festival’s atmosphere.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred gelding, collapsed and died moments after narrowly defeating Thistlecrack in the Cotswold Chase on Cheltenham’s Festival Trials Day. Despite immediate veterinary attention, he was pronounced dead; the British Horseracing Authority said the cause was a “severe pulmonary haemorrhage,” a rare condition that can strike fit sport horses without prior warning. Although the horse had previously shown post-race overheating and wobbling (ataxia), he had never collapsed and displayed none of those symptoms on Saturday. Many Clouds, owned by Trevor Hemmings and ridden by Leighton Aspell, had earlier won the 2015 Gold Cup trial and the 2014 Hennessy Gold Cup, earning trainer Oliver Sherwood’s praise as the “horse of a lifetime.” The BHA’s acting chief veterinary officer, Tony Welsh, stressed the rarity of such fatalities but said the sport is striving to understand and prevent them. BBC correspondent Cornelius Lysaght noted that, despite past overheating episodes, the report found no significant underlying health issues and attributed the death to the uncommon haemorrhage.

In autumn 2004 a 15-year-old girl was raped in a Portsmouth garage by David Ayrton. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties, later changed name to Davina in 2012 but has made no physical transition. Now aged 34, she denied the charge but was found guilty. Judge Ian Pearson remanded her to custody—probably a male prison in Winchester—citing risks of self-harm and non-attendance; sentencing is set for 4 March. Ayrton previously attempted suicide and protocols have been arranged for her detention. The victim, who had drunk little alcohol, shouted for Ayrton to stop but friends sleeping nearby did not wake. Ayrton first disclosed the assault to a care-home worker in 2014.

Serbia’s doubles team were beaten 6-4 6-4 in Rio by Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares. The defeat followed Novak Djokovic’s singles exit to Juan Martin del Potro the previous day. Earlier in the season the 29-year-old world No 1 had endured a surprise Wimbledon third-round loss to Sam Querrey, but rebounded to secure his 30th Masters title in Toronto ahead of the Olympics.

More than 20 chainsaw carvers will compete this Saturday in Carrbridge in the Cairngorms. Entrants come from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada and the US. Using only chainsaws, they will turn logs into animal and human figures. Reigning champion Pete Bowsher of Moffat returns to defend both his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Wales scrum-half Rhys Webb, 27, has been sidelined since a serious foot injury in September’s World Cup warm-up against Italy. He is now running again, working through a “pre-season” phase, and hopes to be match-ready by early February—possibly slightly ahead of schedule—when Wales open their Six Nations in Dublin on 7 February. Capped 16 times, Webb has just renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, rejecting outside offers to stay with his home region and keep himself in contention for Wales selection.

U.S. border agents confronted two backpack-carrying men about five miles east of Sumas, Washington, on Tuesday morning, disrupting an alleged scheme to move MDMA from Canada to San Francisco. One man, Jeffrey Laviolette, was arrested on the spot; the other, Canadian citizen Nathan Hall, fired at agents, fled, and was captured in British Columbia early Wednesday. Their packs held about 58 lb (26 kg) of ecstasy and a fake California driver’s licence bearing Hall’s photo. Investigators later detained Bellingham resident Kali Henifin, who was to collect the smugglers, and her boyfriend Ryan Lambert, who said he expected $11,000 to drive the drugs south. The three U.S. detainees face conspiracy and drug-trafficking charges. The wooded border stretch, a frequent route for illicit shipments, was sealed off by Canadian and U.S. police during the manhunt.
