• Childline counselled over 4,500 children about online bullying in the past year, up from about 2,400 in 2011-12; the true number affected is believed to be much higher.  
• Victims include children as young as seven who describe torment, abuse and fear of school.  
• Childline says online trolls cause “misery and humiliation” for thousands; president Dame Esther Rantzen calls the figures a “wake-up call” and stresses that cyber-bullying follows children home, worsens if unchecked, and requires action from parents, teachers and schools.  
• The findings are released for Anti-Bullying Week, organised by the Anti-Bullying Alliance, which is working with parents, schools and other groups to address the issue.  
• A child’s testimony highlights the emotional impact of being told to “kill yourself” during online gaming and feeling unsupported by parents.

• After a request from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s office, Jerusalem’s municipal planning committee postponed a vote to approve 492 new housing units in the East-Jerusalem settlements of Ramat Shlomo and Ramot.

• The delay seeks to avoid further tension with Washington just hours before U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry delivers a speech outlining his vision for resolving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and rebutting Israeli criticism of the Obama administration.

• The diplomatic strain follows the U.S. decision on Friday to abstain—rather than veto—a U.N. Security Council resolution declaring all Israeli settlement building in the occupied West Bank and East Jerusalem illegal and a “flagrant violation” of international law.

• Netanyahu rejected the resolution, accused the White House (an accusation the U.S. denies) of helping draft it, and retaliated by summoning U.S. and other supporting ambassadors, recalling Israel’s envoys to New Zealand and Senegal, cutting aid to Senegal, and cancelling a visit by Ukraine’s prime minister.

• About 500,000 Israeli settlers live in roughly 140 communities established in the territories Israel captured in 1967; Palestinians seek East Jerusalem as the capital of a future state.

• Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas says the U.N. vote “paves the way” for a 15 January Paris peace conference aimed at setting a timetable to end the occupation.

• On the eve of Queen Elizabeth II’s 90th birthday (21 April), Prince William told the BBC she has been a “guiding example” of monarchy and duty; he also answered recent “work-shy” criticism, saying he takes his responsibilities seriously but is easing into full‐time royal work with the Queen’s and Prince Charles’s support.  

• Birthday events began with the Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh visiting Windsor’s Royal Mail delivery office (marking 500 years of the postal service), then opening a new bandstand in Alexandra Gardens where schoolchildren sang Happy Birthday.  

• Royal Mail issued ten commemorative stamps, including a four-generation portrait of the Queen, Prince Charles, Prince William and Prince George; other stamps depict her family life and official role.  

• On her birthday the Queen will tour Windsor, unveil the 6.3 km “Queen’s Walkway” celebrating her record reign, and light the first of 900 beacons worldwide; on Friday the Obamas will join her for lunch at Windsor Castle.  

• Prime Minister David Cameron called the day an “important landmark” during PMQs, while republican group Republic criticised the BBC for what it saw as overly celebratory coverage.  

• The Queen—Britain’s longest-reigning monarch—marks two birthdays each year: her actual birthday on 21 April and an official one in June.

West Ham United, making seven changes after recent league defeats, beat League Two side Cheltenham Town 2-0 in the EFL Cup. Diafra Sakho converted Sam Byram’s pass and, moments later, André Ayew struck into the same corner to give the Premier League club a two-goal half-time lead. Cheltenham’s best openings—a Harry Pell volley, a Jordon Forster header and a Pell cross just beyond Dan Holman—did not beat keeper Adrián, while Kyle Storer cleared an Angelo Ogbonna header off the line to prevent a wider margin. The result repeats West Ham’s victory when the teams met at this stage four years ago and ends League Two participation before the third-round draw.

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, 36, was killed when motorist Andreas Werner, 46, turned his VW Transporter across his path on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion. Werner, from Leipzig and holidaying near Bala, admitted causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates' Court, was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. McNicholl’s family opposed a jail sentence, accepting the crash resulted from a momentary lapse; Werner expressed remorse.

Imran Khawaja, 27, from Southall, west London, left the UK in January 2014, joined the Islamic State-linked Rayat al Tawheed group in Syria and called himself Abu Daigham al-Britani. Online he became one of the most visible British fighters, fronting slick propaganda that mixed donation appeals, video diaries and violent images—including a photo of him holding a bag with a severed head.  

Watched by MI5, Khawaja decided to return last June. He asked cousin Tahir Bhatti for help, faked an online obituary to suggest he had died in battle, and was collected in Bulgaria. The pair were arrested at Dover.  

Khawaja has admitted four terrorism-related offences and faces up to life in prison; Bhatti has pleaded guilty to assisting an offender. Deemed “a dangerous man,” Khawaja was held in Belmarsh’s high-risk unit while awaiting sentence. An additional charge of soliciting murder will remain on file.

Kayden Jackson, 22, has left Wrexham—where he scored 4 goals in 36 games as they finished eighth—to become Barnsley’s third signing for next season. He rejected a new Wrexham deal, and caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom praised his speed and direct play before Sunday’s League One play-off final at Wembley.

• Since Sunday, sealed bottles of “Vanish” detergent have been washing up at Poldhu Cove and nearby Cornish beaches (Gunwalloe, Polurrian, Church Cove, Marazion).  
• National Trust volunteers are collecting them because leaking detergent could harm wildlife; Cornwall Wildlife Trust is “highly concerned.”  
• Suspected source: a container that fell from the MV Blue Ocean during stormy seas near Land’s End in May, though the Maritime & Coastguard Agency says the link is only circumstantial.  
• Cornwall Council and partner agencies are monitoring the situation; the public is told to keep children and dogs away and not to retrieve the bottles.  
• Vanish’s manufacturer has not yet commented.

An incident happened around 14:00 on the A9 north of Berriedale, Caithness. Several people suffered minor injuries. The road was closed and traffic diverted via the A897 Helmsdale-to-Melvich route. Police Scotland’s investigation is ongoing.

French centre-back Dorian Dervite, 28, has signed a new contract with Bolton Wanderers. He joined from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances, including 14 last season when he helped the club finish second in League One and gain promotion to the Championship. Manager Phil Parkinson praised Dervite’s late-season impact. The defender’s deal follows new contracts for teammates David Wheater, Gary Madine and Jem Karacan.

After the Commons rejected Lords’ amendments on EU citizens’ rights and Parliament’s say over any Brexit deal, relations between the two opposition parties fractured.  

• Liberal Democrat peers insist on re-tabling the amendments; Labour peers will now defer to the Commons.  
• Lib Dem Lord Oates says Labour is willing to “concede everything”; Labour’s Baroness Smith counters that Lib Dems are giving people “false hope.”  
• A Labour Lords source calls the Lib Dem stance “grandstanding” for campaign leaflets; Lib Dem Europe spokesperson Baroness Ludford accuses Labour of “waving through” a hard-Brexit plan.  
• Though the parties have often combined to defeat the government on other bills, Labour predicts “residual tensions,” while the Lib Dems still expect to cooperate where they agree.

• Defence barely features in the 2015 UK election: opinion polls rank it below issues such as the economy, NHS and immigration, and the main parties devote only a page or two of their manifestos to it.

• The strategic context is worsening (Islamic extremism, migrant crises, an assertive Russia) while UK forces are shrinking: the regular Army is falling to 82,000, the Navy has 19 warships and no maritime-patrol aircraft, and the RAF is down to seven front-line fast-jet squadrons.

• Spending is sliding. The UK has dropped from fourth to sixth in world defence outlays and, without an extra £25 bn over five years, will dip below NATO’s 2 %-of-GDP benchmark to about 1.7 % (possibly 1.5 %). Only UKIP and the DUP promise to keep the 2 % pledge.

• Further cuts are likely whoever wins; defence is not a “protected” budget and could lose another £2–£3 bn annually. Yet Tory promises (no further Army cuts, annual 1 % equipment rise, full Trident replacement) restrict where savings can come from.

• Nuclear policy is split: Conservatives and UKIP want four new Trident submarines; Labour might cut to three; Lib Dems would end continuous patrols; SNP and Greens would scrap the deterrent entirely. Another delay or review is possible.

• Big-ticket programmes face strain: two new aircraft carriers may lack crews and F-35 jets (12 planned versus 36 capacity), risking a “hollow force”.

• Senior analysts warn credibility with the US and NATO will suffer if the UK drops below 2 % spending and continues cutting conventional capabilities while funding Trident.

Overall: Britain confronts a more dangerous world with diminishing military resources, contested nuclear plans and uncertain funding—calling into question its traditional ability to “punch above its weight.”

• Barcelona bought Neymar from Santos last summer, announcing a €57 m (£48.6 m) fee, of which £34 m went to the player’s parents.  
• When signing-on bonuses, wages, agents’ fees and a new tax payment are included, Neymar’s total cost to the club reaches about £106.8 m.  
• Amid a court probe that claims the true transfer cost was under-reported, former president Sandro Rosell resigned and is also under investigation, though he denies wrongdoing.  
• While insisting it committed no offence, Barcelona has made an additional tax declaration of €13.55 m to cover any “divergent interpretation” of its obligations.  
• A judge has ruled there is enough evidence to keep investigating; it is unclear if Barcelona’s payment will end the case.  
• On the pitch, Neymar has 7 goals in 18 La Liga games and 3 in 7 Champions League matches this season.

• Michael Luciw, 27, from Nottingham, died when the Ford Transit he was travelling in was hit head-on near Kegworth, Leicestershire, at 02:00 GMT on 12 October; a Mazda Premacy driven the wrong way by Albert Kenneth Newman also killed Newman and seriously injured van driver Andy Harrington.  
• Luciw’s family describe him as a generous, fun-loving new father and say his death “feels as if he has been taken away.”  
• The family and Harrington argue that retired motorists should face regular on-road driving and medical tests, claiming slower reactions in old age mean some should no longer drive; they say loss of a licence need not remove independence because over-60s receive free bus passes.  
• Current UK rules require drivers over 70 only to complete a self-assessment form every three years; there is no compulsory test.  
• The DVLA states it has no plans to introduce age-based restrictions, saying data do not show older drivers cause more serious crashes, and licences are revoked if medical standards are not met.  
• Age UK acknowledges the need for safety but stresses that driving is vital for many older people’s independence.

• Transvaginal mesh/tape implants have treated more than 20,000 Scottish women for incontinence and prolapse, but many report severe, long-term complications; over 400 are suing health boards and manufacturers.  

• An independent review recommended that mesh for pelvic organ prolapse should not be offered routinely; women must be given full information and alternative treatments; and reporting of adverse events must become mandatory.  

• Two patient members and a consultant quit the review, alleging key material was removed and the final report was “watered down.”  

• New review chair Tracey Gillies, who replaced Lesley Wilkie late in the process, apologised to MSPs for failing to secure consensus, calling the task “almost mission impossible.”  

• Health Secretary Shona Robison said the Scottish Government will keep implementing the review’s recommendations but cannot impose an outright ban, which is the UK regulator MHRA’s remit.  

• Prof Alison Britton will now audit how the original review reached its conclusions and identify lessons for future inquiries.

• At Glasgow’s Emirates Arena, 23-year-old Laura Muir ran 5,000 m indoors in 14 min 49.12 sec, beating Liz McColgan’s 25-year-old British record by 14 seconds.  
• McColgan, pleased a fellow Scot surpassed her mark, initially queried whether the largely solo race and drug-testing arrangements met UK Athletics criteria, but British Athletics expects the record to be ratified.  
• Rules allow a record without on-site doping control, and Muir was the only athlete to finish the full 5 km in a mixed 3 km race, lapping rivals.  
• McColgan believes Muir can lower her time toward 14 : 30 and win global medals, provided she refines race tactics.  
• Muir already holds the British 1,500 m record (3 : 55) and was a finalist over that distance at the Rio 2016 Olympics.

Jung claimed gold on Sam, who stepped in after Fischertakinou fell ill. France’s Astier Nicolas earned silver, and the USA’s Phillip Dutton took bronze. Britain’s William Fox-Pitt, returning less than a year after a serious fall and coma, finished 12th on Chilli Morning: despite a flawless final show-jumping round, earlier cross-country time faults dropped him from a leading dressage position. Ireland’s Jonty Evans placed ninth on Cooley Rorkes Drift.

Andy Murray, 30, beat Italy’s 29th-seed Fabio Fognini 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5 in 2 h 39 m, clinching match point at 20:57 BST. After falling 2-5 behind in the fourth set, Murray saved five set points and won five straight games to reach Wimbledon’s last 16 for the 11th time; he next faces France’s Benoit Paire on Monday. Fognini mixed strong play with temperamental flashes—incurring a point penalty for an obscene gesture and struggling with an ankle problem—while Murray, unhappy with his movement and the fading light, was relieved to avoid a deciding set and a roof delay. Fellow Briton Johanna Konta also advanced to week two, defeating Maria Sakkari 6-4 6-1.

Paramedics were called to a sudden death at Joe’s Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014. Police soon arrived and found customers still inside; till receipts showed alcohol sales as late as 04:49 BST. 

• The bar was ordered closed for three months.  
• License holder Colleen O’Neill, 43, was charged with two counts of allowing alcohol consumption outside licensing hours; James Thomas, 44, faced one count.  
• A defence solicitor admitted local licensing laws “were not strictly adhered to,” and the bar had been operating into the morning.  
• The judge called O’Neill’s record “appalling,” regretted he could not impose a custodial sentence, fined her £3,000, and fined Thomas £1,000.

• Launching the Ulster Unionist Party (UUP) manifesto, “Real Partnership”, Mike Nesbitt said “Domination doesn’t work, partnership does,” and framed the 2 March election as a referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive (RHI) scandal, which he says is costing £85,000 a day and reflects “incompetence, arrogance, cronyism and the strong whiff of corruption” after 10 years of DUP/Sinn Féin rule.  

• Nesbitt told voters to give their first preference to the UUP and then transfer to candidates they believe will “do the right thing”, adding he would rather share power with the SDLP than Sinn Féin; he refuses to retract the remark despite senior colleague Danny Kennedy publicly distancing himself.  

• Nesbitt claims door-step feedback in unionist areas shows support for his stance and is relaxed about individual UUP candidates adopting different transfer positions.  

• Key manifesto pledges: cut hospital waiting lists; raise PSNI staffing to 7,500; prioritise the York Street interchange; stand up for the LGBT community; and guarantee that no sector is worse off because of Brexit, alongside wider measures to “clean up Stormont.”  

• Nesbitt hopes these messages will outweigh the controversy over his SDLP transfer comments.

Northern Ireland’s Justice Minister Claire Sugden has secured executive backing to seek Assembly approval for a legislative consent motion that will pardon men convicted under now-abolished gay sexual-offence laws. Mirroring “Turing’s Law” announced in England and Wales, the measure will grant automatic posthumous pardons and allow living gay and bisexual men to apply for pardons, aiming to deliver equal treatment and redress historic injustices as quickly as possible.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, clocked 4:19.12 to finish second to Kenya’s Faith Kipyegon and break Yvonne Murray’s 1994 Scottish mile record of 4:22.60. The time lifts Muir to second on the UK all-time list, behind Zola Budd’s 4:17.57. Already the Scottish 1500 m record-holder and fifth at the 2015 World Championships, she now targets Olympic selection at the British trials in Birmingham on 24–26 June. Muir opened her season with an 800 m win in Montbéliard, races 1500 m in Stockholm next week, and continues to combine training with her veterinary studies, having just finished her fourth academic year.
The passage showcases readers’ photographs of 26 Scottish beaches that have earned the highest (“excellent”) rating for water quality.

• Barrister Richard Horwell QC told the inquiry that the two prime suspects, Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi, had no personal motive to kill Alexander Litvinenko and that the Russian state “is likely to have been the sponsor” of the plot.  
• Litvinenko, 43, was fatally poisoned with radioactive polonium-210 in London in 2006 after drinking tea during a meeting with the two men; he died almost three weeks later.  
• Use of polonium and the suspects’ “trail of polonium” point to Russian state involvement, though Horwell said this does not necessarily implicate President Vladimir Putin personally.  
• Possible motives include Litvinenko’s 2000 defection to the UK and his public accusations that the FSB murdered opponents and was corrupt, along with his “many personal attacks on Putin.”  
• Horwell stated Litvinenko was attacked twice with polonium, public health consequences are unknown, and the suspects have “no credible answer” to the scientific evidence.  
• Extradition efforts have failed; Kovtun and Lugovoi remain in Russia, making a UK murder trial unlikely. Kovtun was criticised for refusing to give evidence.  
• The inquiry was adjourned until Friday.

• Steve Smith, 26, is appointed Australia’s full-time Test captain after Michael Clarke, 34, announced his retirement following the Ashes defeat that put England 3-1 ahead.  
• Smith already captains the one-day side and will lead the Twenty20 team while Aaron Finch is injured.  
• David Warner, 28, is named vice-captain despite past disciplinary issues, with selectors praising his recent maturity.  
• Selector Rod Marsh says Smith is “the right man for the job,” noting his 2,952 Test runs at an average of 54.66 from 32 matches and previous stand-in role against India.  
• Smith and Warner will also head Australia in the limited-overs fixtures after the final Ashes Test at The Oval on 20 August.

Liberal Democrat leader Tim Farron, who recently defeated Norman Lamb, repeatedly declined to say whether he considers homosexual sex sinful but stressed he is “passionate about LGBT-plus rights.” He vows to prioritise defending and widening equal-marriage laws, including removing the “spousal veto” that restricts transgender spouses. Farron explained that his 2007 vote against the Equality Bill stemmed from concerns over “protection of individual liberties,” yet insists he fully supports legal equality for all, regardless of sexuality.

Sanofi shut its Fawdon drug-manufacturing site in 2015, cutting 450 jobs. Accord Healthcare will now take over the plant for pharmaceutical production and hopes to re-employ many former Sanofi staff. The company says the investment will have an “extremely positive” local impact, a view echoed by Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes, who welcomes the highly skilled jobs and long-term investment. Accord develops, manufactures and distributes more than 130 medicines to about 60 countries worldwide.

Three senior managers are leaving the council.  
• Richard Ellis, former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, finishes on Friday when his contract ends.  
• Ciaran Monaghan, head of the chief executive’s office, and Ewan Sutherland, head of human resources and customer services, are departing through a voluntary redundancy/early-retirement scheme.  

Opposition SNP leader Stephen Flynn says the exits show the council is struggling to retain senior staff and predicts more will follow. Chief executive Angela Scott thanked the three for their dedication and professionalism.

Four gunmen claiming allegiance to Islamic State stormed Kabul’s 400-bed Sardar Daud military hospital at about 09:00, after one detonated explosives at the gate. Dressed partly as medics, they opened fire on staff and patients, wounding more than 50 people before Afghan special-forces commandos landed on the roof and killed all four attackers in an operation that lasted more than six hours. IS said it carried out the assault; the Taliban denied any role. Afghan leaders, including President Ashraf Ghani and Abdullah Abdullah, denounced the strike on a site normally considered off-limits in war. Analysts note that this first direct IS firefight with security forces in the capital, using a Taliban-style breach, signals the group’s growing capability and intent to stage higher-profile attacks beyond its eastern strongholds.

The English rider says this season’s TT was “a bloody disaster”: he crashed, the Honda Fireblade has ongoing mechanical issues, and he ended up acting mainly as a test rider. After further tests at Cadwell, he told the team the bike would not be competitive for the Ulster Grand Prix; the team then withdrew him (without informing him). He had already skipped the North West 200 following team-mate John McGuinness’s practice crash. Clarifying an earlier remark about “quitting,” he states he is not giving up racing, but he will do no more road races on Hondas this year and instead plans to focus on classic and unusual events.

• In Nigeria’s 11 April state elections the opposition All Progressives Congress (APC) captured 19 of the 28 governorships declared, relegating the long-ruling Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) to just eight wins and shrinking it to a mainly south-eastern, Niger-Delta base; Taraba is still pending and Imo was declared inconclusive, while seven states did not vote.  
• The losses— including PDP strongholds Katsina, Kaduna and Adamawa— mark the party’s worst setback since civilian rule returned in 1999 and follow its defeat in last month’s presidential poll won by APC leader Muhammadu Buhari, who is due to take office on 29 May.  
• APC now holds most northern states and Lagos, Nigeria’s commercial hub, but none of the five oil-producing states, a potential headache for Buhari given restive militants in that region.  
• Voting was generally calmer than in past years, though the electoral commission logged 66 violent incidents, mainly in Rivers and other southern states.  
• With governors controlling huge budgets and influence, PDP faces a period of rebuilding after defections, corruption allegations and criticism over its handling of Boko Haram helped fuel voters’ desire for change.

• US environmental group Mighty alleges that Singapore-based trader Olam, and its majority owner Temasek, buy palm oil from “rogue” producers who use slash-and-burn clearing, thereby worsening the annual haze that affects Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand and Indonesia.  
• Mighty claims Olam has created a “secretive market” in which most of its palm oil comes from unknown, potentially unsustainable sources, and says similar forest-clearing practices are occurring in Olam’s joint-venture plantations in Gabon.  
• Olam rejects the charges, stating that it sources 99 % of its palm oil from third-party suppliers, represents less than 1 % of the global market and enforces a strict “no burn – no peat – no deforestation” policy. After pressure from Mighty, the firm has published the names of its 14 suppliers and says non-compliant producers will be dropped once vetting is complete.  
• Temasek also denies the accusations, noting it supports no-burn policies but does not direct Olam’s day-to-day operations.  
• The dispute highlights broader criticisms of the $88 bn global palm-oil industry, which faces persistent allegations of deforestation, labour abuses and weak government enforcement, especially where companies bring jobs and investment to rural areas.

On 27 August 2016, following the introduction of a law permitting dogs to dine outdoors at restaurants, an eatery began offering special “puppy platters.” A video clip shows the resulting canine feast—described as “a right dog's dinner.”

• Fernando Forestieri is doubtful with a knee problem after two substitute appearances.  
• Derby striker David Nugent may return from a groin injury after missing the Huddersfield draw.  
• Jacob Butterfield seeks a recall following his late equaliser against Huddersfield.

Pakistan has lifted its 2012 Supreme-Court-ordered ban on YouTube. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority told internet providers to restore access after Google introduced a Pakistan-specific version of the site that lets the PTA request local blocking of “offending material.” Google says such requests will be reviewed under its community guidelines and listed in its Transparency Report, and that content will not be filtered automatically. Young Pakistanis largely welcome YouTube’s return, while some activists demand fuller disclosure of the agreement’s terms. The original ban followed deadly nationwide protests over the anti-Islam film “Innocence of Muslims.” Google has also launched local YouTube versions for Nepal and Sri Lanka.

• Domenico Scala, chairman of FIFA’s Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is Swiss-Italian like presidential candidate Gianni Infantino.  
• Liberian FA president Musa Bility says this shared nationality breaches Article 7.4 on conflicts of interest and has told Scala to quit the committee by Thursday or face an appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport.  
• Scala stepped aside in 2015 when Swiss incumbent Sepp Blatter was running, but his spokesman insists no rule requires him to do so now because there is no incumbent and nationality alone is not a disqualifier.  
• FIFA’s presidential election to replace Blatter is on 26 February in Zurich; the five candidates are Infantino, Prince Ali, Sheikh Salman, Jerome Champagne and Tokyo Sexwale.  
• Bility was barred from standing in the election, now backs Prince Ali, and argues that preserving the election’s integrity is vital for FIFA after recent scandals.

• Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, died shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday at Harford Attachments, Spar Road.  
• They were working in a paint-spraying area when a suspected flashover explosion occurred, likely caused by accumulated toxic fumes ignited, creating a fire-ball effect.  
• Bodies were removed Tuesday afternoon; a forensic search of the digger-bucket factory has been completed.  
• Detective Chief Insp. Paul Durham reports “significant progress” in forensics and witness statements.  
• Health and Safety Executive inspectors and electrical safety experts are collecting further evidence.

• Morocco and Tunisia both regained the right to compete in 2017 Africa Cup of Nations qualifiers after resolving separate disputes with Caf.  

Morocco  
– Banned in February 2015 for refusing to host the 2015 finals because of Ebola fears.  
– Cas overturned the ban and cut the fine from US$1 m to US$50 000, so Morocco re-entered the 2017 qualifying draw.  
– FA president Fouzi Lekjaa said the row’s impact was “minimal”; Morocco are now in Group F with Cape Verde, Libya and São Tomé.  

Tunisia  
– Risked exclusion after sending an angry letter about refereeing in their 2015 quarter-final loss to hosts Equatorial Guinea.  
– Caf demanded an apology by 31 March 2015; a meeting with president Issa Hayatou led to Tunisia’s apology and reconciliation.  
– FTF vice-president Maher Snoussi insists they never accused Caf or the referee of corruption, only incompetence.  
– Tunisia stay in the 2017 qualifiers, drawn in Group A with Togo, Liberia and Djibouti; reaching the finals would mark a record 13th consecutive appearance.  

Additional context  
– Equatorial Guinea staged the 2015 tournament on 64 days’ notice after Morocco’s withdrawal.

In the 95th minute of Manchester City’s 3-1 home defeat by Chelsea, a mass confrontation led to FA charges against both clubs.  
• City’s Sergio Agüero was sent off for a high, late tackle on David Luiz and given a four-match ban (his second violent-conduct dismissal this season).  
• Team-mate Fernandinho was also dismissed after a clash with Cesc Fàbregas and received a three-match ban.  
• Fàbregas faces no further action.  
• City manager Pep Guardiola has apologised for his side’s conduct.  
• Both clubs must respond to the charge by 18:00 GMT on 8 December.

Wales’ cancer survival is poor partly because patients who lack obvious “red-flag” symptoms wait weeks for scattered tests and start treatment late. After studying Denmark’s rapid-diagnosis model, two Welsh health boards are piloting similar one-stop clinics:

1. Cwm Cynon pilot (six months):  
   • 40 local GPs can send any patient they suspect may have cancer straight to a diagnostic centre at Royal Glamorgan Hospital within seven days.  
   • Around six patients a week will receive multiple tests on the same day.  

2. Parallel trial at Neath Port Talbot Hospital run by Abertawe Bro Morgannwg board.

Aims: speed diagnosis, reassure patients, and improve survival—raising the current Cwm Taf figure of only 35 % of “concerning-symptom” cases diagnosed promptly. If the Cwm Cynon test succeeds, other Welsh health boards plan to adopt the service.

• England crushed Pakistan at Old Trafford, winning with a day to spare to square the four-match series 1-1.  
• Scores: England 589-8 dec & 173-1 dec; Pakistan 198 & 234 – England’s second-largest victory over Pakistan by runs.  
• Joe Root, promoted to No.3, was man of the match: 254, 71* (48 balls), four catches and a wicket.  
• Praise flowed:  
  – Michael Vaughan called it “an absolute hammering” and Root’s “best Test-match innings.”  
  – Captain Alastair Cook (105 & 76*) hailed Root as “extraordinary.”  
  – Coach Trevor Bayliss said Root “did a bit of soul-searching” after errors in the first Test.  
• Pakistan’s batting faltered, lasting only 63 and 70 overs; only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq have passed fifty in the series so far.  
• Geoffrey Boycott felt Pakistan’s “spirit was broken” and expects England to “be too strong,” while Vaughan still predicts a tight series.  
• Pakistan play Worcestershire in a two-day game before the third Test at Edgbaston on 3 August.  
• Misbah acknowledged poor shot selection and low confidence but believes his “strong characters” can respond.

• With Warren Gatland and Rob Howley away on British & Irish Lions duty in New Zealand, Wales forwards coach Robin McBryde will become Wales’ head coach for the 2017 summer tour—his third stint after leading tours in 2009 and 2013.  
• McBryde welcomes the “honour” and “exciting opportunity” to lead the national side.  
• The Welsh Rugby Union will name additional assistant coaches shortly, with a full management group expected to be confirmed next week, according to WRU chief executive Martyn Phillips.  
• WRU chairman Gareth Davies says the simultaneous Lions and Wales tours offer valuable development opportunities that will benefit Welsh rugby long-term.

Hull City 2-1 Southampton (Premier League, KCOM Stadium)

• Southampton led after 6 minutes when Charlie Austin scored a penalty given for Curtis Davies’ foul on Maya Yoshida.  
• Hull then lost both starting strikers, Abel Hernandez and Will Keane, to first-half injuries.  
• Substitute Robert Snodgrass transformed the game: on 61 minutes he swept in Sam Clucas’ cross to equalise, and two minutes later his free-kick was headed in by Michael Dawson for 2-1.  
• Saints dominated the closing stages but keeper David Marshall made several fine saves and Clucas produced a stoppage-time goal-line clearance.  
• The victory ends Hull’s six-match league losing streak, their first win since 20 August, though they remain in the bottom three going into the international break.  

Manager reaction  
• Mike Phelan praised his players’ character, singling out Marshall and Snodgrass, and welcomed the break to deal with new injuries.  
• Claude Puel blamed a post-Europa-League lapse in concentration and urged his side to learn from it.  

Next fixtures (19 Nov): Sunderland v Hull; Southampton v Liverpool.

A local motorcyclist was killed in a collision with a tractor at about 14:15 BST on the B1191 in Thornton near Woodhall Spa. The tractor driver was unhurt. Lincolnshire Police are appealing for witnesses. The B1191 was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road (Woodhall Spa) and the A158 Jubilee Way (Horncastle).

Macedonian President Gjorge Ivanov has halted the probe into covert-recording allegations of high-level abuse of power, saying he wants to end the long-running political “agony” before June’s early elections and to “defend national interests.”  

Reactions:  
• Opposition leader Zoran Zaev called the decision illegal and urged demonstrations; several hundred protesters gathered in Skopje.  
• EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn said the move violates rule-of-law principles and jeopardises Macedonia’s EU bid.  

Background:  
Since 2015 Zaev has released recordings that allegedly show ministers rigging votes, covering up a murder, wire-tapping 20,000 people and engaging in corruption; the government denies the claims and accuses Zaev of trying to destabilise the country.

• Alan Curtis and assistant Paul Williams will oversee Swansea’s game against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley’s dismissal.  
• The club hopes to appoint a new manager quickly, with former Derby boss Paul Clement their preferred choice.  
• Curtis stresses the need for a manager capable of avoiding relegation, warning that promotion back from the Championship would be difficult if Swansea go down.  
• Promoted in 2011, Swansea’s rise followed near-bankruptcy and a brush with relegation from the Football League in 2003; they became known for attractive, possession-based football.  
• Curtis believes the club “lost the Swansea Way” after Michael Laudrup’s 2014 exit due to frequent managerial changes and inadequate player replacements; the Martínez, Rodgers and Laudrup eras are cited as the best.  
• He still thinks the current squad can stay up and ensures new signings understand the club’s journey, often via the documentary “Jack to a King.”

Leyton Orient beat Dagenham & Redbridge 3-2 (Simpson 2, Gnanduillet; Cureton, Dikamona).  
• Result confirmed Dagenham’s relegation from League Two back to the National League, nine years after entering the Football League (2007) and six after reaching League One (2010) under current boss John Still.  
• The Daggers have League Two’s worst goal difference, have shipped 20 more goals than at the same stage last season, and rely on 40-year-old Jamie Cureton, whose nine goals are down from 20 in 2014-15. Still says he will stay to pursue promotion next year.  
• Orient, now two points outside the play-offs, played their first game since Kevin Nolan lost the manager’s job; interim boss Andy Hessenthaler stressed professionalism and the need to keep winning.

• Former Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard, 36, will re-join the club in February as a youth coach, his first role since retiring in November after a 19-year playing career.  
• Manager Jürgen Klopp welcomed the move, saying they discussed Gerrard’s ambition to become a manager and calling the appointment “wonderful news.”  
• Gerrard is working toward his UEFA A coaching licence and views this post as a step toward future management.  
• He had considered but declined the MK Dons managerial vacancy, feeling it was “too soon.”  
• Gerrard’s playing career began with his Liverpool debut in 1998; he left in 2015 for LA Galaxy and won the Champions League, UEFA Cup, FA Cup and the League Cup three times while at Anfield.

Morton beat Alloa 4–1: McManus scored twice (first after 15 minutes), Forbes added a deflected second, McAusland briefly made it 2–1 before half-time, and Johnstone sealed the hosts’ comfortable victory late on.

• Ofsted inspected 18 suspected unregistered schools, mainly in Muslim communities in the Midlands, and found three Birmingham sites where children were taught in “squalid, unhygienic and unsafe” conditions; all three are now closed.  
• Running an illegal school (teaching children more than 20 hours a week without registering) carries a potential jail sentence of up to 51 weeks.  
• Ministers are consulting on tighter rules for any setting that teaches children 6–8 hours a week or more.  
• Sir Michael Wilshaw warned the cases found are likely only “the tip of the iceberg” and that children risk abuse or radicalisation; he criticised officials for slow, confusing advice to proprietors.  
• The government has funded a six-person Ofsted team to investigate illegal schools and has asked Ofsted to prepare prosecution cases; Education Secretary consent is required for each prosecution.  
• Action will target any religious group—Muslim, Jewish, Christian, etc.—operating unsafe, unregistered education centres.  
• Public consultation on the proposed regulations runs until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin, operating from the Born in the Borders visitor centre near Jedburgh, is the first new distillery in the Scottish Borders for almost 200 years. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes runs the tiny, cowshed-sized facility—one of the UK’s smallest stills—using local Teviot valley botanicals to express the area’s “terroir.” The venture complements the on-site Scottish Borders Brewery and precedes several planned whisky projects in the region. Named after the 1545 Battle of Ancrum Moor heroine Lilliard, the brand highlights both local heritage and its all-female production team.

• In August 2013, Gary Green, 51, reversed a tractor into Harry Whitlam at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, near Leeds, killing the boy.  
• Green, who had drunk the equivalent of about 13 pints and was more than twice the legal drink-drive limit, was operating on private land, so he was charged under health-and-safety, not road-traffic, law.  
• He admitted failing to ensure others’ safety and received a 16-month-and-two-week jail sentence.  
• Harry’s mother, Pam Whitlam, said the family had been “changed forever” and stressed that no one should drive any vehicle while drunk.  
• HSE inspector Julian Franklin called the incident “extremely tragic” and Green’s behaviour “reckless.”

Luis Suárez’s appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) has partly succeeded. 

1. What changes  
   • The four-month suspension for biting Giorgio Chiellini still stands, but CAS ruled it “excessive” to bar him from all football activity.  
   • Suárez may now train with Barcelona, play in friendlies, attend matches and do promotional work.

2. What remains  
   • He must miss the next eight competitive Uruguay internationals (the remainder of his nine-match FIFA ban).  
   • He cannot play competitive club football until the suspension ends; his Barcelona debut is expected in El Clasico at Real Madrid on 26 October.

3. Immediate schedule  
   • First Barça training session: Friday; public presentation: Monday at Camp Nou.  
   • Eligible for Uruguay friendlies versus Japan and South Korea in September and Saudi Arabia in October.

4. Reactions  
   • CAS said FIFA’s overall sanctions were “generally confirmed” but total activity ban was disproportionate.  
   • Players’ union FIFPro called the penalties still “disproportionate.”  
   • Commentators (e.g., Gary Lineker) and lawyers note the decision balances punishment with the club’s interests.

5. Context  
   • Suárez, 27, joined Barcelona from Liverpool for £75 m last month.  
   • This is his third biting incident; he also served an eight-match ban in 2011 for racially abusing Patrice Evra.

On 18 March 2014, Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a 380-metre “wife-carrying” race, edging Lithuanian pair Vytautas Kirkliauskas and Neringa Kirliauskiene. The course includes haystack hurdles, a steep slope and water-pistol attacks. Any pairing can enter—the event featured men carrying women or men, and one woman carrying a woman. After a week’s track training, the winning duo now advance to the World Championships in Finland this July.

• From October 2014 the paper car-tax disc will be abolished and replaced by an electronic system that lets motorists pay by monthly direct debit.  
• Stephen Hammond, the responsible minister, told Swansea East AM Mike Hedges that this shift will alter some job roles at the DVLA’s 5,000-strong Swansea centre and cut the volume of refund processing.  
• Hammond said any staffing reductions would be handled through retraining and redeployment, not redundancies.  
• Hedges welcomed the assurance, saying it should reassure concerned DVLA employees even though overall job opportunities will fall.

Hungary says it will not amend three controversial measures—tighter asylum-seeker controls, a draft law labelling NGOs as “foreign-backed,” and a Higher Education Law that could shut the Soros-founded Central European University—arguing they are purely domestic matters. Foreign Minister Péter Szijjártó told Reuters that the EU “should refrain from interfering,” and that Poland has promised to veto any attempt to strip Hungary of its EU voting rights, a sanction that requires unanimous approval. The right-wing Fidesz government faces sustained EU pressure, large street protests at home, and warnings from EU Vice-President Frans Timmermans of impending action if no “positive developments” occur. Critics question the legality of housing asylum seekers in secured shipping containers, and human-rights groups say the NGO bill would stigmatize civil society organisations.

A live-action Beauty and the Beast film is in the works:

• “The star” will portray Mrs Potts, the teapot housekeeper.  
• Kevin Kline plays Maurice (Belle’s father).  
• Emma Watson is Belle, with Dan Stevens as the Beast and Luke Evans as Gaston.  
• Josh Gad appears as Gaston’s sidekick LeFou.  
• Bill Condon directs; filming starts at Shepperton Studios in May.  
• US release is set for 17 March 2017.

Adrian ‘A. A.’ Gill, the celebrated – and often controversial – Sunday Times columnist, has died from the “full English” of cancers shortly after revealing his diagnosis. 

Key facts
• Career: Joined the Sunday Times in 1993 and became its “heart and soul”, famed for dazzling, fearless prose that he dictated by phone because of dyslexia. Earlier wrote art reviews, then Tatler.  
• Reputation: Lauded as “a giant among journalists” yet notorious for incendiary pieces – shooting a baboon, insults aimed at the Welsh, Rhyl, Norfolk, the Isle of Man and presenter Clare Balding, for which he was censured.  
• Tributes: Paid by editor Martin Ivens, former editors John Witherow and Andrew Neil, and writers Jay Rayner, Tim Shipman, Stig Abell and Piers Morgan.  
• Background: Born Edinburgh 1954; educated at St Christopher School, Central Saint Martins and the Slade.  
• Personal life: Married author Cressida Connolly (1983) and future Home Secretary Amber Rudd (1991), with whom he had Flora and Alistair. Illness prompted engagement to long-time partner Nicola Formby (“The Blonde”), mother of their twins Edith and Isaac.  
• Final work: His last column, reflecting on his illness, appears in tomorrow’s Sunday Times.

Mongolian rapper Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar (stage name Amraa, lead singer of Khar Sarnai) was allegedly beaten in Ulan Bator by an unnamed Russian diplomatic officer who struck him with a bottle and kicked him in the face after the performer appeared on stage in a traditional red deel embroidered with a swastika. The swastika is an ancient Mongolian symbol that predates Nazi use, though it is also employed by local far-right groups; the artist’s family and lawyer deny claims he shouted “Heil Hitler.” Sukhbaatar spent about ten days in a coma and suffered serious brain injuries. Mongolian police say the case is under investigation; the suspect was not detained, with police citing the injury’s classification and rejecting suggestions of diplomatic immunity. The Russian embassy says it is probing the incident but contends media reports about the date, participants and circumstances are “distorted.”

Activists from the Plane Stupid group staged a protest on the airport’s northern runway at 03:30 BST on Monday to oppose expansion plans. They have been charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security-restricted aerodrome area and are due in court on 19 August. The Metropolitan Police will review airport security following the incident.

• In Cardiff, Glamorgan were bowled out for 220, their total built almost entirely on opener Nick Selman’s 101 from 144 balls—his second first-class century after four successive ducks.

• Gloucestershire seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles exploited helpful, cloudy conditions to take regular wickets; Taylor hit the stumps three times.

• Apart from Selman, only Aneurin Donald (36 off 30) and late runs from Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten added any substance, giving Glamorgan one batting bonus point.

• Gloucestershire’s reply began in evening gloom; the match ended with the game finely balanced and bowlers still on top.

• Glamorgan were captained by Michael Hogan, standing in for the injured Jacques Rudolph.

• Post-play, Selman spoke of regaining form after recent failures, while Taylor noted the assistance for seamers and his satisfaction at limiting Glamorgan to 220.

Craig Hughes, 33, from Flint, was arrested in August after telling Tennessee’s Hope Line Crisis Centre that he planned to make a false emergency call and then shoot responding officers on the Dee Estuary. He made the threats twice while drunk. At Mold Crown Court he admitted two charges; sentencing is next week. Judge Niclas Parry remanded him in custody, noting Hughes’s 2009 firearm conviction and the fact he was on bail for other firearms offences (since cleared). Hughes’s lawyers said he never truly intended to carry out the threats. The Hope Line provides confidential support and counselling.

Surrey beat Yorkshire by 19 runs.

Surrey innings:
• Slipped to 8-2 but recovered to 255-7.
• Steven Davies (six and 10 fours) and Ben Foakes (90) added 130.
• Matthew Waite dropped Davies on 43; later took 3-48.

Yorkshire chase:
• Adam Lyth fell early; they reached 75-2.
• Stuart Meaker’s burst of 3-61 in nine balls removed Jonny Bairstow, Gary Ballance and Jack Leaning.
• Tim Bresnan’s 68 and Waite’s 38 left 27 needed from the final three overs; Yorkshire were all out for 236, Bresnan last man out.

Reaction:
• Surrey captain Gareth Batty hailed the Davies-Foakes stand and timely wickets.
• Yorkshire captain Alex Lees said the bowlers set up a reachable target but top-order batting failed.

Context:
Yorkshire, beaten in the T20 Blast semi-final the previous weekend, missed the chance to reach a Lord’s final for the first time since 2002.

At 07:00 BST a 56 ft (17 m) converted trawler, 6 mi (10 km) west of South Stack, radioed Holyhead coastguards after its own pump failed to stem flooding. An RNLI lifeboat provided an additional pump and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

Laura Muir, 24-year-old Scottish middle-distance runner and final-year veterinary medicine student, will skip the April 2018 Commonwealth Games on Australia’s Gold Coast because they clash with her May exams. She returns to university next week and says completing her degree takes priority, though she is “gutted” to miss one of the few events where she can represent Scotland. Muir still hopes to target the World Indoor Championships in March if studies allow. At the recent World Athletics Championships she placed fourth in the 1500 m, sixth in the 5,000 m—setting an outdoor personal best of 14:52.07—and believes she has “at least two, even three more Olympics” ahead.

• Six months after Steven Gerrard’s slip v Chelsea ended Liverpool’s title hopes, Robbie Savage argues the team now look “miles away” from another challenge and must instead fight just to finish in the top four; if Brendan Rodgers achieves consecutive Champions-League qualifications it should be judged a success.  

• Main reason for decline: goals have vanished. Suarez has been sold, Sturridge is injured, and replacements Balotelli, Lambert and Borini neither score nor press with last season’s intensity. Result: only 4 first-half league goals in 10 games compared with 59 across 38 matches last year; set-piece productivity has also collapsed.  

• Defensive frailties remain despite heavy spending (Sakho £18 m, Lovren £20 m). Back line still lacks a leader and goalkeeper Mignolet is not commanding.  

• Savage’s XI v Chelsea: Mignolet; Johnson, Skrtel, Toure, Moreno; Can, Gerrard; Sterling, Coutinho, Lallana; Borini. He would drop Lovren, use a compact midfield four, and rely on full-backs for width. Even so he expects Chelsea, “on a different planet”, to win at Anfield again.  

• Gerrard, 34, can still anchor midfield and should get a new contract, but must manage the physical and mental demands of age; the memory of the slip will hurt, yet his desire should extend his Liverpool career beyond this season.

East Ayrshire Council plans a £45 million education campus on Sutherland Drive, Kilmarnock, containing primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school and a childcare centre, and hopes to name it after William McIlvanney.  Born and schooled in Kilmarnock, McIlvanney taught English before turning to full-time writing in 1975, debuting with Remedy Is None and later earning the title “Godfather of Tartan Noir” for the Laidlaw trilogy and novels such as Docherty and The Big Man.  He was also a noted poet, journalist, broadcaster and commentator on Scottish politics and sport.  McIlvanney died at his Glasgow home on 5 December.

A suspected British sea mine from the 1940s-50s was discovered in the river at Gourock on Monday.  

• Three nearby streets were evacuated on a precautionary basis through the morning and early afternoon, and people within 500 m were told to stay indoors, open windows and keep close to walls.  
• A half-mile exclusion zone was imposed on the water; small boats were banned and Caledonian MacBrayne ferries between Gourock and Rothesay were disrupted.  
• Royal Navy Northern Diving Unit personnel, uncertain how much explosive remained because of the mine’s deterioration, decided to move it to a safer location before making it safe.  
• Police emphasized there was no immediate danger, and Inverclyde Council thanked residents and businesses for their cooperation.

UK Sport has announced its Tokyo 2020 funding plan:  
• Total pot: £345 m for 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports, £2 m less than the Rio 2016 cycle.  
• Sports losing all backing: archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby – and badminton, which received £5.74 m last cycle and took a Rio bronze (Ellis/Langridge).  
• Cycling drops by over £4 m to £25.98 m; judo gets a small rise despite an identical one-bronze return.  
• Medal targets for Tokyo: 51–85 Olympic and 115–162 Paralympic medals (Rio totals were 67 and 147).  
• UK Sport says limited funds must be focused on greatest medal potential; critics (notably Badminton England and representatives of basketball, volleyball and handball) accuse it of neglecting certain and especially team sports.  
• Funding for Tokyo’s new sports (baseball/softball, karate, skateboarding, sport climbing, surfing, Para-taekwondo, Para-badminton) is still to be decided; £9 m remains unallocated. The government has confirmed continued support for the overall programme.

Bournemouth councillors have approved (7–3) plans to demolish three Victorian hotels—Bay View Court, The Cottonwood and the Ocean View—on Grove Road/East Overcliff Drive. The site will be redeveloped by The East Cliff Project LLP into a six-storey, 90-room four-star hotel plus two assisted-living blocks of nine and seven storeys containing 122 apartments. English Heritage, the Ancient Monuments Society and 49 residents opposed the scheme, arguing it would severely damage the conservation area, while 246 letters backed it. Planning board chair Cllr David Kelsey said the old hotels are no longer functional and that the project balances tourism needs with improved housing for older people, despite the regrettable loss of historic buildings and trees.

Off-duty soldier Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, of the Royal Gibraltar Regiment and originally from Carrickfergus, was found unconscious and later died after being punched and repeatedly beaten outside The Cellar bar in Brecon in the early hours of 8 May. CCTV showed Jake Vallely, 24, who had been drinking for seven hours and boasting he was the “hardest man in Brecon,” carrying out the attack and dragging Boyd’s body away before fleeing. Vallely was convicted and will be sentenced on 8 December, while his friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of manslaughter after evidence showed he had left before the assault. Police condemned the “despicable” killing, and Boyd’s family paid tribute to the lively, caring soldier whose promising career was cut short.

• Barnet Council’s chief executive Andrew Travers has left “by mutual agreement” following polling day errors that omitted voters’ names from registers at all 155 stations, causing many to be turned away.  
• An independent investigation, reporting by the end of May to the General Functions Committee, will examine the failure and preparations for June’s EU referendum; the council is still choosing who will lead it.  
• Deputy chief executive John Hooton becomes interim chief executive.  
• The council apologised, issued emergency proxy votes, and faced residents’ concerns over the election’s fairness.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1.  
• Josh Gillies put Gateshead ahead with a first-half free-kick.  
• Wrexham levelled before the break through Sean Newton’s free-kick.  
• Ryan Bowman headed in Craig Baxter’s cross for the second-half winner.  

Manager reactions:  
• Gateshead’s Malcolm Crosby praised his side’s improved second-half passing and the quality of Bowman’s goal.  
• Wrexham’s Gary Mills lamented his team’s recurring second-half drop-off and missed chances.
The 2014 Global AgeWatch Index ranks social and economic welfare for people over 60 in 96 countries. Norway is first, while Afghanistan is last, with Mozambique second-to-last.

OneWeb, with Airbus as manufacturing partner, is building a global broadband constellation that starts with at least 600 satellites and could exceed 2,000, aiming to connect every part of the planet, including all schools.  

Key points:

1. Mass-production approach  
   • Airbus has opened its first high-volume line in Toulouse and will add two more in Florida.  
   • Target: three satellites per shift for under US$1 million each— a major shift from traditional, expensive “gold-plated” spacecraft.

2. Deployment timetable  
   • First 10 satellites launch next April, another batch in November.  
   • >300 satellites on-orbit by end-2020/early-2021, >600 about a year later, >800 by mid-decade.  
   • Over 20 Soyuz rockets, each carrying 32–36 spacecraft, constitute the largest launch campaign in history.

3. Financing and competitive position  
   • $1.7 billion in equity already raised; further loans sought.  
   • Competing plans exist (SpaceX, Boeing, ViaSat, etc.), but Airbus/OneWeb claim a first-mover edge.

4. UK involvement  
   • Company registered in the Channel Islands; licensed by the UK Space Agency.  
   • Expected revenue flow and regulatory leadership should bolster the UK space ecosystem.

5. Space-debris mitigation  
   • ESA study urges de-orbit within five years; OneWeb pledges re-entry within two, with added hardware and a capture adapter for failed satellites.

6. Industry impact  
   • Airbus hopes to use the new production lines for other customers, though bespoke, high-end satellites will remain necessary for certain missions.

The project thus hinges on unprecedented low-cost mass manufacturing, an aggressive launch schedule, significant financing, and stringent debris-mitigation commitments.

• Scottish Finance Secretary John Swinney says the UK government’s recent spending review imposes “unprecedented” pressure, leaving Scotland’s discretionary budget 12.5 % lower in real terms by 2019-20 than in 2010-11, with 4.2 % of that fall still to come and over £1 bn in further cuts expected.  
• He will set out the 2016-17 Scottish budget on Wednesday and vows to shield schools, hospitals and the police from these cuts, citing past gains such as more police, lower crime, free university tuition and a record health budget.  
• The UK government counters that Scotland will actually have £390 m more to spend next year (or £750 m counting underspend) and says the block grant will be almost £30 bn, arguing this is preferable to the SNP’s independence option.  
• Scottish Labour accuses Swinney of anti-austerity “posturing” and demands a long-term budget with alternative tax choices to both the Conservatives and the SNP.

• Standard “accessible” toilets do not meet the needs of many people who require a hoist, an adult-sized bench and space for two carers; without these facilities families often resort to changing relatives on dirty floors or in cars, limiting outings and causing distress.  
• Changing Places toilets provide the required space (about 12 m²) and equipment; an estimated 250,000+ UK residents need them, yet only 893 exist nationwide.  
• Since 2009 the Building Standard (BS 8300:2009) has merely recommended, not required, their inclusion, so designers and businesses frequently omit them, citing cost, space and retrofit difficulties.  
• Campaigners such as Lorna Fillingham are petitioning for compulsory provision in new large buildings (shopping centres, cinemas, sports venues); evidence has been submitted to the Women and Equalities Committee.  
• Real-world examples show both the problems and the benefits: families describe humiliation when facilities are absent, but report greatly improved experiences where Changing Places toilets are provided, e.g. Cardiff’s city centre and Arsenal FC’s stadium, which successfully converted two standard toilets into one Changing Place.

Italian consumer groups, backed by SEIU and several European unions, have filed an antitrust complaint with the European Commission alleging that McDonald's:

• Imposes excessive rents, fees and unusually long contracts on franchisees, preventing them from switching to rivals.  
• Uses these terms to maintain a dominant market position, which they say raises prices and reduces consumer choice.

Franchisees run 73 % of McDonald’s European outlets and generated $9.27 bn in global franchise revenue for the firm in 2014.

McDonald’s rejects the claims, arguing its risk-and-reward model benefits both franchisees and customers.  
The European Commission will examine the complaint and can open a formal investigation if it finds merit.

• 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, Co Down was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve during what was meant to be an appendix operation at Belfast’s Royal Victoria Hospital; surgeons removed one large tumour and five smaller growths.  
• Bangor Elim Church, where Josh’s father works, added the hashtag #prayforjosh to Facebook and Instagram posts seeking prayer and support.  
• The hashtag went viral: one update was shared 948 times and viewed by more than 79,000 people worldwide, with further backing on Twitter from classmates and others.  
• Within the last week a large roadside billboard reading “#prayforjosh” was anonymously funded and erected beside the A2 at Holywood playing fields.  
• Josh’s family, church and a growing global online community are now rallying behind him during his recovery.

The UK is reorganising its military estate. Plans include:
• Closing Brecon Barracks in Powys, ending a military presence that has existed since 1805.  
• Creating a specialist light-infantry centre at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan.  
• Shutting Cawdor Barracks, Pembrokeshire, in 2024 and a storage depot at Sennybridge in 2025.  

Brecon and Radnorshire MP Chris Davies condemns the Brecon closure, citing its historic role, local unemployment and tourism; he is launching a petition. About 85 civilian and 90 military staff work there, with no immediate job losses expected. Nearby Sennybridge training ground and the Dering Lines infantry school will stay open. Labour’s Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith supports rationalising the estate but warns of uncertainty for affected communities.

A House of Lords EU Committee report says that although fishing drove pro-Brexit sentiment, the sector is small (0.5 % of GDP, 12 000 jobs) and could be sidelined in the talks.  

Key points:  
• UK catches mainly come from stocks shared with EU states; most UK-caught fish is sold to, and much of that eaten in Britain is bought from, the EU.  
• Continued tariff-free access to the EU market may require Britain to let some EU boats keep fishing in UK waters.  
• The report urges retention of core Common Fisheries Policy features—science-based quotas, international cooperation—and warns that quitting the CFP could leave England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland with four different management regimes.  
• Industry figures remain upbeat, citing the chance to control a 200-mile exclusive zone and recent quota rises for plaice, haddock and prawns.  
• The government says Brexit is an opportunity for fairer, sustainable fisheries while aiming for maximum single-market access.

• Edward Snowden, a 29-year-old former CIA technical worker, revealed he leaked classified documents because he found the scale of U.S. surveillance “horrifying.”  
• The documents show the NSA collects, on a massive scale, phone metadata from companies such as Verizon (call duration, location, numbers) and, through the Prism programme (established 2007), can obtain chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, social-network posts, web chats and search activity from servers of Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, PalTalk, AOL, Skype, YouTube and Apple. All nine firms deny giving “back-door” access; experts suggest access may be limited and court-ordered.  
• U.S. officials call the leaks “extremely damaging” and say surveillance has prevented attacks, arguing full transparency would aid terrorists. President Obama states total privacy is incompatible with total security; Senator Dianne Feinstein says records are only queried for links to al-Qaeda or Iran.  
• Data-protection laws mainly regulate companies, not governments; most corporate privacy policies allow disclosure when legally required. Because cloud data of users worldwide is often stored in the U.S., the Patriot Act and FISA Amendments let American authorities reach non-U.S. data with minimal transparency.  
• Foreign reaction is uncertain: the U.K.’s GCHQ will not confirm or deny involvement; the EU Commission seeks details and stresses that national courts decide legality of data transfers.  
• Privacy advocates say Prism shows that anyone using major online services may be monitored without recourse. Snowden says he leaked the information so people would not “live in a world where everything I do and say is recorded.”

OpenAI is a new, non-profit AI venture backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys and Amazon Web Services. It has $1 billion pledged but plans to spend only a small portion of that in the near term. Free from profit motives, the project says it will pursue research that maximizes “positive human impact,” making AI an extension of human will and sharing its benefits widely and safely. The initiative arises amid warnings—from Musk and Stephen Hawking, among others—that advanced AI could become an existential threat, though some experts consider such risks remote.

Doncaster soldier Lance Bombardier Ben Parkinson, who suffered severe brain injuries in a 2006 Afghanistan bomb attack, carried the Olympic torch for almost 30 minutes on 26 June, walking with crutches and an assistant. The event triggered an outpouring of public support: more than 5,000 Facebook friend requests (the site’s personal-page limit), 19,000 hits on one update, a surge of mail and e-mail, and thousands joining his Pilgrim Bandits charity site. Parkinson, who now speaks unaided, spends about 12 hours a day on rehabilitation and fundraising for military charities. Facebook advises he open a public page or use its “subscribe” feature. Overall, 8,000 people are carrying the torch on its 8,000-mile, 70-day route to the London Olympics opening on 27 July.

In 2011 the U.S. poverty rate held at 15%, leaving 46.2 million people in poverty after three years of earlier increases. The average poverty line for a family of four was $23,021. Real median household income fell 1.5%, while income inequality (Gini index) rose 1.6%—its first annual increase since 1993. The share of uninsured Americans dropped to 15.7% from 16.3%. Poverty had reached a record 15.1% in 2010.

• Jos Buttler, 25, who joined Lancashire from Somerset in 2013, has signed a new contract that keeps him at the club until 2019.  
• A short-format specialist, Buttler holds England’s three fastest ODI centuries, highlighted by a 46-ball hundred against Pakistan.  
• Lancashire cricket director and head coach Ashley Giles calls him “one of the most talented cricketers in the game,” noting his decisive role in last year’s T20 Blast final and his positive influence in the dressing room.  
• After a stint with Mumbai Indians in the IPL, Buttler will rejoin Lancashire for Friday’s T20 Blast home fixture against Durham.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates—HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham and HMS Cornwall—are laid up in Portsmouth Harbour and are up for sale. 

Key points:
• Interested buyers had to register by 23 January; viewings run in late February-March and a final decision is due in the spring.  
• No preservation schemes have yet been submitted.  
• The Disposal Services Authority wants at least one ship taken by a UK recycler to test domestic capability, though MP Penny Mordaunt hopes at least one will instead be preserved, ideally sunk as an artificial reef to boost tourism.  
• The Ministry of Defence will choose the option giving the best financial return but is keeping bid details confidential.  
• Type 22 frigates were originally anti-submarine vessels that became versatile surface combatants and typical flagships, carrying about 280 crew.  
• The previous major Royal Navy sale was aircraft carrier HMS Ark Royal, scrapped for £3 million last year.

Since 1987 Fiji has suffered repeated coups rooted in tension between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians: 
• 1987 coup overthrew an Indian-dominated government and briefly imposed a constitution guaranteeing indigenous supremacy. 
• 2000 coup led by George Speight held the first ethnic-Indian prime minister and others hostage. 
• 2006 bloodless military takeover was the fourth coup in 20 years. 
The upheavals damaged tourism, the wider economy and Fiji’s international standing, leading to Commonwealth suspension in 2009. After promising and holding free elections in 2014, Fiji regained normal ties with Australia and New Zealand and was readmitted to the Commonwealth. 

Demography: Population is now a small indigenous Fijian majority after many Indo-Fijians emigrated; social life is largely segregated, with tiny Chinese, Rotuman and other minorities.

Economy: Though sugar and tourism earn most foreign exchange, Fiji also mines gold, silver and limestone and has services and light manufacturing. Chronic trade and budget deficits leave it one of the world’s highest per-capita aid recipients.

• Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad says Syria is “doing its best” to meet the UN/OPCW timetable for eliminating its 1,300 tonnes of chemical weapons, despite missing the deadline to hand over the full stockpile.

• He blames the delay on wartime security, claiming one of two outgoing shipments from Damascus to Latakia was twice attacked by “terrorist groups.”

• Only about 30 tonnes (4%) of the arsenal have left Syria so far; the U.S. warns the plan is slipping, while Russia urges Syria to finish coastal transfers by 1 March and all destruction is due by end-June. The OPCW confirms security problems are slowing the operation.

• Mekdad rejects U.S. criticism of government barrel-bomb use in Aleppo, insists the army does not target civilians, and accuses Washington of backing “terrorists.”

• Monitors say barrel bombs have killed at least 246 people (73 children) in Aleppo over five days; activists report 14 more deaths on Thursday.

• Conflicting claims persist over Aleppo’s central prison: the Syrian Observatory and rebel sources say Islamic Front and al-Nusra fighters overran it and freed hundreds of detainees; state media says government forces repelled the attack and still hold the facility.

• Mekdad affirms: “Syria is committed to all its agreements… We shall implement on time all our obligations.”

Booker Prize 2014 – key facts

1. Prize changes and timetable  
• 46th year of the award, but the first time it is open to any writer publishing in English, whatever their nationality.  
• Winner to be announced at London’s Guildhall on Tuesday night and shown live on BBC News/Arts.

2. The six-book shortlist  
• Neel Mukherjee – The Lives of Others (1960s Calcutta family saga; bookmaker favourite at 5/2).  
• Richard Flanagan – The Narrow Road to the Deep North (WWII Burma Railway love story; 3/1).  
• Howard Jacobson – J (dystopian love story; Jacobson won in 2010).  
• Ali Smith – How To Be Both (twin narratives, Renaissance Italy and 1960s child).  
• Joshua Ferris – To Rise Again at a Decent Hour (atheist New York dentist and online identity).  
• Karen Joy Fowler – We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves (family tale narrated by college student Rosemary; best-selling of the six with 55,000 UK copies).

3. Sales impact of the shortlist  
• Post-announcement surge for all titles; Fowler leads overall sales, Mukherjee jumped from 97 to 507 copies in a week; Ferris next at just over 6,000 since May.

4. Judging and stakes  
• Panel chaired by A.C. Grayling with Sarah Churchwell, Jonathan Bate, Daniel Glaser, Alastair Niven and Erica Wagner.  
• Each shortlisted writer already receives £2,500 and a specially bound copy.  
• Literary critics describe the list as “weak” and question whether Jacobson could become a two-time winner so soon after Hilary Mantel’s recent double.

5. Recent context  
• Last year’s prize went to 28-year-old New Zealander Eleanor Catton for The Luminaries, making her the youngest Booker winner to date.

• A married celebrity, identified in court as “PJS”, is fighting to keep his name out of the English and Welsh media while The Sun on Sunday seeks to publish claims of his occasional sexual encounters, including a 2011 three-way meeting with two people (AB and CD).  
• After an earlier High Court refusal, PJS won a temporary anonymity order from the Court of Appeal, but on Monday that court lifted the ban, saying the allegations were already so widely reported abroad and online that confidentiality was “probably lost” and a permanent injunction was now “unlikely”.  
• The Court of Appeal gave PJS until 10:00 BST Tuesday to petition the UK Supreme Court; publication of his identity was barred until 13:00 BST Wednesday.  
• The Supreme Court has agreed to hear arguments on whether to grant a full appeal; its interim injunction keeps the anonymity order in force until the hearing ends.

• Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1, opened in 1989.  
• It was purchased in August for £345.5 million (new owners include Crown Estates).  
• The owners and Blaby District Council are drafting plans to:  
  – ease parking and traffic congestion,  
  – refurbish shop fronts and other “tired” areas,  
  – upgrade walkways, parking zones and other common facilities.  
• Council leader Ernie White calls the site “the gateway from Blaby into the city” and wants a better first impression.  
• Crown Estates’ Paul Clarke stresses that improving parking, congestion and overall quality is the priority.

Disney’s live-action “Beauty and the Beast” was meant to open in Malaysia this Thursday but was delayed for a content “review” because it contains an “exclusively gay moment.”  
• The Malaysian Censorship Board has now approved the movie with one “minor edit” to that scene and given it a P13 (parental guidance) rating, yet no new release date has been set.  
• Board chairman Abdul Hamid stressed that once content is approved screening logistics are up to the cinemas; ticket-holders are being offered refunds.  
• The brief scene shows LeFou grappling with romantic feelings for Gaston.  
• Homosexual acts are illegal in Muslim-majority Malaysia, though the tourism minister called an outright ban “ridiculous.”  
• The review decision sparked online mockery, with users labeling it “stupid and laughable.”

Southampton landlords who rent to more than three unrelated tenants must hold a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) licence, which costs about £1,000; failure to obtain one can lead to fines of up to £20,000. The city estimates around 1,500 HMOs remain unlicensed. National rules target houses of three or more storeys with five-plus unrelated occupants, while Southampton’s scheme specifically covers properties in Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling (since 2013) and Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, Bassett (since 2015). Shelter reports 5–6 daily calls from tenants worried about eviction and poor conditions. Most landlords comply, but some resist; the council has prosecuted one company and 13 individuals so far.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny (Fine Gael) and Fianna Fáil leader Micheál Martin seek to form a minority government and avert a second election. Fianna Fáil will enable such a government but will not endorse its programme. Disagreement over water charges—Fianna Fáil wants them scrapped, Fine Gael wants to retain them—is the chief obstacle; a commission on Irish Water’s future is being discussed. The recent election left Fine Gael with 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23 and Labour 7, leaving no party with a majority and no taoiseach yet elected.

Fire broke out Tuesday afternoon on car deck of Italian-owned ferry Sorrento, 27 km off Mallorca while sailing to Valencia. Distress call sent 13:50 local; blaze soon forced full evacuation. Passengers and crew left in lifeboats, were picked up by passenger ferry Puglia and are being taken back to Palma de Mallorca, where psychologists will meet them. At least three people were air-lifted to hospital (one seriously injured). Several vessels joined the rescue. Cause of the fire is unknown, and authorities warn the Sorrento may sink.

• 38 MPs told the Electoral Commission that people, including students, claimed online to have voted twice in the 8 June general election, an offence punishable by an unlimited fine.  
• Britain has 381 separate local electoral registers that cannot communicate with the central online registration system, so duplicate entries cannot be automatically spotted.  
• From 1 December 2016 to the 22 May 2017 deadline, 4.9 million registration applications were submitted (2.9 million in the six weeks after the snap poll was called), yet the register only grew by 1.4 million—implying 30–70 % duplicates in different areas.  
• A record 46.8 million people were registered and 68.7 % voted, the highest general-election turnout since 1997; several student-heavy constituencies saw electorates rise by more than 10 %.  
• The Commission wants:  
  – local registers electronically linked to the online system,  
  – an online “check-before-you-apply” verification function (used in Australia, New Zealand, Ireland),  
  – people registered in two seats to pick in advance where they will vote.  
• Labour supports enforcing the law against double voting but cautions against changes that would make it harder for students and young people to register.

Officials say former University of Nebraska and NFL running back Lawrence Phillips, 40, apparently committed suicide in his single-occupancy prison cell early Wednesday. A 1990s college star who later played for the St Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers, Phillips’ pro career ended in 1999 amid repeated legal troubles. He was serving a sentence of more than 30 years for driving his car into a group of teenagers and for assaulting a former girlfriend, and had been isolated after being accused of killing cellmate Damion Soward; a judge ruled Tuesday that Phillips could stand trial for that death. The method of suicide is unknown. Former Nebraska coach Tom Osborne said Phillips was intelligent but struggled with persistent anger issues.

Private Derby XXX, the Mercian Regiment’s Swaledale ram mascot, was promoted to lance corporal in Chester during celebrations of the regiment’s eighth anniversary. Brigadier Andrew Williams presented the promotion, citing the ram’s “good behaviour.” Derby XXX is the 30th ram in an unbroken mascot line that began in 1858 during the Indian Mutiny. Enlisted in February 2014, he has an army number, draws pay for his rations, and spends mating-season leave on the Chatsworth Estate. His service highlights include switching on Ashbourne’s Christmas lights and meeting Prince William at the unveiling of the 1914 Christmas Truce memorial.

Liverpool’s Europa League quarter-final second leg at Anfield produced a classic.  
• Borussia Dortmund led 2-0 after nine minutes through Mkhitaryan and Aubameyang, then 3-1 when Reus scored after the break.  
• Liverpool, needing three goals in the last half-hour, replied via Origi, Coutinho, Sakho and, in injury time, a towering Lovren header to win 4-3 and reach the semi-finals.  
• Jurgen Klopp’s touchline passion, his mantra of turning “doubters into believers” and references to the 2005 Istanbul comeback framed the night; the crowd’s relentless noise helped crack a high-class Dortmund.  
• Anfield was awash with colour, a prolonged “You’ll Never Walk Alone”, and a perfectly observed minute’s silence for the Hillsborough anniversary.
