• Positives for Liverpool: Origi’s growing stature, Coutinho’s creativity, Can’s strong display before injury, and Klopp’s clear imprint on team and supporters. Defensive frailties, especially at left-back, remain.  
• The victory places Liverpool in a last four that also includes Sevilla, Villarreal and Shakhtar Donetsk, keeping both the Europa League trophy and Champions League qualification firmly in sight.  
• Klopp has barred players from touching the “This Is Anfield” sign until they win silverware—Thursday’s comeback supplies fresh motivation to do exactly that.

• UK Brexit Secretary David Davis met the devolved administrations in the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee and proposed monthly meetings to share analysis, creating a “two-way information flow” as Brexit talks are prepared.  
• Davis said the session was constructive and pledged to work with Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland to secure the “best deal for the whole UK.”  
• Scottish Brexit Minister Michael Russell welcomed being involved but criticised the UK government’s continuing lack of clarity on whether it seeks to stay in the EU single market or customs union, stressing that single-market membership is “essential” for Scotland.  
• The UK government wants the High Court ruling on triggering Article 50 overturned in the Supreme Court, but the Scottish government will oppose this, with Lord Advocate James Wolffe applying to be heard in the appeal.

Thirteen cloned sheep at the University of Nottingham—including Daisy, Debbie, Denise and Diane, all cloned from the same adult ewe as Dolly—are being intensively studied to see whether cloning accelerates aging. Led by developmental biologist Kevin Sinclair, the team conducts regular physical exams, joint X-rays and full-body fMRI scans, tracking cardiovascular disease, diabetes and osteoarthritis—the illnesses most linked to aging. Dolly’s early death at 6½ and her arthritis prompted the study; scientists want to know if “age-memory” carried over from adult donor cells makes clones age prematurely. Approaching nine to ten years old, all the cloned sheep currently appear healthy, and full results will be released next week.

• York’s Musidora Stakes: Unbeaten Shutter Speed (trainer John Gosden, jockey Frankie Dettori) won as 4-7 favourite, beating Vintage Folly by 1¾ lengths on very soft ground; it was the fifth Musidora success for the Gosden–Dettori partnership.  
• Target plans: Shutter Speed will skip the Epsom Oaks and head to the French Oaks at Chantilly, while Gosden keeps Enable and Coronet for Epsom.  
• Duke of York Stakes: Tasleet (14-1), trained by William Haggas and ridden by Jim Crowley, scored comfortably from Magical Memory and Comicas.  
• Future runners: Gosden will inspect conditions before deciding whether Derby hope Cracksman contests Thursday’s Dante Stakes, with concern over the soft going and the short 16-day gap to the Derby.

• Sterling wobbled: it fell against major currencies, briefly recovered mid-afternoon, then slipped again, ending 0.2 % lower at $1.4226, 0.6 % lower at €1.2605 and 1 % down against the yen (≈151).  
• Market nerves: the volatility index jumped to heights last seen in 2008 as new polls, 10 days before the EU referendum, showed the Leave camp ahead; Betfair cut the implied Remain probability to 68.5 % from almost 80 %.  
• Analysts expect every fresh poll to move the pound; hedge funds are short-selling sterling and traders say the currency has lost more than 2 % in two sessions, revisiting April lows.  
• Global knock-on: Japan’s Nikkei fell 3.5 % and Hong Kong’s main index 2.5 %. London’s FTSE 100 slipped 1.1 % to 6,044.9, led by a 4.2 % drop in Lloyds.  
• Leave figures argue the pound is merely back at March levels and say a weaker currency aids exporters; April trade data showed the UK deficit narrowing on stronger exports.

Braintree Town (the Iron) sit sixth in the National League, one point and one place below the play-off positions. After a long trip they lost to Barrow, conceding in the fifth minute; it was Braintree’s third straight defeat, while Barrow stretched their unbeaten league run to nine games. Manager Danny Cowley praised his side’s effort, called their season so far “remarkable,” and, despite the setback, said the part-time team will embrace the tough challenge ahead.

From April 2015 most planning powers in Northern Ireland will move from the central Planning Service to the new councils. Councillors will decide on applications for house builds, extensions and other local developments, adding to other new council duties such as off-street parking and tourism.  

Supporters, including Michael Corr of PLACE, say this democratises planning and lets councils shape integrated community-development plans, provided voters choose councillors who understand regeneration issues.  

Opponents, led by Friends of the Earth’s James Orr, warn of risks seen in the 1960s housing discrimination: preferential treatment, cosy developer-politician ties and opaque decision-making. They demand a strict code of conduct and full disclosure of political donations. Some politicians resist greater donor transparency, citing security concerns, while any move to open the registers rests with the Northern Ireland Secretary.

Teenie, a one-year-old cat from Niddry View in Winchburgh, was found by owner Sarah Nisbett on 14 March after being shot twice in the shoulder and once in the left back leg, forcing vets to amputate the leg. Treated by the Scottish SPCA, Teenie is now relearning to move, and the charity is appealing for information to identify the shooter. The SPCA says the case shows the urgent need for a licensing system for air guns—proposed by the Scottish government but opposed by 87 % of consultation respondents—which would restrict ownership to those with a legitimate reason and aid police in tracing irresponsible users.

Liverpool have signed 24-year-old Aston Villa striker Christian Benteke after activating his release clause, making him the club’s second-costliest purchase and their seventh addition of the summer. Benteke, who scored 49 goals in 101 Villa games and hit 15 last season after returning from an Achilles injury, joins on a long-term deal aiming “to win trophies.” His arrival follows Raheem Sterling’s £49 m departure and is intended to solve Liverpool’s goal shortage after Luis Suarez’s sale and Daniel Sturridge’s injuries; last season’s replacements Mario Balotelli and Rickie Lambert managed only three league goals. Manager Brendan Rodgers has also added forwards Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino and recalled Divock Origi. Ex-Villa boss Paul Lambert and former Liverpool striker John Aldridge back Benteke to thrive, citing his power, pace and self-belief.

A national study of 671 UK state and independent schools, commissioned by Tablets for Schools and led by researcher Barbie Clarke, shows rapid growth in classroom tablet use:

• Current use: tablets are employed in 68 % of primary and 69 % of secondary schools; 9 % already run one-device-per-pupil schemes, with academy schools the heaviest adopters.  
• Expansion: 45 % of schools not yet using tablets plan to do so soon; total school tablets are projected to double from about 430,000 in 2014 to almost 900,000 by 2016.  

Impact on learning:

• The study finds no clear, isolatable evidence that tablets raise academic attainment, although many head-teachers report improved motivation, engagement and family involvement.  
• A separate National Literacy Trust/Pearson survey indicates touch-screens can boost reading, especially for boys and children from poorer homes.

Wider context:

• Pupils’ immersion in technology is high: in 1:1 tablet schools, a quarter of secondary students call themselves internet “addicts” and about two-thirds take a connected device to bed. Ofcom data show 70 % of 5- to 15-year-olds have home access to a tablet.  
• Advocates such as Simon Mason, head of Honywood Community School, argue tablets better match modern life than laptops, giving pupils portability, instant access and a sense of trust.

Overall, tablets are spreading quickly in UK schools, but definitive links to better academic results remain unproven.

“Growing Up in the City” at the Museum of Liverpool presents 25 photographs (1880s-1990s) that chart children’s lives and the city’s social history—from street play and celebrations to child labour. Highlights include an 1887 portrait of well-to-do siblings Florence, George and Gertie Rollo in fancy-dress for a mayoral ball, and a c.1900 image of a young maid. Curated by Kay Jones, who selected the pictures from hundreds in National Museums Liverpool’s archives, the show is intended to balance happy childhood memories with harder realities. It runs until 25 September.

• Centre-back Myles Anderson, 27, has ended his Barrow deal by mutual consent to sign for their National League rivals and could face his former club on 18 February.  
• Anderson, previously with Aldershot, Exeter and clubs in Italy, is valued by Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson for his leadership qualities.  
• Striker Ruairi Keating, 21, joins the Gulls on Micky Adams’ recommendation; the move awaits international clearance.  
• Keating has played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps and is seen as young, raw but “incredibly hungry.”  
• The Gulls sit four points above the relegation zone with just one win in their last six matches.

Bolivia has enacted a child-protection and labour law that:

• Allows children as young as 12 to be formally contracted to work, provided they have parental authorisation.  
• Introduces a 30-year prison sentence for child homicide and tougher penalties for violence against minors.  
• Was approved by Congress, then signed by Vice-President Álvaro García Linera while President Evo Morales was abroad; García says it balances Bolivia’s social reality with legal and treaty obligations.  

Context and reactions:

• UNICEF estimates more than 500,000 Bolivian children already work, from shoe-shining and street vending to hazardous mining and farm labour.  
• The government hopes the measure will combat extreme poverty.  
• The International Labour Organisation, whose conventions set 14 as the minimum working age for developing countries, is examining whether the new law violates its standards.

Rosie O’Donnell, 50, suffered a severe “widow-maker” heart attack last week at her Nyack, New York, home. After feeling chest pain, nausea and fever following an act of helping a stranger, she looked up “women’s heart attack symptoms” online, took aspirin, but did not call 911. A cardiologist the next day found a coronary artery 99 % blocked and inserted a stent. In a blog poem titled “my heart attack,” she said she was “lucky to be here” and urged women to recognize symptoms and call emergency services. O’Donnell is known for roles in Drop Dead Diva, Will & Grace and Nip/Tuck, and her OWN talk show The Rosie Show was canceled in March.

• Che Labastide-Wellington, from Harrow, was fatally stabbed about 00:30 GMT in an alleyway near a party in Belvedere Way, Kenton, having earlier been at the event.  
• Police say a group of youths had tried to force entry to the well-supervised party; although Che was not involved in that initial dispute, he appears to have been targeted later.  
• He died roughly an hour after the stabbing. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and is in a stable condition in hospital.  
• Detectives are appealing for witnesses who were between Belvedere Way and Tylers Gate at the time.  
• Arrests: a 21-year-old man (murder), two boys aged 15 and 16 (murder, both bailed until mid-December), and a 14-year-old boy (possession of an offensive weapon).

Denmark overhauled its cancer-diagnosis system after data 15+ years ago showed poor survival rates linked to long waits, especially for patients with non-specific symptoms.  
New model (from 2007) gives GPs three referral routes:

1. Alarm-symptom pathway: strict fast-track targets for obvious cancers.  
2. Hospital-based “diagnosis centres”: rapid, multi-test work-ups for patients whose symptoms are concerning but unclear. By law, any physical illness must be investigated within 30 days of GP referral.  
3. “Yes-no” centres: same-day tests/scans for patients with minor symptoms that rarely, but sometimes, hide serious disease.

The system reduces GP–specialist “ping-pong,” uses existing resources without a surge in referrals, and has led to markedly improved cancer survival, allowing Denmark to catch up with other Nordic countries. A Welsh delegation has studied the approach as a potential model for similar NHS reforms.

• After the UK government abolished the Office of Fair Trading (OFT), Powys County Council won the contract to take over its estate-agency enforcement role.  
• The new Powys-based team, led by James Munro, can issue warning and banning orders to agents who act dishonestly or break estate-agent laws.  
• Local trading-standards departments will still handle complaints and prosecutions, but will refer suspected breaches of the Estate Agents Act to Powys.  
• The contract is worth £170,000 a year, and Powys hopes successful delivery will help it secure further external work.

NHS Employers has endorsed a Nuffield Trust plan to reshape the 1.3 million-strong NHS workforce so that staff such as nurses and pharmacists can take on tasks normally done by doctors. Pilot schemes already show nurses covering hospital-doctor duties and pharmacists assisting GPs, which could ease gaps in junior-doctor rotas and over-stretched GP surgeries and better suit today’s focus on managing long-term illnesses. The report says extra training funds will be essential. Supporters (report author Candace Imison and NHS Employers chief Danny Mortimer) see major gains in care quality and job satisfaction, but the BMA’s Dr Mark Porter and Unison’s Christina McAnea warn that up-skilling must not replace proper doctor training or serve as a cheap fix amid tight NHS budgets.

A crash at 03:00 GMT forced Avon and Somerset Police to close the A36 Lower Bristol Road in Bath, outside the First Bus depot at Rackfield Place. The road remained shut until 14:00 GMT, causing rush-hour disruption and delays to commuters and bus services. An investigation into the collision is under way. First Bus reports that some routes are back to normal and expects a full service by the evening commute, with managing director James Freeman thanking the public and staff for their cooperation.

Natural Resources Wales (NRW) says the planned £1.3 billion Swansea tidal lagoon would kill about 21 % of migrating salmon and 25 % of migrating sea-trout each year. Developer Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) disputes this, calling the figures “unrealistic and grossly misleading” and claiming NRW has not shared the methodology behind them; TLP’s own modelling suggests a worst-case fish mortality of about 2 %. NRW insists its assessment uses the “best available evidence,” gathered over 18 months and reviewed by independent experts. The lagoon is intended as a pilot for larger schemes at Cardiff, Newport and Colwyn Bay. A UK-government review of the project’s overall viability is awaited, while the Welsh Government remains supportive but wants an early decision from Westminster.

Northern Ireland will set up an industry-led agri-food marketing body, to be designed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB), DETI Minister Arlene Foster announced. Modeled on the Scotland Food and Drink organisation, the new body will give strategic leadership and coordinate marketing efforts across government and the private sector. The agri-food industry, which supports almost 100,000 jobs in farming, fishing, retail and distribution, is seen as central to export-led growth. Agriculture Minister Michelle O’Neill welcomed the plan but noted it could affect the roles of existing organisations, including her department, and said she would discuss the details with the AFSB.

The Woodland Trust is inviting the public to help plant thousands of saplings at Brackfield Wood, Faughan Valley, on Saturday afternoon. The site is one of four new UK woods in a four-year scheme to plant millions of native trees in memory of those who died in WW1, under the pledge “We will stand for those who fell.” Brackfield’s target is 40,000 trees, symbolising the 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who lost their lives in the war. Volunteers, asked to wear sturdy footwear, can plant the Trust-supplied saplings at the Glenshane Road site (about seven miles from Derry, with limited parking). The finished wood, enriched with wildflowers such as poppies, is intended as a lasting wildlife haven and place for reflection.

• Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year (Harrogate) went to Hilary for “Someone Else’s Skin,” a tightly-written thriller about domestic violence and honour crime featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome.  
• Judges called the book “emotionally exhausting,” powerful and atmospheric.  
• At the same ceremony, US writer Sara Paretsky received the Outstanding Contribution to Crime Fiction award for her 23-year body of work featuring Chicago PI V. I. Warshawski (played by Kathleen Turner in a 1991 film and a BBC Radio 4 drama).  
• Paretsky’s tough female protagonist was hailed as a “game changer,” and the author founded the international support group Sisters in Crime.  
• The prizes opened North Yorkshire’s annual crime-writing festival, whose shortlist was deemed “really strong” this year.

• New Zealand all-rounder Mitchell Santner (24) broke a finger in only his second Worcestershire match in 2016, derailing both his season and the county’s qualification hopes.  
• Director of cricket Steve Rhodes says the club has “unfinished business” with Santner and has re-signed him; he will rejoin the Rapids after the June 2017 ICC Trophy.  
• Santner, who debuted in Tests in 2015, is eager to return and contribute with both bat and ball.  
• Worcestershire have also secured Australian fast bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the entire 2017 season.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old British millionaire, died near Kiev in 2008 when a car with stolen plates, no lights and travelling about 75 mph struck him as he stood on a dual carriageway hard shoulder trying to hail a taxi. The driver did not brake or stop.  

At Exeter County Hall, coroner Dr Elizabeth Earland ruled the death “unlawful killing,” saying the evidence, though largely circumstantial, was “overwhelming.” Devon and Cornwall Police told the inquest that witnesses in Ukraine described the impact as deliberate. Ukrainian police closed their original inquiry but reopened it as a murder case in 2011; it remains open but is not being actively pursued.

Pring’s Ukrainian wife, Ganna “Anna” Ziuzina—19 years his junior—had returned to a restaurant for a “missing glove” moments before the crash, tried to claim his assets within days, sold his Range Rover and possessions, and stood to receive the first £200,000 of his estate. Computer records indicated she was having an affair. Pring’s family and a close lawyer friend believe the fatal hit-and-run was staged so she could inherit his money. Ziuzina, a former lap dancer who first told the family she was a teacher, declined to attend the inquest, saying she had already given statements to Ukrainian police.

• Charlie Fearns, a boy from Litherland, Merseyside, has been ill since he was three and has relapsed for a third time.

• After his first T-cell transplant failed and no further treatment is available in the UK, he must return to Seattle Children’s Hospital for more experimental T-cell therapy.

• An anonymous donor has offered to pay the entire cost of this treatment, as confirmed in an email from the hospital on Wednesday.

• Parents Sophie and Rob Fearns say they are “ecstatic,” “overwhelmed” and “extremely grateful”; the financial clearance means therapy will begin as soon as possible, with a start date expected next week.

After last month’s theft of celebrity photos from iCloud, Apple has extended its optional two-step verification system so it now also protects iCloud back-ups.  

Key points:  
• With two-step turned on, anyone logging in from a new device must supply both the account password and a four-digit code texted to a trusted phone (or sent via Find My iPhone).  
• Without the code, iCloud access and iTunes/iBooks/App Store purchases are blocked; a 14-character recovery key can be used if the trusted device is lost.  
• Previously, attackers could still download complete back-ups using Elcomsoft’s Phone Password Breaker despite two-step protection. The update stops that method; Elcomsoft’s owner Vladimir Katalov concedes there is now “no workaround.” Apple also now emails the account holder whenever a back-up download starts.  
• Katalov warns that losing or having the recovery key stolen could lock users out or let attackers cause damage.  
• Security academic Prof Alan Woodward argues two-factor authentication should be on by default, not merely recommended.  
• Apple says it will “more aggressively encourage” users to enable two-factor verification and adopt stronger passwords; CEO Tim Cook says raising user awareness is the priority.

• Billericay Town could sell a 20% stake to 30-year-old Mark Wright, though final terms are still undisclosed; The Sun says he would join the board.  
• The club sit eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points off the play-offs.  
• Wright was runner-up in 2011’s “I’m A Celebrity…” and previously played non-league football for Lewes, Crawley Town and Rushden & Diamonds.  
• Billericay were recently bought by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is willing to invest about £10,000 a week.  
• In March the club also signed 35-year-old former England defender Paul Konchesky.

• A BBC investigation into Sports Direct’s warehouse practices has prompted the Commons Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee to summon owner Mike Ashley to give evidence on staff treatment and minimum-wage compliance.  
• Chair Iain Wright MP has given Ashley until 21 March to accept one of several proposed hearing dates in Westminster; Ashley had instead invited the committee to the firm’s Shirebrook site.  
• If he refuses to attend, the committee may ask the House of Commons to consider a contempt complaint.  
• Sports Direct has not commented, though it has previously said it would review workers’ rights under Ashley’s oversight; Ashley also owns Newcastle United FC.

• Slain opposition leader Boris Nemtsov had begun a report on Russia’s role in Ukraine; after his death, colleagues headed by Ilya Yashin completed it and titled it “Putin. War.”  
• Drawing on already-published Russian and foreign sources, the  report assembles evidence that regular Russian troops, armour and commanders—not local separatists—secured all key rebel victories in Donetsk and Luhansk after Crimea’s annexation in March 2014.  
• It cites soldiers who say generals ordered them into Ukraine, notes volunteers are paid about $2,000–3,000 a month, and estimates Moscow has spent 53 billion roubles (≈$1 billion) on the conflict; promised compensation to dead soldiers’ families has largely not materialised.  
• Russia officially denies deploying its army, claiming any fighters are volunteers.  
• Only 2,000 copies of the dossier are being printed because many publishers fear handling it; the opposition plans fundraising for wider distribution but doubts how many Russians want information that challenges Kremlin narratives.  
• Yashin’s team argues President Putin orchestrated the war to revive his popularity—an effort they concede has worked, just as Nemtsov’s earlier corruption exposés and Sochi-cost reports failed to mobilise public protest.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, a 34-year-old from Wath-upon-Dearne, Rotherham, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. A post-mortem confirmed he died from head injuries. South Yorkshire Police have arrested a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman in Sheffield; both remain in custody.

• Welsh First Minister Carwyn Jones says he was neither shown nor asked to help draft the Article 50 letter and calls the UK government’s handling of devolved administrations “unacceptable.”  
• Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns replies that the contents have long been discussed, the Prime Minister has visited Wales repeatedly, and the UK government must act for the whole UK.  
• In the letter to Donald Tusk, Theresa May promises full consultation on which repatriated EU powers should stay at Westminster and which should pass to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, predicting “a significant increase in the decision-making power” of the devolved governments.  
• Exactly which powers—such as farming or regional economic aid—and whether associated funding will follow remain unclear; Jones doubts money will continue after 2020.  
• Some UK officials cite past EU spending in Wales as a reason to retain control in London, but that may now be politically harder.  
• More clarity may come in Thursday’s Great Repeal Bill white paper, but for now the list of powers to be devolved is still “something of a mystery.”

Two cars were damaged on Friday night in the Nursery Drive/Parkhead area of Newry when police officers were attacked while on duty. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin condemned the “mindless” assaults on PSNI officers and the local community. Police also urged parents to ensure they know where their children are and what they are doing.

• American Apparel’s founder and ex-chief executive, Dov Charney, was removed from the company last year after employee complaints and alleged misuse of funds.  
• In a San Francisco court filing responding to Charney’s defamation suit, the board detailed illicit emails to female staff and racially derogatory remarks, asserting he repeatedly violated sexual-harassment and anti-discrimination policies.  
• The board said it does not expect Charney ever to return, arguing no company would risk hiring him.  
• Charney’s lawyer, Keith Fink, called the filing false and an invasion of privacy meant to extort leverage.  
• Earlier this month, the company obtained a restraining order barring Charney from publicly disparaging American Apparel or trying to oust board members.

• Great Britain’s men play Greece at London’s Copper Box Arena, their sole home fixture before FIBA EuroBasket 2017.  
• The sides met earlier in Patras, where Greece won 92-64; three players from that Greek victory will be absent in London, giving GB hope of revenge.  
• Guard Teddy Okereafor, a Stratford native, says the game’s high level will help prepare the team and will excite newcomers playing in London for the first time.  
• Following the match, coach Joe Prunty’s squad heads to a four-team tournament in Poland, then opens EuroBasket in early September in Istanbul.  
• Live coverage: BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website/app, 17:30-19:30 BST.

• In January 2007 the author, a BBC reporter, covered Steve Jobs’s unveiling of the first iPhone in San Francisco.  
• By borrowing marketing chief Phil Schiller’s handset, he showed the device on the Ten O’Clock News, prompting complaints that the BBC was over-hyping a product launch.  
• On the Newswatch programme he argued that some products deserve major coverage because they can transform everyday life, comparing the iPhone (perhaps rashly, he thought then) to the Model T Ford.  
• A decade later he believes that judgement was correct: smartphones—sparked by the iPhone’s combination of functions and easy-to-use interface—have put powerful computers in more than two billion hands, up-ended industries and changed habits such as photography and instant sharing.  
• Earlier phones could take pictures or access the internet, but Jobs’s focus on a compelling user experience made people actually use those features.  
• While today companies like Amazon and Google lead with AI products, the author sees that sunny January morning as the true start of the mobile-connected era.

In Victor Avenue, Melton Mowbray (Leicestershire), five cats have died after ingesting antifreeze: seven-month-old Meereen on Monday, three other cats in the past week, and one cat two weeks earlier. Tests confirmed the toxin in all affected animals. The RSPCA says it is not yet known if the poisonings are accidental or deliberate and urges residents to check vehicles for leaks and store chemicals safely.

• Athens is calm: despite imminent VAT hikes, pension cuts, subsidy reductions, privatisations and market-opening reforms, there are no street protests.  
• Tourism is booming: Athens airport expects 25 m arrivals this year, up from 21 m.  
• Syriza is set to accept a third bailout worth €86 bn, even though the party once denounced such terms; July’s bank shutdown convinced it that “there is no alternative”.  
• Alexis Tsipras remains popular, although fiscal austerity continues and monetary austerity persists because banks are still partly closed and unable to lend.  
• The economy faces a severe squeeze that could intensify poverty and threaten retail activity.  
• The bailout will only stick if Greeks see hope; many argue this requires substantial debt relief—possibly cutting the debt burden by one-third to one-half—and creditors should avoid triumphalism while providing that relief.

• Dame Barbara Windsor’s character, Peggy Mitchell, has returned to EastEnders to reveal her cancer is back and will die in episodes airing this spring, marking Windsor’s final appearance.  
• Ross Kemp will make a short-term comeback as Grant Mitchell—his first since 2006—to reunite the Mitchell family for Peggy’s farewell.  
• Kemp, who portrayed Grant from 1990-1999 and in 2005-06, accepted the role because of his close friendship with Windsor.  
• Producers say the storyline will showcase Grant and his brother Phil (Steve McFadden) at their best as they face losing their mother.

• Lance Corporal Trimaan “Harry” Dhillon, 26, became obsessed with and stalked 24-year-old Alice Ruggles before killing her in October.  
• When police informed her parents, Sue Hills and Prof. Clive Ruggles, they immediately suspected Dhillon.  
• Dr. Hills feels guilt for previously assuring Alice the situation would be fine and for dismissing another daughter Emma’s fears that Dhillon would kill her.  
• Prof. Ruggles admits none of them, including Alice, grasped the danger despite warning signs.  
• Dhillon denied murder but was found guilty and given a minimum 22-year sentence.  
• The family has created the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness of stalking, wanting Alice remembered for her vibrant, smiling personality.

EDF’s board has approved funding for the £18 billion Hinkley Point C nuclear plant in Somerset, intended to supply about 7 % of UK electricity. Contracts were due to be signed immediately, but the UK government has unexpectedly called for a further review and will decide in the autumn, prompting EDF’s chief executive to cancel a site visit.  

Key points from the passage:  
• Financing: EDF is supplying most of the money; roughly one-third comes from Chinese investors.  
• Concerns: environmental impact, high guaranteed power price (£92.50/MWh), escalating costs, and the role of foreign state-owned investors.  
• EDF issues: heavy financial strain, a €4 billion rights issue, and senior resignations over the project’s riskiness.  
• Industry reaction: nuclear and manufacturing bodies urge a quick decision to avoid future supply and cost problems, while Greenpeace calls the project poor value and advocates more renewables.  
• Timeline highlights: nuclear proposed (2006); Hinkley approved (2013); price deal agreed (2013); China investment deal (2015); EDF board green-light (July 2016); UK government delay (July 2016).

England and Wales’ updated online divorce application includes a prominent box asking for “the name of the person your spouse has committed adultery with.”  

Key points  
• Family lawyers say naming this third party usually heightens conflict, complicates the case, and can delay proceedings by making the new partner a formal co-respondent.  
• Although Ministry of Justice guidance states there is “no obligation” to name anyone and that it is “not normally necessary,” practitioners worry people will fill the box in simply because it appears on the form.  
• Earlier forms only provided an optional space; the new wording is seen as a stronger prompt.  
• Statistics: of just over 100,000 divorces granted in 2015, 12,148 cited adultery and 46,815 cited unreasonable behaviour.  
• Lawyers report about 80 % of adultery clients initially want to name the new partner, but judges disapprove of drawing them into the case.  
• The form was redesigned to be more user-friendly for people divorcing without legal advice, yet critics fear it will instead fuel unnecessary conflict and extra costs.

• Wales’ £450 million-a-year forestry industry says government policy now favours environmental objectives—native broadleaf planting, public access and wildlife protection—over growing conifers for timber.

• Confor reports that 16,000 ha of commercial forest have disappeared since 2001; only 90 ha were replanted last year, yet 20,000 ha a year are needed to meet ministers’ long-term timber targets. Britain is already the world’s third-largest wood importer, and sawmills say they could greatly expand if supplies existed.

• About half of Welsh woodland is state-managed, half private. Some forests are hard to harvest and timber transport can trouble rural communities.

• The Welsh Government says its Glastir grants and “Woodlands for Wales” strategy aim to balance economic, environmental and social goals and is encouraging commercial investors, but Confor argues the approval system remains too slow and bureaucratic.

A boy was struck and badly injured on Bank Street in Coatbridge near Langloan Primary School at about 16:40. Emergency crews attended and took him to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where he is in a serious condition.

Russian defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko has begun presenting the Ushakov Medal—Russia’s award for naval bravery—to surviving British veterans of the WWII Arctic Convoys.  

Key points  
• The convoys ran from Britain to northern Russia, supplying the Soviet Union while enduring U-boats, air attack, ice and storms; 104 merchant ships, 16 warships and more than 3,000 Allied seamen were lost.  
• Veterans such as 91-year-old Able Seaman Charles Lewis say they were “just doing our bit,” though Churchill called the route “the worst journey on earth.”  
• Russia first offered the medal in 2012 as thanks for help that “armed us to defeat the Germans on the Eastern Front,” but the UK Foreign Office blocked it under rules banning foreign awards for actions over five years old.  
• After campaigners pressed for recognition (and Britain created its own Arctic Star in 2012), the Foreign Office made an exception; President Putin handed out the first medals in London on 16 June 2013.  
• The current ceremony fulfils Russia’s pledge to honour those convoy sailors who showed “courage in the defence of Russia and her interests.”

HM Inspectorate of Probation examined 100 unpaid-work (Community Payback) cases, interviewed 86 offenders and issued 15 recommendations. It found:

• Slow starts and poor enforcement: offenders were often delayed in beginning work and frequently excused for non-attendance; one had completed only 16 hours in 17 months.  
• Scale of the scheme: courts can impose 40–300 hours; about 70,000 offenders received such sentences in 2014.  
• Organisational failings: chaotic lifestyles, inadequate scheduling and offenders being turned away even when they arrived on time hamper delivery.  
• Missed rehabilitative potential: work is treated mainly as punishment, wasting chances to build skills and reduce re-offending, though inspectors saw some high-quality projects and positive offender attitudes.

Key recommendations include ensuring offenders start promptly, applying sanctions for absence, stopping the practice of turning punctual offenders away, and tailoring work objectives to individual circumstances.

Chief Inspector Paul Wilson called for “urgent remedial action.” The Ministry of Justice accepted all recommendations and says it is already implementing them to make community sentences tougher and more effective.

• The Sun put comedian Russell Brand on its front page, branding him a “hypocrite” for urging an economic-political “revolution” while living in an up-market London home regularly seen in his video blog, The Trews.

• While backing East London tenants outside 10 Downing Street, Brand was asked by Channel 4 News about the rent he pays; he called the reporter “a snide” and walked off.

• BBC Newsbeat could not confirm Brand’s reported plan to sue The Sun and Rupert Murdoch, but he has been tweeting rebuttals under the hashtag #TheSunLogic.

• Brand has answered the hypocrisy charge before, conceding he is “rich” and has benefited from the capitalist system, but arguing:
  – real change must be both personal and systemic;
  – sharing wealth alone is “a sweet, futile gesture” without wider reform;
  – inequality and ecological crisis remain “incontrovertible facts” his critics prefer to ignore.

Craig Venter (b. 1946) is a biologist-entrepreneur who repeatedly accelerated genetics research by pushing it into competitive, privately funded territory. 

Key points:
• After serving as a Vietnam War medic, he pursued medical studies and excelled at research.  
• At the U.S. National Institutes of Health in the 1980s he sped up gene sequencing by focusing on RNA messages and automated machines, then left in 1992 to found The Institute for Genomic Research.  
• In 1995 his team produced the first complete genome of a free-living organism (Haemophilus influenzae).  
• In 1998 he founded Celera Genomics, forcing a public-private race to sequence the human genome; both sides published in 2001.  
• Wealth from these ventures let him self-fund new projects, notably the J. Craig Venter Institute (2006) which created the first synthetic organism, nicknamed “Synthia,” after more than a decade of work (results published in Science).  
• He also led the Sorcerer II expedition to catalogue ocean microbial genomes.  

Venter is controversial for his aggressive, profit-oriented style and boasts, yet his methods have sped genomics, and he argues synthetic microbes could launch a new industrial era by replacing fossil fuels and capturing CO₂.

• Online survey (26 Feb–5 Mar) questioned ~1,000 English parents of 4-17-year-olds; 628 had children who eat school lunches.  
• 80 % of those children had tried foods at school they had never tried at home.  
• 50 % of parents said their child later asked for school-tried foods to be cooked at home.  
• Favourite vegetables: carrots, sweet-corn, peas; least liked: aubergine, chick-peas, spinach.  
• Research was commissioned by England’s School Food Trust after a Mumsnet poll suggested some parents use packed lunches because their children are “fussy.”  
• Trust and Mumsnet leaders say school meals, now governed by strict nutrition rules, expose pupils to a wider, healthier range of foods.  
• About 40 % of primary pupils in England, fewer in secondary schools, and 46 % in Scotland take school lunches.

Álvaro Morata, a 23-year-old, 6 ft 3 in striker playing for Spain at Euro 2016, left Real Madrid for Juventus in 2014 in a deal that lets Madrid buy him back for up to €30 m (£23 m). 

Key facts:
• Spain: 3 goals so far at Euro 2016.  
• Juventus (2014-16): 27 goals, two Serie A titles, two Coppa Italias, scored in the 2015 Champions League final (Juventus 1-3 Barcelona).  
• Real Madrid: Academy graduate, first-team debut at 18, 10 goals, substitute in their 2014 Champions League win.  
• Transfer interest: Previously linked with Arsenal and Chelsea.

Wilson, 30, returned to Nottingham Forest from Celtic for £2.5 million in August 2013. He made 51 appearances in this second stint, having earlier spent four seasons with Forest before joining Celtic. Released last May, he is currently without a club. His earlier career also included spells at Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the world’s third-largest retailer, is making an “orderly and efficient” exit from the US by offloading its loss-making Fresh & Easy chain to Los Angeles-based private-equity firm Yucaipa, led by Ron Burkle.  

Key points  
• About 4,000 of Fresh & Easy’s 5,000 staff will move to the new owner; roughly 50 of the 200 stores (in California, Nevada and Arizona) will close.  
• Tesco will lend the venture around £80 m and expects total disposal costs of about £150 m, part of which might be repaid.  
• If Yucaipa turns the business around, Tesco can later buy a stake.  
• The sale follows Tesco’s first annual profit decline in 20 years.

An athlete tells BBC Sport’s Nick Hope that despite early racial abuse, he persevered, briefly thought about competing for France, and is now focused on winning a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics; BBC Sport also offers a guide on starting martial arts.

• French scientists led by Marie Gardent (University of Savoie) have completed the first full inventory of French-Alpine glaciers since the 1970s, examining ~600 glaciers in the Mont Blanc, Ecrins, Belledonne, Vanoise, Ubaye and Grande Rousse – Arves massifs.  
• Using historical maps, satellite images and aerial photos—checked manually to avoid errors from debris cover and shadows—they compared present ice cover with the only previous inventory (late 1960s/early 1970s).  
• Total glacier area has fallen from about 375 km² in the late-60s/early-70s to roughly 275 km² in the late-2000s: a 26 % loss, with the shrinkage accelerating after the mid-1980s (area ~340 km² in 1985-86).  
• Retreat is uneven: southern ranges have suffered the most (Belledonne glaciers nearly gone; Ecrins retreat three times that of Mont Blanc). Northern sectors, benefiting from higher peaks, more precipitation and cloud, have fared better; La Mer de Glace has declined only slightly (31.5 km² to just over 30 km²).  
• The findings, presented at the AGU Fall Meeting, echo accelerated glacier loss seen elsewhere in the Alps.

• Scotland’s women have won all five Euro 2017 qualifiers and can virtually clinch a first‐ever major-tournament place by beating fellow unbeaten Iceland at Falkirk on Friday; the return in Reykjavik on 20 September should decide the group winner.  
• After play-off heartbreak for Euro 2013 and the 2015 World Cup, 24-year-old Bayern Munich forward Lisa Evans says another failure would be “devastating”, while veteran keeper Gemma Fay has chased qualification for 15 years.  
• Iceland, ranked 20th to Scotland’s 21st, are top seeds, but even the best six runners-up qualify automatically, leaving Scotland in a strong position.  
• Twelve of the 20-player squad now play abroad (five in England, four in Sweden, two with Seattle Reign and Evans in Germany), alongside BBC Women’s Footballer of the Year Kim Little.  
• Evans has just won the Bundesliga with Bayern, describing celebrations with men’s stars Franck Ribéry and Arjen Robben as “mind-blowing”.  
• She believes overseas experience and the growing quality of Scotland’s domestic league are raising national-team standards and hopes a large Falkirk crowd will help secure a historic finals berth.

Stuart Campbell, founder of the pro-independence Wings Over Scotland blog and former computer-games reviewer, was arrested in the west of England on Friday after a south-London woman alleged two years of online harassment. The Metropolitan Police are investigating; Campbell has been released on bail until mid-September. He says the complaint concerns non-threatening tweets that remain visible, and accuses media reports of encouraging unfounded speculation. He has announced he will post less frequently “for reasons totally outwith my control.”

PETA has asked Skegness to drop its 1908 “Jolly Fisherman” mascot—created for a Great Northern Railway “Skegness is so bracing” poster—and replace him with a fish logo reading “Skegness – A Happy Plaice.” The group says the fisherman promotes cruelty to sea animals and that a new mascot would show the resort as progressive and animal-friendly. Mayor Carl Macey welcomes ideas but believes residents view Jolly as a harmless, well-loved figure and doubts there is much appetite to remove him; the council will still consider PETA’s proposal.

Scotland comfortably defeated Georgia, running in six tries to two.  

Key points:  
• Georgia struck first through scrum-half Vasil Lobzhanidze, but Scotland replied with scores from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try (after Georgian lock Kote Mikautadze collapsed a maul and was sin-binned), Sean Maitland and Stuart Hogg to lead by the interval.  
• Hamish Watson powered over soon after half-time to extend the advantage.  
• Georgia’s pack then forced a second Lobzhanidze try from a dominant scrum and won further scrum penalties, one of which saw Scotland prop Moray Low yellow-carded.  
• Scotland finished strongly: debut scrum-half Ali Price sparked a counter-attack that ended with Hogg’s second and Scotland’s sixth try.  
• Greig Laidlaw landed all five conversions and a penalty, while Merab Kvirikashvili kicked two penalties for Georgia.  
• Head coach Vern Cotter praised Scotland’s first-half control (91 % possession at one stage) and game management.  

Final tally: Scotland six tries and a penalty, Georgia two tries and two penalties.

Widnes Vikings beat Castleford Tigers after a late scare.

Key points:
• Widnes led 14-6 at half-time through tries by Macgraff Leuluai, Patrick Ah Van and Chris Bridge; Castleford’s only first-half score came from Widnes loanee Paddy Flynn.  
• In the second half Flynn scored again, but further Widnes tries from Ah Van, Lloyd White (2) and Joe Mellor stretched the lead to 38-12.  
• Castleford then hit back with three tries in four minutes by Larne Patrick, Luke Gale and Flynn (completing his hat-trick), but Widnes held on for the win.  
• The result ends a run of nine defeats in ten for Widnes, consigns Castleford to a fourth straight home league loss, lifts Widnes to seventh place (above Wakefield) and leaves Castleford sixth, one point ahead of the Vikings.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti held at Guantanamo Bay since 2002 after being arrested in Pakistan for alleged al-Qaeda/Taliban links (which he denies), has been freed. A US Periodic Review Board ruled in July that he no longer posed “a continuing significant threat,” and he flew home on a Kuwaiti government plane; on return he must spend at least a year in a militant-rehabilitation center. Al-Odah had challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court, and Kuwait had lobbied for his release. He is the first prisoner freed since May’s Bergdahl–Taliban swap, reducing Guantanamo’s population to 148, as President Obama continues efforts to close the facility opened in January 2002.

“PPAP” (“Pen-Pineapple-Apple-Pen”) is a one-minute novelty song by DJ Piko-Taro, an animal-print-clad comic persona of Japanese entertainer Kazuhiko Kosaka. Created spontaneously, the song pairs a bouncy beat, nonsensical lyrics about merging a pen with an apple and a pineapple, and an easy dance.

First posted on Piko-Taro’s YouTube channel, the video drew over 4 million views; 9GAG’s Facebook repost exceeded 44 million. The earworm has generated both delight and irritation online, inspiring countless covers—from Japanese duo Riko & Rika to a heavy-metal take and Thai web celebrity Happy Polla—while mainstream Japanese media have largely ignored it. Viewers have likened Piko-Taro’s look to One Piece’s Borsalino, and some commentators predict he could become “the next Psy.”

• Thousands gathered at Hyde Park Corner for the dawn Anzac Day service; up to 400 then paraded to the Cenotaph for wreath-laying.  
• A separate service took place at Westminster Abbey, ending with the Australian and New Zealand national anthems.  
• Anzac Day marks the 1915 Gallipoli landings, the first major World War I action by Australian and New Zealand troops; the first London commemoration was held in 1916 with King George V.  
• Alexander Downer, Australia’s high commissioner, praised the courage and sacrifice of the Anzacs while addressing attendees and placing a wreath.  
• Veterans, serving personnel, their families, and many Australian and New Zealand expatriates joined the events, which featured prayers by schoolchildren and the three nations’ anthems.  
• The eight-month Gallipoli campaign was among WWI’s bloodiest, aimed at forcing the Ottoman Empire out of the war.

• 30-year-old striker David Clarkson re-signed for Premiership club Motherwell in July and is now set to make his St Mirren debut in Saturday’s Championship match against bottom side Alloa.  
• He hit nine goals for Dundee last season but has mostly come off the bench this term; he insists he is fully fit after regular U-20 games and hard training.  
• Clarkson has almost 400 senior appearances, two Scotland caps (one goal), and has also played for Bristol City, Brentford and Bristol Rovers.  
• St Mirren sit eighth in the Championship, seven points above Alloa, and Clarkson hopes his arrival can spark a run that lifts the club up the table.

Bernard Matthews has been sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan.  
• Unite union feared the takeover might jeopardize workers’ pensions, but talks produced guarantees that all existing agreements, including current pension arrangements, will be honored.  
• The firm’s final-salary scheme closed in 2004; employees’ alternative scheme remains unchanged.  
• Boparan plans to invest, cut costs, and use spare capacity to process chicken as well as turkey, aiming to return the business to strong profitability.

• At a council scrutiny meeting, leaders addressed serious problems with the new Cowes-East Cowes chain ferry, launched on 14 May.  
• Since launch the vessel has broken down, run aground, been suspended for crew-training issues, and damaged cars during embarkation.  
• In response, council leader Dave Stewart announced free crossings at Cowes until 2 July and ordered an external audit review of the project.  
• Local businesses, suffering loss of trade, asked about compensation; transport councillor Ian Ward said compensation “was up for discussion.”  
• Ward called the ferry a prototype with expected “teething problems,” noted that electrical faults have been fixed, ramp extensions are being built to stop vehicle scraping, and grounding issues linked to seamanship have been resolved.

• UK fishing helped fuel the pro-Brexit vote, hoping to escape the EU’s Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) and regain full control of national waters.

• A House of Lords EU Committee report says the sector (0.5 % of GDP; 12,000 fishers) must not be sidelined in Brexit talks: most UK catches come from stocks shared with EU states, most are sold into the EU, and much of the fish Britons eat is imported from the EU.

• Continued tariff-free access to EU markets will likely require concessions, including allowing some EU-flagged boats to keep fishing in UK waters.

• The report urges the UK to keep key CFP principles—science-based quotas, co-operation with neighbours—while warning that Brexit could fragment management into four separate UK regimes (England, Wales, Scotland, N. Ireland).

• Industry leaders remain upbeat, citing recent quota increases and the prospect of controlling a 200-mile exclusive economic zone; the government says Brexit is a chance to redesign fisheries management while protecting market access.

Timothy Geaney, 69, admitted taking or allowing indecent images of children between 2004 and 2014. Earlier this year Dumfries Sheriff Court gave him a community payback order, placed him on the sex-offenders register and required him to attend a sex-offender programme; most images involved partially dressed young boys posed erotically. After a General Teaching Council for Scotland hearing, which judged his conduct “fundamentally incompatible” with teaching and likely to recur, he was found unfit to teach and removed from the teachers’ register, with a two-year ban on re-applying. Geaney did not attend the hearing.

• A major fire broke out on 2 March at Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited’s Duncan Street site, disrupting train services for several days while firefighters worked.

• Although Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service had visited nine times in the past year and found the operators, Asset and Land Group, “broadly compliant” with fire-safety laws, the service warned the Environment Agency (EA) in February about potential risks to residents, transport and the environment.

• Following joint inspections, the EA first suspended the firm from taking new waste and has now revoked its environmental permit; unless the company successfully appeals, operations must cease after 7 August and all existing waste must be removed.

• Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited could not be reached for comment, and the cause of the fire is still unknown.

• Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad says Syria “is doing its best” to meet the UN-OPCW timetable for eliminating its chemical arsenal, despite missing Wednesday’s deadline to hand over all agents.

• Mekdad blames the delay on attacks by “terrorist groups,” claiming a second convoy carrying chemicals from Damascus to Latakia was twice fired on.

• Syria has declared about 1,300 tonnes of chemical weapons; only 30 tonnes (≈4%) have left the country so far.  
  – The U.S. fears the plan is slipping; Russia wants all chemicals at the coast by 1 March; the final destruction deadline is end-June.  
  – The OPCW cites security problems for the slow progress.

• Mekdad rejects U.S. criticism over army barrel-bomb use in Aleppo, insisting the government does not target civilians and saying Washington backs “terrorist elements.”

• Monitoring groups report heavy barrel-bomb casualties in Aleppo (246 dead, including 73 children, in five days; 14 more on Thursday).

• Rebels from the Islamic Front and al-Nusra Front say they have taken Aleppo’s central prison and freed hundreds; the government claims the assault was repelled, and fighting continues.

• Mekdad affirms: “Syria is committed… We shall implement on time all our obligations.”

England crushed Pakistan at Old Trafford, levelling the four-Test series 1-1 with their second-largest runs victory over Pakistan. England declared at 589-8 and 173-1; Pakistan replied with 198 and 234, the match ending inside four days.  

Key performer: Joe Root, promoted to No.3, scored 254 and an unbeaten 71 (off 48 balls), took four catches and one wicket, earning Man-of-the-Match honours. Captain Alastair Cook (105 and 76*) and pundits Michael Vaughan and Geoffrey Boycott hailed Root’s innings and England’s all-round display.  

Pakistan’s batting struggled—only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq have passed 50 in the series so far. Misbah admitted poor shot selection and low confidence.  

Next: Pakistan play a two-day warm-up at Worcestershire before the third Test starts at Edgbaston on 3 August.

Older People’s Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is launching a review of residential care in Wales.  
• She is asking residents, their families and friends to share experiences so her office can highlight both good practice and the harm caused by poor care.  
• Evidence gathered will feed into recommendations for care homes and relevant public bodies.  
• The review will assess quality of life through residents’ physical and psychological health, social relationships and the care-home environment, and will include discussions with care providers, staff and public officials.  
• Care Forum Wales backs the review’s aims but criticises the absence of anyone with direct care-home experience on the commissioner’s advisory panel.

• Paul Sheerin, 39, ex-Aberdeen midfielder and Arbroath player-manager since 2010, has been appointed to replace Neil Cooper at Aberdeen (Pittodrie) after a thorough selection process led by manager Derek McInnes.  
• Arbroath, who were relegated to League Two after finishing bottom of League One in 2013-14, agreed to release Sheerin; chairman John Christison understood his wish to return to Aberdeen.  
• Sheerin’s background: played for several Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden, earned a Scotland U-21 cap in the mid-1990s, and delivered Arbroath’s first national trophy by winning the 2011 Scottish Third Division title and promotion.

• Following Bob Bradley’s dismissal, Alan Curtis and assistant Paul Williams will lead Swansea against Bournemouth on Saturday while the club seeks a swift permanent appointment, with ex-Derby boss Paul Clement the preferred choice.  
• Curtis stresses the need for a manager capable of steering the team clear of relegation, warning that if Swansea drop into an increasingly strong Championship they may struggle to return, especially if key players leave.  
• Promoted to the Premier League in 2011 after escaping near bankruptcy and potential Football League relegation in 2003, Swansea gained praise for attractive, possession-based football.  
• Curtis believes the club has “lost a bit of the Swansea Way” since Michael Laudrup’s 2014 departure, citing frequent managerial changes and inadequate player replacements.  
• He maintains the current squad can survive and ensures new signings understand the club’s ascent, often referring them to the documentary “Jack to a King.”

Craig Venter (b. 1946) is a biologist-entrepreneur who transformed gene sequencing into a high-speed, highly competitive enterprise.

Key points

• Vietnam-war hospital duty gave him a sense of urgency and pushed him toward medicine and research.  
• At the US National Institutes of Health in the 1980s he adopted automated DNA sequencers and, by targeting messenger-RNA rather than whole genomes, greatly accelerated gene decoding.  
• Criticized by some scientists—James Watson called his early data work fit “for any monkey”—Venter left NIH in 1992 to found The Institute for Genomic Research.  
• In 1995 his team produced the first complete genome of a free-living organism (Haemophilus influenzae).  
• In 1998 he launched Celera Genomics to finish the human genome in three years, forcing a race with the publicly funded project; both published in 2001. The controversy over data access earned him wealth and notoriety.  
• With personal resources he founded the J. Craig Venter Institute (2006) to build a synthetic organism. After more than a decade of work the team reported “Synthia,” the first synthetic life form, in Science.  
• Venter also leads a global ocean-sampling expedition aboard his yacht Sorcerer II, cataloguing microbial genomes to study gene evolution and function.  
• He argues that engineered microbes could launch “a new industrial revolution,” reducing oil dependence and capturing CO₂.

Noted for outspoken self-confidence, private jets and yachts, Venter remains controversial but has repeatedly accelerated and redirected the field of genomics.

A Sutton Trust/Boston Consulting Group study says England’s apprenticeship system is weak compared with countries such as Germany.

Key findings
• Of 520,000 annual apprenticeship starts, fewer than 200,000 reach level 3 (A-level standard); 58 % are below that, and three-quarters go to people over 25 who are often already in work.  
• Only 61,000 new places are taken by young people, versus 570,000 in Germany, where 90 % are level 3.  
• Just 20 % of English employers offer apprenticeships; Germany’s figure is 51 %.  
• England has 18,000 separate vocational qualifications, Germany 330.  
• Eleven young applicants compete for each English apprenticeship place.

Recommendations
• Create up to 300,000 additional starts each year.  
• Make most of them three-year, level-3 programmes, with some four-year level-4 courses; keep level-2, two-year courses to no more than 10 %.  
• Restrict delivery to institutions with high-quality facilities and expert staff; improve careers guidance.

Reactions
• The Association of Colleges backs higher standards but says adding 300,000 places will be hard and argues some respected level-2 schemes (e.g., construction) should stay.  
• The Department for Education says reforms already demand minimum one-year duration, more English and maths, and that every apprenticeship is a paid job; further plans will be published shortly.

• British Paralympian Storey won in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing over two minutes ahead of Poland’s Anna Harkowska.  
• The 37-year-old can secure a 17th world title in Saturday’s road race and is aiming for more success at the 2016 Rio Games.  
• She is Britain’s most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals: 11 gold, 8 silver and 3 bronze across six Paralympics, including four golds at London 2012.  
• Storey holds 21 world titles in cycling and swimming.  
• She began as a swimmer, earning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics, and switched to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United’s escalating debts have led to their expulsion from the Conference Premier.  

• Debts: c. £225,000 overall, including £148,000 owed to “football creditors” and more than £70,000 in unpaid PAYE tax.  
• Deadlines: The Conference set a payment deadline of 5 June, then extended it to 6, 7, 9 and finally 12 June. The club, taken over by London businessman Tommy Agombar on 3 June, still failed to pay.  
• Outcome (10 June): Conference removed Hereford; Chester are reinstated to the Premier and Hayes & Yeading remain in Conference South.  
• Background:  
  – Fans’ trust (HUST) had offered £1 for the club and to clear debts but were rejected.  
  – Former boss Martin Foyle issued a winding-up petition over unpaid wages; he and other players have since left.  
  – Falling crowds (average 1,758 vs 3,270 in League Two five years earlier) worsened finances.  
• Effect: The last-day victory that had originally kept the Bulls up now counts for nothing; supporters and players are left “desperately sad,” but the Conference insists the club has only itself to blame.

James Milner, 30, formerly of Manchester City, is stepping away from England duty.  
Key facts:  
• Senior career: 61 caps since his 2009 debut, one goal (in a 5-0 win over Moldova in the 2014 World Cup qualifiers).  
• Tournaments: Squad member at two World Cups and two European Championships, but played only three minutes at Euro 2016.  
• Youth record: England Under-21 record-holder with 46 caps (debut in 2004).  
Milner said the choice was “common sense” and wished manager Sam Allardyce, the players, staff and supporters well.

Christopher Hogwood, pioneering conductor and scholar of the early-music movement, has died at his Cambridge home after several months’ illness. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to follow.  

Key facts:  
• Founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, directing it worldwide for about 30 years.  
• With the AAM issued 200+ recordings, including the first complete Mozart symphony cycle on period instruments; his 1980 Handel Messiah with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson was later ranked by BBC Music Magazine among the 20 greatest recordings ever.  
• Studied keyboard at Cambridge University (with Rafael Puyana and Mary Potts) and later with Zuzana Ruzickova and Gustav Leonhardt.  
• Early career: keyboard player/musicologist with the Academy of St Martin-in-the-Fields under Sir Neville Marriner; founder member of the Early Music Consort of London.  
• Held posts as artistic director of the King’s Lynn Festival and Boston’s Handel and Haydn Society, and taught at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell universities.  

Colleagues praised his generosity, scholarship and lasting influence on historically informed performance.

A Northern Ireland boy was withdrawn from mainstream school in June because he could not cope. His parents asked for a special-school place, but in September were told every South Eastern Education Board special school was full and no start date could be given. The boy’s mother quit her job to care for him; he feels isolated and does not understand why his siblings attend school while he cannot. An additional classroom assistant has now been hired at a local special school, so the family hopes he can start within weeks, but the mother fears other families will face the same capacity problem. The Education Authority declined to discuss the individual case, stating it is reviewing special-school needs and aims to have sufficient local places from 2016.

• Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is bidding to take over Newport Gwent Dragons and wants to run Rodney Parade primarily as a rugby venue.  
• Newport County, who share the ground, hold a lease with fixture priority until 2023 provided they stay in the Football League; club director Gavin Foxall insists this contract must be honoured.  
• The takeover will be decided by Newport Rugby shareholders on Tuesday, 9 May.  
• Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey says existing agreements for County and Newport Squash Club are legally protected and the WRU has been informed.  
• WRU plans to lay an artificial pitch, which would breach Football League regulations.  
• On the field, County sit two points above the League Two drop zone with two matches left; six wins in ten under caretaker Mike Flynn mean survival is possible this weekend if they win and Hartlepool lose.  
• Foxall warns relegation would be a “massive” setback for fans and the city.

• Sierra Leone has just been declared Ebola-free after the virus killed about 3,955 people there (part of 11,314 deaths across West Africa).  
• Interviewee: abducted at 15 by RUF rebels in 1991 civil war; branded with “RUF,” drugged, forced to loot and kill, witnessed brutal mutilations; eventually escaped to Freetown.  
• In jail he met preacher Richard Cole, founder of Lifeline Nehemiah, who gave him shelter, schooling and a mission to help rebuild Sierra Leone; Cole died in 2006 but the vision continued.  
• When Ebola hit in 2014 he and Lifeline colleagues turned their clinic into an anti-Ebola hub:  
  1. Education – told more than 10,000 people in local languages that Ebola was real and how to stay safe.  
  2. Relief – delivered food and supplies to about 11,000 people in urban and rural areas.  
  3. Treatment – with community help and partner agencies, set up an Ebola treatment unit that saved many lives.  
• Faced fear and suspicion (some thought Ebola was witchcraft); a pregnant victim left untreated inspired the rapid creation of the clinic.  
• He now regrets his wartime actions, believes in investing in youth and sees hope for Sierra Leone’s future.

About 80,000 Wedgwood artworks, ceramics, manuscripts, letters and photographs were due to be auctioned to cover the pottery firm’s pension debt. A public appeal, led by the Art Fund in September, met its funding target within a month, allowing the entire collection to be saved. Ownership will pass to the Victoria and Albert Museum, which will then loan the works back to the Wedgwood Museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, where they will stay on display. The Wedgwood Museum had inherited Waterford Wedgwood’s pension liabilities after the company’s 2009 collapse, went into administration in 2010, and was legally permitted in 2011 to sell the collection to reimburse the Pension Protection Fund. Administrator Bob Young, campaign supporter Tristram Hunt MP and family descendant Alison Wedgwood all hailed the rescue as vital to preserving a significant part of Britain’s cultural heritage.

• Billericay Town are eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points outside the play-offs.  
• Talks are under way for Wright to buy a 20% stake; Dan Groves says the detailed terms are still undisclosed.  
• The Sun claims the 30-year-old would also join the board as a club director.  
• Wright, runner-up on I’m A Celebrity in 2011, previously played non-league football for Lewes, Crawley Town and Rushden & Diamonds.  
• The club was recently bought by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is prepared to invest £10,000 a week.  
• In March, Billericay signed 35-year-old former England international Paul Konchesky.

Bank of England Governor Mark Carney, originally due to leave in 2018 and urged by some to stay until 2021, chose a “third way”: he will extend his term by only one year, departing in mid-2019.  

Key points  
• Purpose of the one-year extension: give markets continuity during the early Brexit negotiations while avoiding a mid-talks departure.  
• Main reason: personal—his family, especially two school-age daughters, want to return to Canada once their A-levels/GCSEs finish in 2018.  
• Not a response to political pressure, criticism of pre-referendum forecasts, or tension with Prime Minister Theresa May (who left the decision to him).  
• By 2019 the Article 50 process should be complete, after which a new governor will steer the U.K.’s post-Brexit economic path.

Blackpool 1–1 Colchester United  
• 12' – Blackpool went in front when Nathan Delfouneso crossed for Jamille Matt to tap in from close range.  
• 17' – Keeper Sam Slocombe brilliantly stopped Matthew Briggs, but from the resulting corner Kurtis Guthrie levelled for Colchester.  
• First-half stoppage – Slocombe denied George Elokobi and Guthrie then headed against the bar as Colchester pressed.  
• 75' – Blackpool’s best late chance was wasted when an unmarked Tom Aldred headed wide from a corner.  
• Injury-time – Colchester were reduced to ten men after substitute Sean Murray received a straight red card for a foul on Jim McAlister.  
Despite opportunities at both ends, the match finished all square, 1-1.

Northern Ireland charity Action Mental Health has created the “Healthy Me” programme for P6–P7 pupils to ease the stress of transfer tests and the move to secondary school. After a five-school pilot, the charity wants the interactive, emotional-wellbeing workshops introduced province-wide. Sessions teach breathing and relaxation techniques, highlight sources of support, encourage pupils to seek help, and give teachers basic training in promoting mental health. Launched at Carrick Primary School, the scheme has been welcomed by P7 teacher Helen Hamilton, who sees rising anxiety in pupils and parents over secondary transfer. Chief executive David Babington says the initiative builds coping skills for modern stresses, echoing Chief Inspector Noelle Buick’s call to strengthen young people’s resilience. Entry figures for this year’s AQE and GL transfer tests—14,681, up from 14,575 in 2015—underline the continuing pressure on pupils.

• Fawley Waterside plans to retain and convert Fawley Power Station’s 198 m chimney into the tallest visitor attraction south of The Shard, anchoring a £1 billion “merchant city” scheme.  
• The wider 300-acre redevelopment will add a marina, homes, restaurants and fast ferries to Southampton and Portsmouth; a petal-shaped glass structure will surround the chimney.  
• An outline planning application is expected later this year, with construction targeted to begin in 2018.  
• Background: the oil-fired plant on the west side of Southampton Water opened in 1971, generated 2,000 MW—enough for one million homes—contained 1,100 miles of cabling, and closed in 2013 before its sale in 2016.  
• Developer Aldred Drummond says preserving the chimney offers a cost-effective landmark, likening it to Brighton’s i360 and Portsmouth’s Spinnaker Tower.

• At the Track Cycling World Championships in Hong Kong, 23-year-old Chris Latham won bronze in the men’s scratch race, giving Great Britain its second medal after Elinor Barker’s earlier silver in the women’s scratch. Adrian Teklinski (Poland) took gold and Lucas Liss (Germany) silver.  
• Britain’s men’s team pursuit squad lost the bronze-medal ride-off to Italy. The women’s quartet of Barker, Emily Nelson, Manon Lloyd and Ellie Dickinson placed fifth in qualifying and missed the medal rounds.  
• Joe Truman was eliminated in the men’s keirin semi-final.  
• Katy Marchant, Britain’s sole female sprinter, qualified 16th in the women’s sprint but went out in the first round to China’s Lin Junhong; she still has the 500 m time trial and keirin to come.  
• Commentators Chris Boardman and Sir Chris Hoy praised Latham’s well-timed final sprint, while Barker and Joanna Rowsell Shand highlighted the young women’s pursuit team’s long-term potential.

Ross Kemp will make a short-term return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell, a role he played from 1990-1999 and again in 2005-06. He is coming back to join Steve McFadden’s Phil for Peggy Mitchell’s final storyline: Peggy (played by Dame Barbara Windsor) has revealed her cancer has returned and will die in episodes airing this spring. Kemp said he could not refuse appearing in Windsor’s last episodes and looks forward to reuniting the Mitchell family on screen. Executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins called Grant’s comeback a chance to show Kemp and McFadden “at their very best.”

• At Anfield, Sadio Mané struck twice in 138 seconds, leaving second-placed Tottenham badly off the pace.  
• Manager Mauricio Pochettino said Spurs’ slow start and “lack of desire” showed “a team that is not ready to fight for the Premier League,” warning that a Chelsea win the next day and a 12-point gap would be “a big problem.”  
• Tottenham’s away form is poor: only two wins on the road since 24 September and just one victory in their last 17 away games against fellow top-six sides.  
• Pochettino admitted the side “cannot cope with the pressure” required for a title challenge.  
• Pundit Danny Murphy criticised the switch from a back three to a back four, describing Spurs’ defence as “all over the place,” noting their lack of pace and contrasting mind-set away from home, and saying improvement is needed quickly.

• In Saturday’s elections, the opposition All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governorships declared, handing the long-ruling Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) its worst setback since civilian rule began in 1999.  
• The defeat deepens the PDP’s slide after last month’s presidential loss to APC leader Muhammadu Buhari, who will be sworn in on 29 May.  
• APC captured key northern states, including Katsina, Kaduna (home of outgoing Vice-President Namadi Sambo) and Adamawa, and retained Lagos in the south-west; PDP held only eight states, largely in the south-east, and kept the oil hub Rivers.  
• Taraba’s result is pending and Imo’s vote was declared inconclusive; no elections were held in seven states.  
• Analysts say APC’s gains have turned PDP into a largely regional party, though APC still failed to take any of the five oil-producing states—an area where militant disruption could threaten federal oil revenues.  
• Voting saw 66 violent incidents, mainly in southern states, but overall was calmer than previous polls, suggesting democratic progress.  
• Observers blame PDP’s losses on defections, corruption allegations and its handling of Boko Haram, and expect the party to undergo major rebuilding under new leadership.

At this year’s Hebridean Celtic Festival (Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, 19–22 July), an augmented-reality app will let users scan onsite signs and posters to access videos, band interviews and other online content on their phones or tablets. The material will be updated before and during the event, enabling both visitors and remote audiences to view information, buy tickets and sample the festival atmosphere. Acts announced include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries and Dougie MacLean. Festival director Caroline Maclennan says the feature is intended to enhance enjoyment and global engagement with HebCelt.

• Ofsted has inspected 21 Birmingham schools linked to the alleged “Trojan Horse” plot; five, including Park View, Nansen Primary, Oldknow Academy, Golden Hillock and Saltley School, were judged “inadequate”.  
• Education minister Lord Nash has formally begun terminating the government-funding agreements for Park View School and Nansen Primary.  Park View Educational Trust could therefore be removed from running its three academies.  
• Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School face the same sanction unless they meet detailed demands by 4 July (end unequal treatment of non-Muslims, stop gender segregation, broaden the curriculum, etc.).  
• Saltley School, the only local-authority school in special measures, will get a temporary governing board while it works to improve.  
• Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw says a “culture of fear and intimidation” has emerged as some groups seek to impose a narrow, faith-based ideology; inspectors found poor safeguarding, unvetted extremist speakers and Islamic-themed assemblies at Park View.  
• An anonymous head teacher describes parents trying to undermine her during inspections, saying she almost resigned until the Trojan Horse allegations surfaced.  
• Park View Trust plans a legal challenge to Ofsted; some parents accuse inspectors of bias and want Education Secretary Michael Gove to visit the school.  
• The implicated academies must respond to Lord Nash by 4 July; final decisions on their governance and future funding will then be made by the Department for Education.

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, 38, is serving a five-year Iranian jail term for allegedly plotting to overthrow the government; the exact charges have never been disclosed. Her appeal is being heard in Tehran on Wednesday behind closed doors, with no family present and no clear timeline for a decision. Husband Richard Ratcliffe, 41, says the UK has done too little, believes his wife is a diplomatic “bargaining chip,” and is seeking a visa to visit her and their two-year-old daughter Gabriella. The child’s passport was confiscated, so she remains in Iran with grandparents and now speaks mostly Farsi. Nazanin endured solitary confinement, suicidal thoughts and a hunger strike but is reportedly stronger since leaving solitary at Christmas. Amnesty International calls her a “prisoner of conscience” and urges her immediate release; the appeal could quash, reduce or extend her sentence.

• Vinnie Barker (known as Vinnie) died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich.  
• Prosecutors say optometrist Honey Rose, 35, failed to notice his swollen optic discs and to refer him for further checks.  
• The undetected swelling was due to fluid build-up in the brain, which increased skull pressure and led to Vinnie’s death.  
• The prosecution argues that this death was preventable and that Rose’s failure was so far below acceptable professional standards that it was “criminal,” amounting to gross negligence manslaughter.  
• Honey Rose, from Newham in east London, denies the charge; the trial at Ipswich Crown Court continues.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, from Guthrie near Forfar, coerced a woman into sexual encounters with a man he found on an adult website, filmed the acts, and sent an explicit clip to the woman’s sister on Christmas Day 2014. He was convicted at Dundee Sheriff Court of coercion (Sept 2013–Sept 2014), causing the sister and father to view sexual images, and threatening or abusive behaviour. The case was sent to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing; Weatherhogg was placed on the sex-offenders register and assessed as a moderate re-offending risk. The victim said she felt blackmailed; the judge said the sentence must reflect society’s abhorrence, while the defence noted the shock of his remand.
