Afghanistan beat Ireland in the first T20 in Greater Noida, reaching 171-4 with two overs left to overhaul Ireland’s 165-5. Key contributions: Ireland – Stuart Thompson 56, Gary Wilson 41* and captain William Porterfield 39; Afghanistan – Samiullah Shenwari 56, Mohammad Shahzad 47 and Najeeb Tarakai 27. Spinner Amir Hamza took 2-23, the only bowler with multiple wickets. Porterfield admitted Ireland were 15 runs short and “didn’t quite execute” with the ball. Paul Stirling fell for a duck, and paceman Boyd Rankin missed the T20s with a back injury but should return for the ODIs starting 15 March. The sides play the second T20 at the same venue on Friday.

• Barcelona maintains it has committed no offence in Neymar’s transfer but, to avoid “divergent interpretations”, has made an extra tax payment of €13.55 m.  
• The club originally said Neymar cost €57 m (£48.6 m), yet, counting signing-on fee, wages, agents’ fees and the new tax outlay, the total cost is put at £106.8 m.  
• Neymar’s parents received £34 m of the original fee.  
• Ex-president Sandro Rosell resigned amid accusations of misappropriating money connected with the deal; he and the club are being investigated, with a judge recently allowing the inquiry to continue.  
• It is still unclear whether Barcelona’s tax payment will end the case.  
• On the pitch, Neymar has scored 7 goals in 18 La Liga games and 3 in 7 Champions League matches this season.

• David Miller (24, Jersey) and Hannah Witheridge (23, Great Yarmouth) were found dead on Koh Tao beach on 15 September; post-mortems showed Miller died from drowning and head injuries, Witheridge from head wounds.  

• Two 21-year-old Burmese migrant workers, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, have allegedly confessed; they are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape and robbery, and face a possible death sentence. Thai police say DNA from Witheridge matches the suspects and deny reports that the confessions were withdrawn.  

• A Metropolitan Police team sent to Thailand has finished reviewing the case, will return to the UK to write a report and brief the victims’ families, and has thanked Thai authorities for their cooperation.  

• The UK Foreign Office had earlier raised concerns with Thailand about DNA verification and alleged mistreatment of the suspects. The British deployment followed Thai PM Gen Prayuth Chan-ocha’s agreement with UK PM David Cameron after initially declining assistance.

Virtual reality is moving beyond entertainment and is being adopted in a range of real-world settings:

1. Public awareness 
   • The UK’s National Autistic Society produced a VR film that lets viewers experience a child’s sensory overload in a shopping centre; it toured malls, is on an app/YouTube and will be packaged for schools.  
   • Alzheimer’s Research UK’s “A Walk Through Dementia” shows how simple tasks become difficult for people with dementia.

2. Retail 
   • Ikea’s HTC-Vive kitchen app lets users walk round and customise a virtual kitchen; huge download numbers and even virtual meatballs convinced Ikea to consider in-store roll-outs.  
   • Estate agents and Westfield shopping centre use VR to preview homes and fashion collections.

3. Healthcare 
   • Surgeon Dr Shafi Ahmed live-streamed tumour surgery in VR; his start-up Medical Realities is releasing “Virtual Surgeon” to cut training costs and widen access.  
   • VR therapy has eased PTSD in U.S. soldiers and reduced spider phobia in 83 % of trial participants.

4. Education 
   • Google Expeditions lets schools take virtual field trips; its cardboard kits have just reached the UK.  
   • Evanescent Studios is piloting a Mandarin-teaching VR app that immerses pupils in Chinese settings.  
   • Economist Films notes that firms like NetDragon are testing headsets that track pupil engagement.

Although VR promises more engaging journalism, teaching, healthcare and retail experiences, high hardware and computing costs remain a hurdle, especially for schools.

• Russia opened the Su-24’s flight recorder in Moscow before media and diplomats; investigators say key flight data seems to be missing, with a full report due next week.  
• The information is needed to settle whether the jet was in Turkish or Syrian airspace when Turkish F-16s shot it down on 24 November.  
• The incident has severely strained Russia-Turkey relations:  
  – Turkey claims the warplane ignored warnings and violated its airspace;  
  – Russia insists it was over Syria, and President Putin has condemned Ankara’s actions and motives.  
• Consequences so far: the pilot was killed on the ground, the navigator rescued, a Russian marine rescuer died, a helicopter was destroyed, and Moscow has imposed sanctions—such as banning Russian package holidays to Turkey—while demanding a Turkish apology.

• Scotland’s women have won all five Euro 2017 qualifiers and face fellow-unbeaten Iceland in Falkirk on Friday; a win would virtually guarantee Scotland’s first appearance at a major finals.  
• Forward Lisa Evans – twice beaten in previous play-offs – says another failure would be “devastating” but stresses the squad are taking “step by step” toward qualification; Iceland remain the main obstacle with the return game in Reykjavik on 20 September.  
• The Scots could also qualify as one of the six best runners-up, but currently lead the group despite Iceland being top seeds and ranked one place higher (20th).  
• Twelve of the 20-player squad now play abroad (England, Sweden, USA, Germany), including BBC Women’s Footballer of the Year Kim Little; Evans has just won the Bundesliga with Bayern Munich and believes overseas experience is raising national-team standards.  
• Evans urges a large home crowd, noting fan support can be decisive.

• The Commission on Local Tax Reform, created by the Scottish government and COSLA, asked Prof Kenneth Gibb to examine worldwide local-tax systems.  
• His review says Scotland’s council tax has had fundamental flaws “from day one” and that failing to update it has deepened the problems, yet “there is no magic bullet” for reform.  
• International findings:  
  – Almost every OECD nation uses a property tax; it is stable, hard to avoid and can influence housing markets, but people are unsure if it is a wealth tax or a service charge, and it is often viewed as unfair because it ignores current income.  
  – Local income taxes are seen as fairer but leave councils with volatile revenues and little scope to adjust rates locally.  
• Reform will be complex and politically difficult.  
• The Commission will run a Scotland-wide public consultation and publish its recommendations in the autumn.  
• The Scottish government regards the present council tax as unfair and awaits the Commission’s report.

Apple has extended its opt-in two-step verification system so it now also protects iCloud back-ups, a gap believed to have let attackers steal celebrities’ photos with pirated copies of Elcomsoft’s “Phone Password Breaker.”  
Two-step verification now works as follows: after entering the normal username and password on a new device, the user must supply a four-digit code sent to a trusted phone (or via Find My iPhone); without it, access to iCloud and purchases is blocked.  A 14-character recovery key can be used if the trusted device is lost.  
Elcomsoft’s owner confirms the change stops his tool and now also triggers an email alert whenever a back-up begins downloading.  He warns recovery keys can be lost or stolen, but security researcher Prof Alan Woodward argues the bigger issue is that two-factor authentication is still optional and should be enabled by default.  
Apple says it will “more aggressively encourage” users to turn the feature on and adopt stronger passwords.

During the 23 January–22 May European-election campaign:

• UKIP, the election winner, spent £2,956,737—about 68 p per each of its 4,376,635 votes.  
• The Conservatives spent the most, £2,980,815 (≈79 p per vote).  
• Labour, which finished second, spent £1,027,339 (≈26 p per vote).  
• The Liberal Democrats spent £1,580,575; after losing 11 of 12 MEPs, their spend equated to £1.45 per vote.  
• The Green Party spent £534,249 (≈43 p per vote) and came fourth.  
• The SNP spent £267,372.  

Altogether, these six parties laid out £9,347,087, and every party except Labour spent more than they did in the 2009 European campaign.

• Centre-back Myles Anderson, 27, has terminated his Barrow deal by mutual consent to sign for their National League rivals and may face his former club on 18 February.  
• Striker Ruairi Keating, 21, joins the same side, subject to international clearance; he was recommended by ex-Port Vale boss Micky Adams and has played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps.  
• Manager Kevin Nicholson praises Anderson’s leadership qualities and Keating’s hunger.  
• The club sit four points above the relegation zone with only one win in their last six matches.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred gelding, collapsed and died from a “severe pulmonary haemorrhage” moments after narrowly defeating Thistlecrack in the Cotswold Chase on Cheltenham’s Festival Trials Day. On-course veterinary staff treated him immediately but he was pronounced dead.  

• British Horseracing Authority acting chief veterinary officer Tony Welsh said such haemorrhages are rare, can affect apparently healthy sport horses and the sport will investigate how to prevent them.  
• Although Many Clouds had occasionally overheated and shown post-race ataxia in the past, he displayed none of those symptoms on Saturday and had never previously collapsed.  
• The Oliver Sherwood-trained, Trevor Hemmings-owned horse had earlier major victories in the 2015 Gold Cup trial and 2014 Hennessy Gold Cup, and was described by Sherwood as the “horse of a lifetime.”  
• BBC racing correspondent Cornelius Lysaght stressed that reports found “no significant underlying health issues,” linking the death to the rare haemorrhage rather than his earlier overheating episodes.

At Holyrood’s final sitting before the 5 May election, several long-serving MSPs delivered valedictory speeches.  

• Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick, herself retiring, was visibly moved as Labour veteran Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond said their farewells.  
• Salmond (FM 2007-14) repeated his view that Scotland is “not divided, but diverse,” welcomed new Scotland Bill powers while arguing they fall short of referendum-time pledges, and ended with “goodbye… for now,” adding light jokes about Cheltenham and election rivals.  
• McNeil, an MSP since 1999, warned Holyrood must strengthen scrutiny and learn from Westminster’s committee system.  
• Former Scottish Conservative leader Annabel Goldie also bowed out, quipping she would miss Finance Secretary John Swinney’s “faux indignation.”

Disney’s live-action “Beauty and the Beast,” directed by Bill Condon (Dreamgirls, the last two Twilight films), starts filming at Shepperton Studios in May and opens in US cinemas on 17 March 2017.  
Cast so far:  
• Unnamed star as Mrs Potts (the teapot housekeeper).  
• Emma Watson as Belle.  
• Dan Stevens as the Beast.  
• Luke Evans as Gaston.  
• Josh Gad as Gaston’s sidekick LeFou.  
• Kevin Kline as Maurice, Belle’s father.

The Crown Prosecution Service will meet victims’ relatives in Warrington at 11:00 BST to announce whether anyone will be charged over the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, in which 96 football fans died. In January, police handed the CPS evidence on 23 suspects: 15 from Operation Resolve (examining the disaster itself) and eight from an Independent Police Complaints Commission inquiry into South Yorkshire and West Midlands Police actions afterward. Sue Hemming, head of the CPS special crime and counter-terrorism division, will deliver the decisions. Margaret Aspinall, whose son died and who chairs the Hillsborough Family Support Group, said the families want accountability and view the day with mixed emotions after a long struggle; last year’s inquests had ruled the fans were unlawfully killed.

Chelmsford Prison says there have recently been many attempts to throw contraband over its walls.  
• A nearby resident has seen packages tossed in on four occasions within two weeks and has been invited to a prison meeting about what to do if it happens again.  
• A former inmate describes the jail as “notorious,” claiming it is “flooded” with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis and alleging drones deliver items, though the Ministry of Justice (MoJ) says no drone activity has been confirmed at Chelmsford.  
• The MoJ states staff work hard to block smuggling but acknowledges further action is needed; the justice secretary has asked for additional measures.  
• Smuggling items over prison walls now carries a potential sentence of up to two years.

• Incident: On a December afternoon outside Bedford Road Lower School, Kempston, lollipop lady Sylvia Blackburn (72) was struck by a VW Golf driven by Brian Wright (55).  
• Circumstances: Traffic lights had turned red and other vehicles had stopped; Wright’s car continued and hit Mrs Blackburn as she escorted a woman and child across the road.  
• Driver’s account: Wright told Luton Crown Court he was “totally blinded by the setting sun” (about 10 minutes from sunset) and did not recall the light’s colour.  
• Consequences: Mrs Blackburn suffered serious head injuries and is now in residential care. Wright admits hitting her but pleads not guilty to causing serious injury by dangerous driving.  
• Court proceedings: Wright expressed remorse, the judge paused the hearing for five minutes so he could compose himself, and the trial is ongoing.

• Middle-distance runner Laura Muir, 24, will miss the April 2018 Commonwealth Games on Australia’s Gold Coast because her final-year veterinary medicine exams are in May.  
• She prioritises completing her degree but says she is “gutted” to lose one of the rare chances to race for Scotland.  
• Muir finished 4th in the 1500 m and 6th in the 5,000 m at the London World Championships, setting an outdoor 5,000 m personal best of 14:52.07.  
• She is considering the March World Indoor Championships in Birmingham as a possible next target, feels in good shape, and believes she still has “at least two, even three more Olympics” ahead of her.  
• In her 5,000 m race, Hellen Obiri took gold, Almaz Ayana was beaten, and Sifan Hassan placed third.

• Trevor Deely, 22, vanished while walking home from a Christmas party in Dublin in December 2000.  
• A new Garda search began Saturday in a three-acre woodland site beside the R112 in Chapelizod, near the River Liffey; it will include excavations and is expected to last weeks.  
• A six-detective team is re-examining the case; they enhanced CCTV that shows Deely speaking with a man in black outside his workplace (Bank of Ireland, Baggot Street) while retrieving an umbrella, and the same man later following him on Haddington Road.  
• The man in the footage remains unidentified; Gardaí have again appealed for him to come forward.

• Juan Martín del Potro, ranked 165 after three wrist operations and a two-year lay-off, upset Stan Wawrinka 3-6 6-3 7-6(2) 6-3 to reach Wimbledon’s third round. He sits in Andy Murray’s half of the draw and will meet either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young next.

• Nick Kyrgios (15th seed), also in Murray’s half, beat Dustin Brown 6-7(3) 6-1 2-6 6-4 6-4 in a rain-interrupted match. He faces Spain’s Feliciano López, who rallied past Fabio Fognini 3-6 6-7 6-3 6-3 6-3; the winner could meet Murray in the last-16.

• Other second-round results: 10th seed Tomas Berdych defeated Benjamin Becker 6-4 6-1 6-2, and 12th seed Jo-Wilfried Tsonga beat Juan Mónaco 6-1 6-4 6-3.

• Tunisia risked expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after sending an angry letter to CAF about the refereeing of their 2015 quarter-final defeat by Equatorial Guinea; they avoided the ban by apologising before the 31 March 2015 deadline.  
• Morocco were initially barred from the 2017 qualifiers for pulling out as 2015 hosts over Ebola fears, but the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned the CAF ban and cut their fine from US$1 m to US$50 000.  
• Both federations now say relations with CAF are repaired: Tunisia’s vice-president Maher Snoussi calls the matter “completely ironed out,” while Moroccan FA chief Fouzi Lekjaa says they are “preparing for a future full of good things.”  
• In the 2017 qualifying draw, Tunisia enter Group A with Togo, Liberia and Djibouti; Morocco enter Group F with Cape Verde, Libya and São Tomé.  
• If Tunisia reach Gabon 2017, it will mark their 13th consecutive Nations Cup appearance, a potential record.

McLaren’s story is now one of sharp contrast.  

1. Past success  
• 182 grand-prix wins (23.2% win rate), 12 drivers’ crowns and eight constructors’ titles.  
• Golden spells: 1984-85, the Honda era of 1988-92 (15 wins from 16 in 1988 with Senna & Prost) and the Mercedes–Häkkinen titles of 1998-99.  
• Last constructors’ title: 1998; last drivers’ title: Hamilton in 2008.  

2. Setbacks and scandals  
• 2007 “spygate”: stripped of constructors’ points and fined $100 m.  
• 2009 “lie-gate”: Hamilton and sporting director Dave Ryan caught misleading stewards.  

3. Current decline  
• Slide began in 2013 with a weak chassis; today the car is good but the new Honda engine is poor, so targets are only mid-grid starts and “some decent points.”  

4. Management response  
• Ron Dennis, architect of earlier dominance, returned after 2013 to revive the team.  
• He and double champion Fernando Alonso (back at McLaren since 2015) believe Honda will fix the engine next year and that McLaren will be the team to break Mercedes’ stranglehold and win “championships, plural.”  

For now, however, McLaren’s hopes rest largely on faith rather than results.

• Paramedics were called to a sudden death at Joe's Bar, Dungiven, at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014.  
• Police found customers still on the premises; till receipts showed alcohol was served as late as 04:49 BST.  
• At Limavady Magistrates Court the judge ordered the bar closed for three months.  
• License holder Colleen O'Neill (43, Kevin Lynch Park) faced two charges of allowing drinking outside licensing hours; James Thomas (44, same address) faced one.  
• The defence admitted licensing laws “were not strictly adhered to.”  
• The judge called O’Neill’s record “appalling,” noted he lacked power to jail her, fined her £3,000, and fined Thomas £1,000.

• Golden State 116, Portland 105:  
  – Stephen Curry hit 8 threes, giving him a single-season record 276 (surpassing his old mark of 272), and finished with 45 points and 9 assists.  
  – Klay Thompson added 26 points; the Warriors erased a 13-point deficit and avoided their first three-game skid of the year.  
  – LaMarcus Aldridge (27 pts, 6 reb) and Damian Lillard (20 pts, 8 ast) led the Northwest-champion Trail Blazers.

• Chicago 89, Miami 78:  
  – The Bulls overturned a 19-point halftime hole with a 39-8 third-quarter surge.  
  – Pau Gasol posted 16 points and 15 rebounds; Aaron Brooks and Taj Gibson scored 14 each, and Derrick Rose and Mike Dunleavy 12 apiece, moving Chicago back to 3rd in the East.  
  – Miami missed its first 12 shots after halftime; Hassan Whiteside had 19 points and 16 boards, but Dwyane Wade shot 4-for-20 (9 points) as the Heat were outscored 57-27 after the break, denting their playoff hopes.

YouTube free-kick specialist Bas van Velzen visited Liverpool’s Melwood training ground posing as a contest winner. Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert and Lazar Markovic expected to give him a dead-ball lesson, but soon realized he was no ordinary fan as he repeatedly bent free-kicks into the top corner. Van Velzen, who has gained online fame for such skills, enjoyed fooling the players and called the meeting “amazing.” He capped the session by revealing Balotelli’s famous “Why Always Me?” slogan, referencing the striker’s 2011 t-shirt celebration.

A Canadian study of 676 breast-cancer patients carrying BRCA mutations shows major survival gains from ovary removal (oophorectomy) in BRCA1 carriers.  

Key findings  
• 345 women had an oophorectomy a mean six years after diagnosis.  
• Overall 20-year survival for the whole group was 77.4 %.  
• In BRCA1 carriers, oophorectomy cut breast-cancer mortality by 62 % and deaths from all causes by 65 %; benefit appeared immediately and lasted 15 years.  
• Surgery within two years of diagnosis yielded a 73 % fall in mortality for BRCA1 carriers.  
• There was no significant survival advantage for BRCA2 carriers.  
• Nine ovarian-cancer deaths occurred only among women who kept their ovaries.  

Implications  
Editors and investigators conclude that oophorectomy should be discussed as part of initial treatment for BRCA1-mutation patients, especially those with oestrogen-receptor-negative tumours, while more research is urged for BRCA2 carriers.  

Context  
Angelina Jolie, who carries BRCA1, previously chose preventive double mastectomy and later oophorectomy; carriers of BRCA1 or BRCA2 face up to a 70 % lifetime breast-cancer risk and high ovarian-cancer risk.

• Around 10 a.m. on Easter Sunday in Durham, North Carolina, married couple Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were struck and killed while lingering on railroad tracks.  
• The northbound Amtrak Carolinian (train No. 80) was traveling from Charlotte to New York City on Norfolk-Southern property.  
• None of the 166 passengers were injured, though one person was treated after falling ill during the resulting 2-hour-45-minute delay; the train then continued its route.  
• An acquaintance said the Lowes may have been living in a nearby homeless camp and had previously sought help moving belongings across the tracks.  
• Durham lies about 25 miles northwest of the train’s next stop, Raleigh; the full Charlotte–New York trip normally lasts about 13½ hours.

Carlos Toro, 66, once a mid-level Medellín cartel member, fled Colombia in the 1980s and spent the next 27 years working unpaid as a top undercover informant for the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration. His intelligence helped bring down figures such as cartel kingpin Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. In return, the DEA repeatedly promised him U.S. citizenship, but never delivered. Now retired and in poor health, Toro’s last visa has expired, leaving him in the United States illegally, unable to collect Social Security and facing deportation to Colombia—where he believes he would be killed within hours. After Toro publicized his situation, the DEA refused to assist; only a former handler, agent Mike McManus, has provided him limited financial help. Toro remains in legal limbo, prepared to go into hiding if deportation proceedings begin.

• ICANN has asked U.S. and Canadian regulators to investigate Vox Populi Registry Ltd., the operator of the new “.sucks” top-level domain, after complaints that its pricing is predatory.  
• Vox Populi let trademark owners and celebrities register “.sucks” names from 30 March at about $2,499 per year (resellers around $2,000), far above typical domain prices (e.g., GoDaddy offers some for $1).  
• Companies and individuals—including YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, Yahoo, Telus Mobility and actor Kevin Spacey—have already paid to secure or remove “.sucks” versions of their names; Taylor Swift previously faced similar costs with “.adult” domains.  
• An industry advisory group (Microsoft, Verizon, eBay, others) calls the practice a “shakedown scheme,” warning that plans to open “.sucks” registrations to the public in September for $10 a year intensify the pressure.  
• If regulators deem the pricing illegal, ICANN may declare Vox Populi in breach of contract and force changes to its operations.

• In June 1988 the body of a newborn boy, wrapped in a blanket and Sainsbury’s bag, was found floating in Windmill Pit pond at Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk.  
• Police failed to identify the mother at the time; villagers paid for the unnamed baby’s burial at St Peter’s church.  
• During a routine case review in April 2014 the body was exhumed; DNA from a leg bone was run through the national database of five million samples.  
• A familial DNA match led detectives to a woman of the right age; she confessed to being the mother.  
• She said the baby was stillborn after a concealed pregnancy and that she placed the body in the pond herself.  
• Arrested on suspicion of infanticide, that charge was dropped. She remains on bail while the CPS considers counts of failing to register a birth and preventing lawful burial; police rule out foul play.  
• The boy, now named “Peter,” was re-buried on 5 June 2014—26 years to the day after his discovery—under a new headstone funded by a stillbirth support charity.  
• Detectives say the 27-year mystery was solved solely through advances in DNA profiling, and all unsolved cases continue to be periodically reviewed.

In Bath, Somerset, Kristopher Hicks, then 23, was being driven home in Michael Young’s taxi on 2 November 2010. Young, 56, wrongly assumed Hicks intended to evade the fare, refused to let him out and began driving back toward the rank, covering almost a mile at more than 20 mph. Hicks jumped from the moving vehicle, sustaining catastrophic brain injuries that have left him epileptic, disabled and reliant on 24-hour care from his mother.

At the High Court Mr Justice Edis ruled Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks. The driver must pay Hicks damages—set at roughly half the sum claimed, estimated in the hundreds of thousands of pounds—plus £250 for false imprisonment. A later hearing will fix the exact figure, and both sides may appeal.

Wednesday night storms triggered tornado sirens and several reported twisters.  
• Kansas: A tornado was spotted 6 mi northwest of Goddard, moving northeast and sparing Wichita; three more sightings occurred near Aetna in the state’s southwest.  
• Missouri: A possible tornado hit Potosi (≈70 mi from St. Louis), bringing wind damage, flooding, fallen trees, roof damage and baseball-size hail reported in nearby Farmington.  
CNN’s Chad Myers warned that nighttime tornadoes are especially deadly, and the National Weather Service expects additional storms Thursday across the Midwest, the Mississippi and Tennessee River valleys, and the southern Great Lakes region.

Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida meet in a middleweight bout in New Jersey on Saturday, with both men believing a victory should earn the next title shot.  
• Rockhold is on a three-fight win streak (most recently over Michael Bisping) and seeks a fourth since losing to Vitor Belfort.  
• He plans to “be the bull,” pressure Machida, mix takedowns, kicks and punches, and exploit what he sees as Machida’s limited ground game.  
• While showing respect for Machida’s long-time elite status, Rockhold says his broader skill-set and cardio will let him “dominate.”  
• Machida, coming off a win over CB Dollaway, counters that applying his own style and strategy can “stop Luke.” After an eight-week camp with partners such as Glover Teixeira, he feels calm, prepared and ready to capitalize on Rockhold’s weaknesses.  
Both fighters agree the winner deserves the next shot at the middleweight championship.

At Fort Pierce’s Aero Acres residential airpark, a light twin-engine Aerostar attempted to land without lowering its landing gear. The aircraft touched down on its belly, its propellers striking and scraping along the runway. Realizing the mistake, the pilot applied full throttle, took off again despite damaged propellers, and flew about 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale, where he landed safely. The pilot was 85-year-old Chris Georgaklis, who has nearly 50 years of flying experience and was traveling with his dog, Buddy. The FAA is investigating; gear-up (belly) landings are usually due to pilot oversight or, less commonly, mechanical failure.

• Manager Manuel Pellegrini says Yaya Toure’s displays have fallen below expectations this season but promises to keep backing him until the campaign ends, rejecting the idea of resting him.  
• Manchester City, looking to refresh an ageing, under-performing squad, are ready to hear summer offers for Toure, who still has two years left on a £220,000-a-week contract but insists he does not want to leave.  
• City’s title defence has unravelled (only 18 points from the last 39); defeat to West Ham on Sunday could let Liverpool close to within a point. Captain Vincent Kompany is sidelined with a muscle injury and may miss the rest of the season.  
• Goalkeeper Joe Hart admits the players have “let the manager down” yet says the squad still backs Pellegrini; the manager accepts final responsibility for team selection.  
• West Ham boss Sam Allardyce advises in-form left-back Aaron Cresswell—wanted by City and Chelsea—not to repeat the mistakes of English players such as Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair, who moved to City and rarely played.

Domenico Rancadore, a 65-year-old Sicilian mafia figure who has lived in Britain for more than two decades and was nicknamed the “Godfather of Uxbridge,” was convicted in Italy in 1999 and sentenced in absentia to seven years for Cosa Nostra membership. Arrested in London on a European Arrest Warrant in 2013, he fought extradition for 18 months. Italian law voids a prison term once more than twice its length has elapsed, so the sentence legally expired in October 2014. Italy’s Court of Appeal has now “extinguished” the sentence, prompting withdrawal of the arrest warrant; the Italian Supreme Court must still note the decision, but Rancadore is free to stay in the UK and need not attend court. Lawyers and extradition experts criticised the delay and associated costs, blaming CPS procedural errors for prolonging a case that could no longer be enforced. Rancadore’s conviction technically remains, but no prison term can now be imposed.

The Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday has a seven-runner field headed by three 7-2 co-favourites: Mr Mole (trained by Paul Nicholls, ridden by A. P. McCoy), Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre (to be ridden by Nico de Boinville for Nicky Henderson). It will be McCoy’s final ride in a Grade One race; his full retirement-day book will be set on Friday. The line-up also includes Mick Channon’s Somersby, and McCoy’s retirement announcement followed his win on Mr Mole at Newbury in February.

In 1975 nine-year-old Marcia Trimble was raped, strangled and left under a shower curtain and a child’s wading pool in a cluttered, windowless garage only 150 yards from her Nashville home; scattered cookies and her missing cookie-sale money were found at the scene. The crime remained the city’s most notorious cold case for 33 years. DNA evidence eventually identified the killer as Jerome Sidney Barrett, a repeat sex offender who had been in and out of prison since the 1970s; he was convicted of Marcia’s second-degree murder in 2009 and given a 44-year sentence.

Marcia’s mother, Virginia Trimble Ritter, had followed her late husband Charlie’s advice never to view the body or crime-scene photographs. Forty years after the murder she changed her mind, asked lead investigator Mickey Miller to show her the images, and saw them on his laptop despite his warnings. The pictures—showing Marcia’s swollen face, pulled-out hair, vomit and blood—left Ritter horrified and angry, declaring she would kill Barrett if she could. She now says she regrets waiting so long to look at the photographs and wants revenge for her daughter’s death.

World No. 1 Rory McIlroy says it is “unthinkable” he will finish his career without winning the Masters and completing the career Grand Slam. A victory at Augusta would make the 25-year-old only the sixth player—after Sarazen, Hogan, Player, Nicklaus and Woods—to win all four majors.  

McIlroy calls his 2011 Masters collapse, when a closing 80 squandered a four-shot lead, “the most important day of my career”; the failure taught him lessons that helped him win the 2011 U.S. Open, the 2012 PGA, and both the Open Championship and PGA in 2014.  

Despite just one top-10 in six Masters starts, he believes Augusta suits his game and thinks he can win there multiple times. He plans to shut out the surrounding hype, using the course as a “sanctuary,” just as he did while coping with last year’s broken engagement to Caroline Wozniacki and a costly legal dispute with his former management firm.

Online chatter this week centred on: a rare quadruple rainbow over New York photographed by Amanda Curtis; China’s new crackdown on hiring strippers for funerals; Robert Downey Jr.’s tense Channel 4 interview; the #KylieJennerChallenge lip-plumping fad; 102-year-old Alice Barker viewing film of her 1930s dance routines; a bomb-themed “prom-posal” that led to a racism dispute; Ewan McGregor cast as Lumière in “Beauty and the Beast”; Johnny Depp’s drastic look in the “Black Mass” trailer; and two inventive celebrations—a “Fresh Prince”-style pregnancy reveal and a military dad photobomb. All of these stories trended online.

• Hospital admissions: Official data show 272 children in England were hospitalised last year with brain damage caused by Foetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS). Experts warn this is likely an underestimate.  
• Scale of the problem: World Health Organisation research indicates at least 1 % of UK babies—about 7,500 a year—may suffer learning, behavioural or physical disabilities from prenatal alcohol exposure.  
• Expert view: Elizabeth Mitchell (National Organisation for FAS) says the condition is permanent, widespread and greatly under-diagnosed, arguing pregnant women should be told to avoid alcohol completely.  
• Case example: 15-year-old Niamh Brown, born with FAS, needs daily assistance and inspired her adoptive parents to found the Foetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorder Trust in 2007.  
• Associated health issues: Prenatal alcohol exposure can also cause liver, kidney and heart defects, cerebral palsy, sight loss and epilepsy.  
• Current guidance: The government advises pregnant women not to drink, but if they do, to limit intake to a maximum of two units no more than twice a week.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, 31, nicknamed “Boomerang Boy” for repeatedly re-offending and returning home, burst into Shildon Post Office and Stores, County Durham, at 8 p.m. on 15 March, waving an axe and demanding money from assistant Andrea Brighty. Shop owner Sab Dhillon rugby-tackled him to the floor, and Dhillon’s wife Sam hit McKerry twice with a baseball bat, forcing him to drop the weapon. Police arrived within minutes and arrested him. McKerry, whose criminal record dates to age 12 and includes more than 80 arrests by age 15, pleaded guilty at Durham Crown Court to attempted robbery and was jailed for six years.

Four Royal Navy sailors – Joshua Finbow (23), Craig Stoner (24), Simon Radford (31) and Darren Smalley (35) – have been charged in Nova Scotia with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault for the alleged gang rape of a woman in her early 20s during an alcohol-fuelled party at Shearwater naval base on 10 April.  

Bail was set at just over £2,000 each, with strict conditions:  
• surrender of passports and a ban on applying for new ones  
• residence on Halifax’s Stadacona naval base and prohibition on leaving Nova Scotia  
• continued employment in – and no resignation from – the Royal Navy without the court’s consent  
• no contact with the victim or six named witnesses.  

Their next court appearance is scheduled for 27 May. The offences carry penalties of up to 14 years’ imprisonment, and further charges may follow as the Canadian investigation continues.

Valerie Jackson, 35, from Las Vegas, has a four-year-old son, RJ, who is one of only about 70 people worldwide with Netherton’s syndrome, an extremely rare genetic form of ichthyosis.  
• Symptoms: from birth RJ’s skin has been bright red, scaly and easily cracked; he loses heat and moisture quickly, is prone to infection and must be covered in Vaseline or other creams several times a day and bathed only twice weekly. There is no cure, though symptoms can ease with age.  
• Misunderstanding and stigma: because his skin looks scalded, strangers often assume abuse. While applying cream in a Walmart, Valerie was surrounded by five armed police after a shopper reported her for child abuse; officers apologized when she explained. The family has also been denied entry to play centers and regularly endures taunts—mostly from adults—who think RJ has been burned.  
• Diagnosis and management: Doctors were initially unsure of the condition; Valerie identified it after joining a Facebook support group and now follows advice shared there. She and her husband Reginald, 40, continue the intensive skincare routine and defend RJ against bullying, emphasizing that, despite his appearance, he is a happy, playful child.

Protein World’s London Underground advert showing bikini-model Renée Somerfield beside the slogan “Are you beach body ready?” triggered a major backlash:

• Objections: More than 50,000 people signed a Change.org petition; the ASA has received about 216 complaints alleging promotion of unhealthy body ideals; posters were defaced and a Hyde Park protest (2 May) is being organised.

• TfL action: The ads are being removed as the firm’s three-week booking ends; TfL says it logged one formal complaint, will follow ASA/CAP advice on any future submissions, and “has zero tolerance towards graffiti.”

• Protein World response: The company insists the image is un-photoshopped, defends its “fitness” message, and has answered critics on social media with combative remarks such as “We are a nation of sympathisers for fatties.” Head of global marketing Richard Staveley told ITV’s Good Morning Britain the brand received violent threats, including a bomb threat now under police investigation, and called the campaign “fantastic.”

• Wider debate: TV presenter Susanna Reid said the advert is “anxiety-inducing”; supporters like Katie Hopkins and Samantha Brick praised it. 

• Context: UK protein-powder sales rose from £73 m in 2007 to £170 m in 2012 and are forecast to reach £358 m by 2017.

• Several rail operators will raise “unregulated” fares on 17 May, some by as much as 87 %.  
• First Great Western (FGW) will almost double the off-peak return between Charlbury (near David Cameron’s Witney constituency) and London, from £33.30 to £62.40; FGW says the change aligns the North Cotswolds route with its other services and notes cheaper advance-purchase singles could keep a return as low as £20.  
• Other examples:  
  – London Midland off-peak first-class single Crewe–Northampton: £30 → £37.  
  – Virgin anytime return Stafford–Liverpool: £26.50 → £33 (24.5 %).  
  – Virgin anytime first-class day return Manchester–Stoke: £29 → £35.30 (22 %).  
• Rail firms may adjust unregulated fares (about half their revenue) three times a year.  
• The rises come just ten days after the general election, despite Conservative and Labour pledges to freeze or cap fares.  
• Prime Minister David Cameron has written to FGW asking it to “urgently review” the increases.  
• Virgin says most affected tickets are “Virgin-trains-only” fares that remain at least 20 % cheaper than rivals and that its overall West Coast rise is 1.65 %.  
• Ticket-search site Trainsplit notes passengers will be surprised, recalling January increases of about 40 % on many anytime and off-peak returns.

• Oldham, Greater Manchester, 18 April, about 11:20 p.m.: vandals pelted newly-wed John Young’s house with stones and bricks while he and wife Elaine were writing wedding-gift thank-you cards.  
• Young, 66, a retired HGV driver and former REME soldier, opened the front door to confront them and was hit in the left eye by a brick hurled “directly” at him.  
• He suffered a forehead wound and irreparable damage to the eye; emergency surgery failed and he is now permanently blind in that eye.  
• Police say there is no known motive; it may have been yobs “messing around.” An investigation is under way and witnesses are asked to call 101.  
• Feeling unsafe, the couple—married only three weeks—plan to leave the neighbourhood for Elaine’s Southport flat.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, 25, has signed a one-year contract extension that keeps him with the county until the end of the 2016 season. He missed all of 2014 after suffering leg injuries in a road accident last April that also claimed the life of his father, Keith, and required ankle surgery. Poynton returned to action on Derbyshire’s pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi and will be available for the start of the new campaign. Elite performance director Graeme Welch praised Poynton’s resilience and form and hopes the new deal will boost his confidence.

• Five-year-old Harley Renshaw from Stretford was diagnosed last year with advanced neuroblastoma in his kidney, neck, lungs and bones.  
• Treatment: 80 days of intensive chemotherapy, surgery to remove the kidney tumour, a stem-cell transplant, and weeks of radiotherapy at Manchester’s Christie Clinic.  
• To cope with radiotherapy he decorated the immobilising face mask as a Ninja Turtle, wore a superhero costume and became a media favourite; Nickelodeon sent him Ninja Turtle gifts.  
• Doctors have now declared him cancer-free; he will attend regular check-ups.  
• Harley has received Cancer Research UK’s “Little Star” award and fronts the charity’s Kids & Teens campaign.  
• Neuroblastoma facts given: affects <100 UK children a year, mostly under five; arises in adrenal or nerve tissue, can spread widely; symptoms depend on tumour site; treatment options include surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, antibody therapy and stem-cell transplant.

Tim Sherwood says 19-year-old Jack Grealish should worry about cementing his place at Aston Villa before deciding whether to play international football for the Republic of Ireland or England. After starring in Villa’s 2-1 FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool, Grealish has both nations pursuing him, but Sherwood’s priority is his club development, advising him to “go with his heart” later—echoing the choice Nabil Bentaleb faced between France and Algeria. Sherwood praises Grealish’s confidence and ball-control, while Grealish’s father also urges him to keep performing for Villa first, calling the country choice difficult and entirely Jack’s. Grealish has represented Ireland at youth level; a final decision is expected after the season.

Private-jet owners face widely different landing charges, with some unexpectedly costly airports.  
Most expensive fees for a 767-400 (often used as a large private jet):  
1. Haneda, Tokyo – £4,559 ($6,850)  
2. Narita, Tokyo – £3,728 ($5,600)  
3. Kansai, Osaka – £3,594 ($5,400)  
4. Toronto Pearson – £3,461 ($5,200)  
5. Darwin, Australia – £3,059 ($4,600)  
6. Bristol, UK – £2,929 ($4,400)  
7. Chūbu Centrair, Nagoya – £2,863 ($4,300)  
8. Dublin – £2,729 ($4,100)  
9. LaGuardia, New York – £2,630 ($3,950)  
10. Salzburg – £2,530 ($3,800)

Private aviation is booming—2.5 million U.S. flights and 705,000 European flights in 2013, with markets worth $16.7 trillion and $15.8 trillion respectively. High-profile events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix create peak demand; example charter prices include New York–Glendale at $38,000–$54,000 round-trip and London–Cannes/Nice around £8,800 one-way. Popular regular routes cost less (e.g., Los Angeles–Las Vegas £2,890; Milan–Rome $5,880). Nevertheless, landing fees alone can run into several thousand pounds each time, underscoring the exclusive nature of private-jet travel.

• Oregon dog‐resort owner Katie Gallegos filmed her two dogs, Labrador Cooper and small pup Daisy, at a McDonald’s drive-thru.  
• While Daisy calmly licks the ice-cream cone, Cooper swallows the remainder in one bite; Gallegos says he always eats fast and therefore lets Daisy start first.  
• The clip has gone viral with 7-plus million views, prompting both amusement and criticism over giving dogs ice cream.  
• Gallegos defends the occasional treat, noting Cooper is very healthy and her previous dog lived to 19 with weekly ice-cream snacks; Daisy only gets a few licks due to her size.  
• A second viral video shows the pair at Starbucks, where Cooper similarly downs a “pup-uccino” (just whipped cream).

Gary Locke, 41, has turned his interim post into a permanent three-year appointment as Kilmarnock manager. The former Hearts boss became interim head after Allan Johnston quit in early February and has since lost only one of seven matches. He will address the media on Friday, having signed the deal alongside chairman Jim Mann.

Jessica Kemp of Eustis says Seminole County elementary staff told her they might remove or suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, because the dōTERRA essential oils (e.g., lavender, chamomile, sandalwood) she applies to his head and neck “smell” and distract classmates. After a teacher’s aide complained, the school board sent her a letter calling the oils a problem for students and staff. Kemp argues the oils keep Logan calm and focused and vows to keep using them. Lake County School District later said Logan will not be suspended, labeling the matter a “health issue.”

At about 3 p.m. on Wednesday a fire swept through the 90-unit Sandpiper beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton Beach, Hamptons. Twelve fire crews fought the blaze, but heat so intense it melted paint on neighboring buildings kept them from entering; the building eventually collapsed. Smoke and flames were visible three miles away. No cause has been confirmed, though reports suggest it may have begun near a parked car. The complex, used as seasonal residences from May to November, was completely destroyed, leaving occupants—including on-site manager Rob Taber—without possessions.

Queen Elizabeth II, 88, was seen riding her black Fell pony Carltonlima Emma in Windsor Great Park. True to habit, she wore a silk head-scarf instead of a helmet, saying helmets spoil her hair. Riding since she received a Shetland pony named Peggy at age four, the Queen has owned and bred many horses, though a knee injury has recently reduced her time in the saddle. She still oversees her Windsor stables, breeds Fell and Highland ponies at Hampton Court and Balmoral, and her grandchildren now ride some of the animals.

Fell ponies—the Queen’s current mount—are an ancient Cumbrian breed, usually black, grey or bay and about 13–14 hands high. Valued since Neolithic times, they were prized by Iron-Age Carvetii, traded by Romans (who bred them taller), used as pack animals by Vikings and Normans, hauled goods through the Industrial Revolution, and became popular family riding ponies in the 1950s.

North Brisbane neighbours argued over loud noise on Thursday night; 55-year-old Leon Yeaman was allegedly felled by a single “blind” punch from 28-year-old warehouse shift-worker Phillip Pama, who had been asleep before confronting him. Yeaman died at the scene. Pama, a married father of three with no prior violence, has been charged with manslaughter, released on strict bail (passport surrendered, 6 pm–2 am curfew, twice-weekly police reporting) and is due back in court on 18 May. Neighbours say Yeaman, a schizophrenic pensioner, was known for playing loud music and drinking.

Russian music teacher Yulia Simonova, 52, had been in a year-long affair with 15-year-old pupil Damian Vanya, showering him with gifts and money. After Vanya ended the relationship for a classmate, Simonova offered a friend 100,000 rubles (£1,400) to find a hitman to torture and murder the boy—specifying broken arms and legs, kidney damage, and a slow death so she could “finish him” herself. Police staged a sting in Shatura near Moscow: an undercover officer posed as the killer, secretly filmed the meeting, accepted expense money, and officers then arrested Simonova in her car. She is charged with attempted murder and faces up to 15 years in prison. Vanya says he is relieved and hopes “they throw away the key.”

Chelsea manager José Mourinho, 52, says he prays and “speaks with God” every day but never about football and never discusses the game with his wife, Matilde Faria. He attends church only when he feels the need, more regularly in Portugal. Mourinho, father of two, stresses a strict separation between his career and family life, asserting he is “a good family person” who tries to help others and admits to professional mistakes born of football’s competitive, emotional nature. His family, familiar with poverty, has worked with the UN World Food Programme, where Mourinho serves as an Ambassador Against Hunger. Chelsea are currently league leaders and face QPR next; earlier this season Mourinho was fined £25,000 for claiming there was a campaign against his team.

On the April 1 episode of “The Price Is Right,” former host Bob Barker, now 91, made his first appearance since retiring in 2007 after 35 years on the show. Barker opened the program, ran the “Lucky Seven” pricing game, then handed the reins back to current host Drew Carey, showing he hadn’t lost his touch despite the eight-year absence.

• Off-duty Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested around 12:30 a.m. Friday on the 3200 block of D Street SE, Washington, D.C.  
• He faces felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property after allegedly trying to break into a house.  
• The Secret Service revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave; he is assigned to the agency’s Foreign Missions Branch.  
• Baldwin was scheduled for arraignment Friday afternoon; no attorney is listed.  
• His arrest comes just two days after a separate misconduct probe of a high-ranking Secret Service supervisor, and while the inspector general is already examining a March 4 incident involving two senior officials who drove into a secure White House area after drinking.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, spotted a hungry male lion in the city’s Safari Park. Wanting to capture its “character and status,” he left his car, lay on the ground about 10 feet from the animal and shot a few photos. The camera’s shutter alerted the lion, which lunged at him; Saeed narrowly escaped by scrambling back into his car. He later admitted the encounter was so close that he would not repeat such a risk.

• March 22, an unidentified woman (estimated age 25-45) was found unconscious and later pronounced dead near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Gravesend, Brooklyn.

• She carried no ID, but had a notable right-leg tattoo: a heart with a ribbon reading “Monique,” topped by a rose (now faded; police released both a photo and an artist’s rendering).

• NYPD hopes the tattoo will help establish her identity; the cause of death is still pending the medical examiner’s report.

• Anyone with information is asked to call NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

After returning to New Zealand in 2009 with little money, Hannah and Alex bought a 1986 Hino flatbed truck and, over 18 months, turned it into a two-bedroom wood-and-steel house. The solar-powered, truck-mounted home now sits on a lot they own in Nelson. It uses solar panels for most electricity (first power bill: $25), gas for cooking and hot water, and spring water for supply; heating comes from a wood stove. The project cost about $25,000, provides near self-sufficient living for the couple and their cat, and they hope to build another someday.

• Study details: Courtney Blackwell (Northwestern University) tracked 352 kindergarten pupils across a school year in a Mid-western U.S. district, comparing three classroom set-ups—no iPads, one iPad per child, and shared iPads.

• Main finding: Children who shared iPads scored roughly 30 points higher on early-literacy tests than both pupils without iPads and those using their own device.

• Interpretation: The advantage appears to stem from the collaborative interaction that occurs when a tablet is shared, not simply from using technology.

• Implication: Schools may want to rethink tablet policies, especially in lower grades, to emphasize shared rather than individual use.

• Context: The results counter recent skepticism from a UK head-teachers’ leader about classroom technology; Blackwell will present the work at the International Communication Association’s 65th annual conference in Puerto Rico.

A piglet in Qionglai City, Sichuan, born without back legs, has learned to walk by balancing on its two front trotters. Footage on People’s Daily Online shows the piglet—nicknamed “Super Pig”—taking wobbly but successful steps while foraging and mixing with its fully-limbed littermates. Owned by farmer Ms Duan, the animal has drawn crowds from nearby villages and become an internet sensation, similar to a two-legged rabbit previously celebrated at Liuzhou Zoo in Guangxi Province.

During Sunday’s inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, front-outside tire changer Todd Phillips of Dayle Coyne Racing was struck when Francesco Dracone’s car spun leaving its pit box on lap 25. Phillips suffered a leg cut, received stitches at the infield care center and was released. Wet conditions had reduced traction throughout the race. Dracone later retired and was classified 23rd.

In Rio de Janeiro, CCTV captured Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, murdering his wife, dancer Cicera Alves de Sena (stage name Amanda Bueno), 29, just four days after their marriage. The footage shows him dragging her outside, smashing her head on concrete 11 times, punching her 10 times, then shooting her in the face five times. He later told police he acted out of jealousy of men looking at her; she danced with the troupe Jaula das Gostozuedas. Severiano fled in a neighbor’s car, crashed, and was arrested. Officers recovered four handguns, a shotgun and a bullet-proof vest from his vehicle. He has confessed and faces life imprisonment.

Sarah Wilson, 41-year-old journalist and best-selling author of “I Quit Sugar,” has revealed that severe anxiety once left her close to suicide. She says a mix of chronic stress, thyroid disease, distant family ties, and feeling isolated without a partner or children convinced her life had no purpose. Wilson now acknowledges she is “an anxious person,” has found some peace, and argues that anxiety and depression are tightly linked—calling anxiety the “new depression.” She urges recognition of this connection to address the growing number of Australian women affected; Beyond Blue notes one in three will experience anxiety, and either condition can trigger the other. (Help lines: Beyond Blue 1300 224 636; Lifeline 13 11 14.)

Elena Curtin, a 23-year-old Portland woman who was seven months pregnant at the time, struck her boyfriend’s ex-girlfriend with a crowbar in November 2014 after finding the woman shooting heroin on her bathroom toilet and refusing to leave. She was charged with second-degree assault and faced nearly six years in prison, but Multnomah County prosecutors dismissed the case just before trial, saying her actions were “completely justified” under Oregon’s law permitting force against intruders. Curtin has since given birth, moved in with her parents, and ended her relationship with the child’s father, while the ex-girlfriend—described by defense counsel as persistently harassing Curtin—reconciled with him.

Gemma, a pit bull in California, is filmed eating treats when her owner slips in a piece of broccoli. She bites it, makes a disgusted face, and spits it onto the floor. The clip jokes that the two children she lives with will hopefully still learn to like vegetables. Other videos show Gemma mostly sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC discovered that a link on its official website, meant for the defunct Young Entrepreneur Awards page, now redirected users to a pornographic site because the awards were cancelled in 2011 and the URL registration on hsbc.com.hk had lapsed. After noticing the error, HSBC removed the link, issued an apology on April 20, and emphasized it has no connection to the external site and that its online banking platform remains secure.

A fire broke out early Sunday on the first floor of a home in Clinton, Maryland. Trapped in a second-floor bedroom, 13-year-old Marcus called 911, calmly gave firefighters precise directions (“up the steps… black door to the right”), reported that his mother, step-father and older brother were also inside, and reassured his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah to “stay low” and breathe. Prince George’s County firefighter Lt. Kenny Ward reached the room, passed Marcus out a broken window to another rescuer, then gave his own gas mask to Aaliyah before bringing her out. Both children were hospitalized with non-life-threatening injuries; the three other family members escaped and were taken to MedStar. Assistant Fire Chief Alan Doubleday called Ward’s actions heroic.

Blue-fluorescent waves have been photographed at Jervis Bay on Australia’s south-east coast. Photographer Andy Hutchinson captured the “beautiful supernatural” glow, produced by millions of light-emitting plankton. The organism responsible is Noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled, carnivorous phytoplankton that feeds on diatoms and flashes blue as a defence mechanism. According to oceanographer Iain Suthers (UNSW), such blooms occur naturally in spring and autumn about 90 % of the time and pose no danger. A similar display was seen at Sydney’s Manly Beach in August 2014.

• New laboratory tests, such as EndoPredict, analyse genetic markers in a removed breast-cancer tumour to judge how aggressive it is and the likelihood of the disease returning.  
• Results are available within days; some women learn their risk of recurrence is as low as 5 %, a figure comparable to— or better than— the benefit provided by chemotherapy.  
• Because of these tests, many patients with low-risk scores can safely forego chemotherapy, avoiding side-effects like hair loss, nausea, weight change and extreme fatigue.  
• Each test costs about £2,500 and is currently mostly private, but specialists argue NHS use would be cost-effective by sparing unnecessary chemotherapy.  
• Surgeons Hemant Singhal and Professor Kefah Mokbel say the tests allow informed treatment choices instead of routinely giving chemotherapy to almost everyone.  
• Case example: 49-year-old Becca Cornford’s EndoPredict score showed only a 5 % ten-year recurrence risk, so she skipped chemotherapy after her second breast-cancer surgery.

• Since women were first allowed to serve on Royal Navy ships in 1990 (women made up about 9% of personnel in 2014), more than 25 female sailors have had to be air-evacuated from ships because they were found to be pregnant.  
• HMS Ocean alone accounted for five pregnancy “medevacs” in the past nine years; HMS Illustrious had at least one, and 18 other vessels—including HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise and HMS Richmond—also carried out emergency evacuations.  
• The Navy enforces a strict “no touching” rule at sea, so pregnancies are assumed to have begun before boarding or while sailors were on leave.  
• In a related incident, Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was flown home from HMS Portland amid allegations of a sexual relationship with a crew member; an unnamed officer replaced her and an investigation followed.  
• Similar issues occur on land operations: 99 British servicewomen were flown home from Afghanistan (2006–2013) and 102 from Iraq because of pregnancy, with 16 Afghan evacuations in 2013 and 18 in 2011. Military rules bar pregnant personnel from war zones, so they are returned on medical-evacuation flights, though routine pregnancy testing before deployment is not required.

• A small quad-copter drone (about 50 cm wide) was found on the roof of Japan’s Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s official residence in Tokyo.  
• It carried a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle holding trace amounts of radioactive cesium; the quantity was too small to harm people.  
• The incident occurred the same day a Japanese court cleared the restart of two nuclear reactors at the Sendai plant, an unpopular move after the 2011 Fukushima disaster.  
• Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga called the discovery an alarming sign of possible drone-based terrorism, especially with the Olympics and G7 summit approaching.  
• Japanese law limits drone flights near airports but not over most of Tokyo, including government buildings; authorities plan to review regulations.  
• Abe was in Indonesia at the time; police are investigating the drone’s origin.

Lu Xincai, a security guard in Zhejiang, China, brings his 84-year-old mother, who has Alzheimer’s, to work every day on the back of his motorbike. He secures them together with a sash and rides the 4 km slowly, taking about an hour. After his father died and with no one else at home—his wife works in another city and his son is at school—he feared his mother would wander off if left alone. His employer, a bank, gives her a room, and he checks on her throughout his shift. Lu says he is repaying the care she once gave him.

• A University of Washington/Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation study (American Journal of Public Health) used CDC telephone-survey data on 3.7 million U.S. adults (2005-2012) to map drinking by county.  
• Heavy drinking (women: >1 drink/day; men: >2) grew 17.2 % nationwide, almost entirely because women’s rates climbed; overall in 2012, 8 % of adults were heavy drinkers.  
• Binge drinking (women: ≥4 drinks/occasion; men: ≥5) also rose sharply: the decade-long increase among women was seven times that of men, reaching 18 % of adults in 2012.  
• County extremes, 2012: binge drinking ranged from 6 % (Madison Co., ID) to 36 % (Menominee, WI); heavy drinking from 2 % (Hancock Co., TN) to 22 % (Esmeralda Co., NV).  
• Total alcohol use (any drinking) stayed roughly level, yet alcohol caused an estimated 88,600 U.S. deaths in 2010 and costs exceeded $220 billion annually.  
• Researchers and clinicians attribute rising excess drinking to changing gender norms, growth of young affluent “work hard/party hard” populations, stagnant alcohol taxes (making drinks cheaper), increased liquor advertising ($3.45 billion in 2011), and relaxed sales regulations.

UN health experts say caesarean sections are being over-used and endangering mothers and babies. The World Health Organization argues the operation should be limited to cases of clear medical need, as it can cause infections, serious complications, disability or death and diverts healthcare funds. WHO recommends a caesarean rate of 10–15%, yet more than 25% of births in England now use the procedure—twice the early-1990s level—partly because increasing numbers of women request planned caesareans due to childbirth anxiety. A planned caesarean costs the NHS £2,369 versus £1,665 for natural birth, and up to one in ten operations lead to infection. The WHO stance conflicts with current NHS/NICE guidelines that permit caesareans even without medical justification.

Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham was arrested on April 17 in Edgartown, Martha’s Vineyard. Police say she broke a window, moved into owner Mark Conklin’s $800,000 summer home for about a week, and held a yard sale with the owners’ belongings. When Conklin discovered her sitting in his living room she claimed the house was hers, then fled in a gray Nissan pickup; officers arrested her a few hours later when she tried to re-enter. Filkins is charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property, and is due back in court May 14. Items reported missing include Crate & Barrel deck chairs and lamps, an Ethan Allen side table pair, a Weber grill, an Ann Chase lamp, two framed posters, cookware, linens, and one of Conklin’s paintings. Police ask anyone who obtained these items to return them and call 508-627-4343, noting purchasers are considered victims eligible for restitution.

Bella Crooke, from Melbourne, lost her unlocked iPhone at a friend’s birthday party. A security guard turned the phone in to Albury Police Station on the NSW-Victoria border the next morning. To locate the owner, officers used the phone to post a series of selfie photos and pun-filled status updates on Bella’s Facebook page, showing the handset in a “holding cell,” assuring it was safely “charged,” and telling Bella to set a password. The humorous posts were quickly shared by her friends. When Bella arrived at the station about 1 p.m., police recognized her from the Facebook photos and returned the phone without needing her name. She has since added a password and thanked the “boys in blue” for their good-humoured help.

At Isimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa, two male hippos were fighting when a five-day-old calf strayed between them. One combatant seized the youngster, hurled it into the air and dragged it through the water. The calf’s mother, unable to intervene effectively, watched in distress and tried attacking the aggressor’s neck, but the baby suffered fatal injuries and died hours later. Tour operator Stacey Farrell witnessed the entire incident.

A three-bedroom, 1,990 sq ft maisonette in Egerton Place, Knightsbridge, is on the market for £575,000—far below local values—because the lease expires in three years and the property needs complete modernisation. At that price the buyer is effectively paying about £191,000 a year (£15,000 a month), similar to renting. A second, larger flat nearby is listed for £595,000 on the same three-year lease.  

• Potential value after refurbishment and a full lease: £2,750–£3,000 per sq ft, putting the smaller flat at roughly £6 million and the larger at about £7.5 million.  
• Extending the lease by 90 years is expected to cost £3.35–£4.5 million, payable to the freeholder (the Wellcome Trust).  
• Such short-lease offerings in Knightsbridge are rare; agents report strong interest but warn that the apparent bargain comes with a “massive premium” for the lease extension.

• Late Friday a computer failure during Starbucks’ daily system refresh disabled point-of-sale registers in 7,000 U.S. and 1,000 Canadian company-run stores (plus Evolution Fresh and Teavana).  
• The outage began in the early evening (East Coast) / late afternoon (West Coast), stopped credit-card processing and normal sales, and led many outlets to hand out free drinks and food; others closed early to avoid the giveaway.  
• Starbucks announced the problem was fixed late Friday night and all stores should open “business as usual” on Saturday.  
• The incident triggered a burst of social-media posts from customers enjoying the windfall.  
• It occurred a day after the chain reported record quarterly revenue of $4.6 billion and a 4.4 % share-price rise to $51.50.

• Detective Constable Gareth Jones of the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit says rural West Wales – especially Ceredigion, Powys and Pembrokeshire – is being used to radicalise and train extremists who outwardly engage in “seemingly ordinary” local activities.  
• Islamic-extremist links to Wales date to 1998, when Abu Hamza allegedly sent ten followers to train in the Brecon Beacons.  
• Subsequent incidents include:  
  – 2005: 7/7 bombers Mohammad Sidique Khan and Shehzad Tanweer white-water-rafting in Bala.  
  – 2010: Cardiff men Omar Latif, Gurukanth Desai and Abdul Miah meeting conspirators in a Welsh country park while planning Mumbai-style attacks.  
  – Lee-Rigby killer Michael Adebowale studying Arabic at the European Institute of Human Sciences near Llanybydder.  
• Jones stresses terrorism is not confined to big cities and urges local communities to pass any intelligence to authorities.

A 5.68-metre juvenile female Omura’s whale, a species formally described only in 2003 and thought possibly extinct, washed up on a remote beach near Exmouth, Western Australia after Cyclone Olwyn. It is the first record of the species in WA and only the second in Australia. DNA profiling was needed to confirm the identity. Usually found in tropical waters around Indonesia, the Philippines and the Sea of Japan, Omura’s whales are noted for a sleek body, 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin. The carcass has been buried so the skeleton can later be retrieved for study and potential museum display, giving scientists valuable data to refine identification guides and map the whale’s distribution.

Texas marketing CEO Cheryl Rios posted on Facebook that Hillary Clinton shouldn’t be president because female hormones could make her “irrational” enough to start a war. The article rebuts her claim: 

• Male leaders’ testosterone has historically fueled risky decisions (e.g., Iraq) and personal scandals, while studies show women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks.  
• Rios’s view echoes persistent workplace bias. Evidence cited: boards have more men named John, Robert, William or James than women; male professors are called “geniuses,” female ones “nice.”  
• Bias, not biology, limits women, making Clinton’s path harder.  
• Equality benefits everyone—companies with more women leaders earn more, children thrive with involved fathers, marriages strengthen, and diverse teams perform better.  
• Time magazine called Clinton “biologically primed” to lead because she is post-menopausal, but credentials matter more.  
• Rios vows to move to Canada if Clinton wins, seemingly unaware Canada had a female prime minister (Kim Campbell, 1993).

The piece calls for confronting gender stereotypes so daughters can truly “be anything.”

Veteran British actor and military-history enthusiast Robert Hardy, 89, is downsizing and has consigned his personal collection of antiques to a £100,000 sale this Saturday at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in South Cerney, Gloucestershire.  
• 238 lots—more than 200 pieces he amassed over his career—will be offered, including:  
  – A hand-painted limewood 3-D diorama of the 1415 Battle of Agincourt (estimate £4,000–£6,000) commissioned by Hardy in the 1960s.  
  – A yew longbow with mother-of-pearl handle and a portrait of Hardy holding it (together up to £2,000).  
  – Early-Victorian Gillows cabinets (to £4,000), paintings, furniture, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, crystal chandeliers and dozens of books dating back to the 17th century.  

Hardy—taught at Oxford by J. R. R. Tolkien and C. S. Lewis, author of two books on the longbow and an advisor on the Mary Rose project—calls the sale “sad” but necessary.  

As an actor he is known for:  
• Siegfried Farnon in the BBC’s All Creatures Great and Small (1978–1990)  
• Numerous portrayals of Winston Churchill and of F.D. Roosevelt  
• Minister for Magic Cornelius Fudge in the Harry Potter films  

He retired from stage work after a fall two years ago but intends to continue television acting.

Florida authorities are searching for Michael Scott Shemansky, who disappeared Saturday after his 57-year-old mother, Sandra Shemansky, was found murdered in the Winter Garden home they shared. Police began looking for him when he missed a scheduled supervised visit with his son; an out-of-state relative’s well-being check led officers to discover Sandra’s body and evidence of foul play. Investigators have recovered the unidentified murder weapon but have not released the cause of death.  

Shemansky, on parole for battery on a law-enforcement officer, has bipolar disorder, a prior psychiatric commitment for a suicide attempt, and is in the midst of a contentious divorce; his wife obtained a domestic-violence injunction against him two years ago. Neighbors say recent legal paperwork and his mother’s attempts to keep him out of further trouble may have escalated tensions. He was last seen in the RV resort’s office requesting water before fleeing on foot without supplies or medication. Anyone with information should call 407-656-3636.

• The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council has awarded Eugene, Oregon, USA the 2021 IAAF World Championships.

• The Council bypassed the normal bidding process, calling it a “unique strategic opportunity” to stage the event in the United States for the first time.

• Eugene had earlier lost the 2019 World Championships bid to Doha, Qatar, but a fresh presentation convinced the IAAF it could successfully host in 2021.

• IAAF President Lamine Diack said the choice united public authorities, private partners, the U.S. Olympic Committee and broadcaster NBC, and served the global growth of athletics.

• A similar no-bid award occurred for the 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan.

• (Background note from passage: Mo Farah won the men’s 10,000 m at the 2013 Championships in Moscow.)

• Victim: 56-year-old professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, who often kept large cash winnings at his Islington flat.  
• Honey-trap: Care-assistant/aspiring model Leonie Granger, 25, met Hassan at a Mayfair casino, posed as “Rachel,” accepted gifts and cash, then left his flat door unlocked for her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson, 28, and friend Nicholas Chandler, 29.  
• Killing: Jackson and Chandler bound, kicked and beat Hassan to death and ransacked the flat, leaving with about £3,000, a TV and phone. They later filmed themselves throwing £50 notes around.  
• Convictions:  
  – Granger – manslaughter, robbery and conspiracy to falsely imprison; jailed 16 years.  
  – Jackson & Chandler – murder (life sentences, minimum 36 years), robbery, conspiracy to falsely imprison, and earlier plots to rob casinos and obtain firearms.  
• Judge William Kennedy called the attack “pitiless and wicked,” describing it as motivated by “ruthless greed.”

• Cesc Fàbregas began the season in outstanding form for Chelsea, amassing 15 Premier League assists by mid-January and seeming certain to break Thierry Henry’s single-season record of 20.  
• Since Christmas his performances have faded, a trend Barcelona had highlighted when he left, noting a habitual late-season dip.  
• In 2015 he has supplied only four assists in 15 club-and-country games and just one in his last five league matches.  
• His slump was evident in Spain’s 2-0 loss to Holland, where he captained the side yet drew a poor four-out-of-ten rating.  
• Fatigue from “playing almost every minute” is blamed; José Mourinho is concerned but still views him as vital for Chelsea’s title run-in.  
• With nine league fixtures left—six against teams he has already assisted against—Fàbregas must regain form to help secure the Premier League crown after already winning the Capital One Cup.

• West Ham are negotiating to sign 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, who impressed during a two-week academy trial and is also being courted by Belgian clubs.  
• Beckford, from Montego Bay United, is regarded as one of the Caribbean’s most promising talents.  
• Separately, West Ham announced that season tickets at their 54,000-capacity Olympic Stadium will start at £289 for the 2016-17 season, the lowest price in the Premier League.

• On 24 January at Everleigh, near Amesbury, about 15 balaclava-clad hunt saboteurs confronted the Tedworth Hunt, which was following an artificial scent.  
• Five saboteurs attacked joint master Mike Lane, 40, beating him with punches, kicks and an iron bar on a rope; he suffered concussion, broken teeth, facial swelling, memory loss and £500 in dental costs.  
• The assault was filmed, the main attacker’s face is visible on the video, and police were given the footage, a dossier naming some saboteurs and their vehicle registration numbers.  
• After three months Wiltshire Police have shelved the inquiry, citing “insufficient evidence”; the case is recorded as “undetected” unless new information emerges.  
• Lane, witnesses and hunt supporters call the decision “pathetic” and “disgraceful,” and the Countryside Alliance is pressing for a ban on face coverings to aid future prosecutions.

Adam Gadahn (aka “Azzam the American”), a 36-year-old U.S. citizen who became al-Qaeda’s chief English-language propagandist, was killed in a U.S. counter-terrorism strike in January, the White House announced. He and another American operative, Ahmed Farouq, died in what were described as separate, non-targeted operations; the raid that killed Farouq also unintentionally killed hostages Warren Weinstein (U.S.) and Giovanni Lo Porto (Italy).

Born Adam Pearlman in 1978 on a rural California farm, Gadahn converted to Islam in 1995, left the United States for Pakistan in 1998, and quickly joined al-Qaeda (using the name Abu Suhayb). After 9/11 he rose to prominence through videos—sometimes in disguise—calling for attacks on U.S., Western and Jewish targets, threatening cities such as Los Angeles and Melbourne, praising Fort Hood gunman Nidal Hasan, lauding the Benghazi consulate assault, urging lone-wolf shootings, and tearing up his U.S. passport. A 2006 federal indictment charged him with treason and material support for al-Qaeda, placing him on the FBI’s Most Wanted Terrorists list.

Documents from Osama bin Laden’s Abbottabad compound show Gadahn advising the group’s media strategy, reflecting his growing internal influence. His final video was released in September 2014, urging the overthrow of the Saudi and Pakistani governments. Gadahn was married to an Afghan woman and had at least one child; he last contacted his family in 2002.

A viral video from China features five-year-old Mai Zizhuo, who has practiced basketball since age two-and-a-half. In the clip he sinks multiple shots and dribbles two balls simultaneously without missing a beat, impressing viewers across the basketball-enthusiastic nation. Online commenters, astonished by his talent, compare their own skills unfavorably, speculate about special effects, and ask about his parents. Mai’s sudden popularity echoes China’s enthusiasm for child prodigies and follows in the wake of national basketball icon Yao Ming.

Tom O’Carroll – a former Open University information officer, leading activist in the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE) and jailed in 1981 for “corrupting public morals” – attended and supported Hacked Off’s rally in the Houses of Parliament on 25 February, chaired by comedian John Cleese.  

• PIE (founded 1974) campaigned to legalise sex with children and, with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL), pressed Parliament to lower the age of consent to ten and legalise incest; O’Carroll sat on NCCL’s gay-rights sub-committee.  
• Hacked Off, created after the phone-hacking scandal, opposes the Independent Press Standards Organisation and wants MPs to establish a statutory press regulator as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry.  
• O’Carroll’s involvement is likely to embarrass Hacked Off, though the group notes its meeting was “open to and free for all members of the public to attend.”

Bondi’s Icebergs ocean pool was emptied on Thursday so fashion label Ten Pieces could stage its Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia show. Spectators on balconies, the beach and the road watched models parade through the dry pool and along the break wall against the ocean backdrop. Ten Pieces—run by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and partner Lucy Hinckfuss—presented a monochrome, unisex capsule of ten garments designed to be worn 20 different ways, suitable from day to night. Guests enjoyed Icebergs food, Santa Vittoria drinks and warm 28 °C sunshine, while regular lap swimmers had to return to the beach.

Amir Khan, the Bolton-born boxer, spent a day at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom safari park in northern California with his wife Faryal and daughter Lamysa, where he fed a rare white tiger and posed with giraffes and sea lions.
