Earlier in the week he confirmed that his next bout will be a welterweight fight against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on 30 May, choosing this match-up over proposed fights with Kell Brook, Adrien Broner or Keith Thurman.

• Mohammed Abu Khdeir, a 16-year-old Palestinian who was beaten and burned to death by three Israelis in July, was recently added to Israel’s Mount Herzl memorial, which honors fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism.  
• His family objected, saying they were not asked and that they do not want his name “listed between soldiers of the occupation.”  
• The Israeli victims’ group Almagor also protested, calling the murder a “rogue attack” rather than terrorism and demanding the name’s removal, threatening to remove their own relatives’ names if it stayed.  
• Israel’s National Insurance Institute, which oversees the memorial, has now agreed to delete Abu Khdeir’s name; it has already been taken off the memorial’s website.  
• A court panel began hearing evidence against the three suspects in his killing in January.

A California YouTube user, Lionel Hutz, recorded his small son in the garden repeatedly trying to use the family cat as a pillow. Each time the boy lies on the cat’s belly, the cat—originally busy licking its fur—gets up and moves to a new spot, until it finally heads indoors. In a follow-up clip, the boy and cat have reconciled, with the child feeding the cat treats.

A federal police-corruption trial in Philadelphia features testimony from Robert Kushner, 32, one of more than a dozen former drug dealers called by prosecutors. Kushner told jurors undercover officers stole $81,000 and seven pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest; six ex-members of the city’s drug squad face racketeering, extortion, robbery, kidnapping and drug-dealing charges. After Kushner’s testimony, Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy in Bryn Mawr fired him from his varsity basketball coaching post, saying his past crimes—2007 drug charges later expunged, a 2008 DUI, and a 2011 arrest that led to four years’ probation—were unknown when he passed a 2010 background check. Kushner insists he never meant to mislead the school, calls the 2011 case baseless, and says he has moved beyond his “bad phase.” Defense lawyers claim the prosecution relies on “19 lying drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.”

An oil-leak explosion late Monday at the PX (paraxylene) chemical plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian, triggered a huge fire. Six people were hurt (five by flying glass) and taken to hospital. More than 600 firefighters brought the blaze under control, and no toxic spill has been reported. The plant, which makes the reportedly carcinogenic PX used in polyester production, also experienced an explosion in July 2013. Originally planned for Xiamen, the project was moved to the current, more remote site after 2007 pollution-related protests; PX plants have attracted similar demonstrations across China despite bans on public protest.

Aston Villa teenager Jack Grealish, known for wearing his socks very low and using children’s-size shinpads, says the look is a lifelong superstition and he will ignore referees who tell him to pull his socks up. After making his first Premier League start in Tuesday’s 3-3 relegation-battle draw with QPR, the Republic of Ireland U-21 international said he was pleased the manager trusted him and hopes for more starts, noting he has yet to suffer a shin injury despite his kit style.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, 22-year-old daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, is no longer in a medically induced coma but has “global and irreversible brain damage.” According to grandmother Cissy Houston and a medical source, she has shown no neurological response for nearly three months, does not react to voices or movement, and breathes through a tracheostomy. Although Bobby Brown recently told an audience she was “awake,” the family’s attorney says only that she is out of ICU, has opened her eyes, and has begun a lengthy rehabilitation; doctors expect she may live a long time, but the eventual quality of her life remains uncertain.

Russia moved to within one victory of the Fed Cup final by taking a 2-0 lead over Germany on Saturday.  
1. Svetlana Kuznetsova opened with a straight-sets win against Julia Goerges.  
2. Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova then saved a match point and defeated Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3; Pavlyuchenkova had 13 double faults while Lisicki committed 63 unforced errors.  
With three matches left on Sunday, Russia needs one more win to secure a place in the final and claim its first Fed Cup title since 2008.

• Meteorologists say another east-coast low could develop from Thursday to Saturday, bringing heavy rain and strong winds, mainly to NSW’s north-east and possibly southeast Queensland; it is expected to move faster and sit farther from the coast than last week’s system, so Sydney should see less severe conditions.  
• The NSW State Emergency Service (SES) still has 4,409 of 24,196 storm-related jobs outstanding and more than 1,000 personnel (including 200 from other states) in the field; further rain could raise floodwaters on already saturated ground and topple loosened trees.  
• The SES is particularly concerned about the Hunter region, which “has been smashed” by the previous storm, and is urging residents statewide to prepare homes and families ahead of the potential new event.

Nina Moric, the 38-year-old Croatian model who appeared in Ricky Martin’s “Livin’ la Vida Loca” video, was reported by Italian media to have attempted suicide after allegedly being found by her mother in her Milan apartment.  
Posting photos of her bruised arms to her 40,000 Instagram followers, Moric rejected the reports. She says she fainted on Saturday night because of low blood pressure, fell and hit her head, was treated in hospital, and is now resting at home. She added that her boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso—quoted in the media as confirming a suicide attempt—was in Naples at the time.  

Italian outlets also claim she tried to kill herself in 2009. Moric was previously married to famed paparazzo Fabrizio Corona (jailed for blackmail), with whom she has a son, Carlos Maria (born 2002).

A YouGov/Sunday Times poll of 2,200 people shows:

• 25 % hope the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge have a girl (3 % prefer a boy).  
• Favourite girl’s name: Diana (12 %), followed by Alice and Charlotte (9 % each).  
• Favourite boy’s name: James (13 %), with Alexander second.  
• Many social-media users also endorse naming a daughter Diana after William’s late mother.  
• 68 % support Prince William’s plan to take six weeks’ paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber struck a group of protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, at about 10 a.m. Thursday. The blast, aimed at people marching against the provincial governor, killed 17 and wounded 64, including MP Humayoon Humayoon. The Taliban denied involvement and no one else has claimed responsibility.

• After seven trophy-filled seasons at Barcelona (four La Liga titles, two Champions Leagues), 31-year-old right-back Dani Alves will leave the club this summer.  
• His agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, revealed he has rejected Barcelona’s “final” offer—a three-year extension dependent on him playing at least 60 % of matches.  
• Santana declared negotiations finished, criticising the club for waiting until April to address Alves’s contract.

Pablo Osvaldo, the 29-year-old forward on loan from Southampton who has already scored three goals in six games for Boca Juniors, told Corriere dello Sport he wants ex-team-mates Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentine club. Osvaldo says their “South-American style” would suit Boca and that La Bombonera’s fans would “go absolutely crazy” for the Italian legends, describing Pirlo as one of the world’s best midfielders and Totti as a Roma icon.

Eighteen-year-old amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson returned to routine stable duties at Paul Nicholls’s yard the morning after a dramatic double-somersault fall from favourite Merrion Square in the 4.20 p.m. race at Wincanton. The incident, viewed hundreds of thousands of times online, left him with only a cut on the nose. Ferguson, who learned what happened by watching the replay, said the fall was unavoidable, called himself lucky, and joked about taking up gymnastics after racing, while noting new Twitter followers and good-natured banter from fellow riders.

• The film “Avengers: Age of Ultron” opened this week, premiering Tuesday at Westfield London; its stars include Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth and Scarlett Johansson.  
• To mark the release, England flanker and London Wasps captain James Haskell posted an Instagram photo in full Iron Man costume, captioned with Avengers-themed hashtags.  
• Haskell’s career path:  
  – Joined Wasps in 2002, winning his first England cap in 2007.  
  – Left in 2009 for two seasons with Stade Français, then played for Japan’s Ricoh Black Rams and New Zealand’s Highlanders (12 games).  
  – Returned to Wasps in 2012, has since passed 100 club appearances and holds 57 England caps.

The spring/summer 2015 runways have put the wide-leg trouser—whether denim, cropped, printed or striped—back in the spotlight as a fresh alternative to long-dominant skinny jeans. Originating in the 1970s and revived several times since, the cut feels effortless yet can overwhelm shorter figures, so Louise Redknapp advises:

• Choose high heels that show the top of the foot to lengthen the leg.  
• Go high-waisted and floor-skimming for full-length styles; keep tops simple (knit, tee or shirt) to balance the volume.

Denim is the easiest entry point: Gucci sent vintage-wash flares down its SS15 catwalk, Topshop offers the Miller jean, and labels like Céline, Stella McCartney and Finery London provide dressier or more affordable options. The wide-leg silhouette instantly updates a wardrobe and works even when spring weather doesn’t. Poppy Delevingne recently demonstrated the look at the AW15 Chloé show.

• More than 200 University of Michigan students petitioned to stop the UMix showing of “American Sniper,” saying the film’s portrayal of the Iraq war was offensive to people from the Middle East.  
• The university briefly canceled the screening, then reversed course after a counter-petition and criticism.  
• Vice-President for Student Life E. Royster Harper admitted canceling the movie was a mistake and affirmed the school’s commitment to free expression; the film will be shown, with “Paddington” offered as an alternative.  
• “American Sniper” stars Bradley Cooper as Chris Kyle, the most lethal sniper in U.S. history, who was killed in 2013.  
• Detroit’s nearby large Arab-American community and praise from football coach Jim Harbaugh were noted in the debate.

• On 3 April on Rottnest Island (off Perth, Western Australia) two French male tourists, aged 18 and 24 and living in Cockburn Central, ignited an aerosol spray with a lighter, sending a flame onto a quokka.  
• The animal was singed but survived.  
• Detectives visited the island, questioned the men, and seized video evidence; both were evicted from the island.  
• Each has been charged with animal cruelty and is due in Fremantle Magistrates Court on 17 April.  
• Quokkas are cat-sized marsupials found mainly on Rottnest Island and Bald Island off the WA coast.

102-year-old Alice Barker, once a chorus-line dancer at New York’s Cotton Club and Café Zanzibar in the 1930s-40s alongside stars like Bill “Bojangles” Robinson and Frank Sinatra, had never seen the films made of her performances because her memorabilia was lost. Volunteers led by Mark Cantor compiled her vintage “soundies” (early music videos) and played them for her in her nursing home, allowing Barker to watch herself dance for the first time. Her reaction: “It’s just fabulous.”

A survey of 1,100 UK adults by vehicle-leasing firm OSV found:

• 31 % of men and 75 % of women have never washed their own car; only 12 % of men who have done it say they do so regularly.  
• Just 5 % have ever asked their children to wash the car for pocket money.  
• Reasons for the decline: Sunday shopping, more televised football, growth of cheap hand-wash and automated car-wash services, and large 4x4/off-road vehicles being harder to clean.  
• Holiday periods still prompt DIY cleaning; about 15 million cars were owner-washed over Easter, though 25 % did it mainly to get out of the house.  
• Highest weekly DIY wash rates: Birmingham, Chelmsford, Sheffield. Lowest: Oxford, Bath, Edinburgh.  
• Most frequently self-washed marques: Audi, Toyota, BMW; least: Range Rover, Peugeot, Mercedes.  
Spokesman Andrew Kirkley says the traditional Sunday street car-wash scene has dwindled because people have less time, cars are bigger, children are less willing, and professional wash options are cheap and plentiful.

• Martin Skrtel says Steven Gerrard, who helped him settle after his 2008 arrival, remains “one of the best players in the world” and is synonymous with Liverpool.  
• Gerrard will captain Liverpool in Sunday’s FA Cup semi-final versus Aston Villa at Wembley; a win would let him end his Anfield career in the May 30 final against Arsenal—his birthday—before joining LA Galaxy.  
• Skrtel admits Liverpool “will never be the same” without Gerrard but insists several current players can fill the void if supported.  
• Both Gerrard and Skrtel are eligible to return against Villa after completing three-match bans.

At 75, Jack Nicklaus made his first Augusta National hole-in-one, holing a 130-yard tee shot on the 4th hole during the Masters par-3 contest while playing with Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. The ace was part of a day that produced five holes-in-one (tying the 2002 record); Camilo Villegas recorded two of them but lost the contest to world No 74 Kevin Streelman in a play-off. Nicklaus, the 1963 and 1986 Masters champion and one of five men with a career Grand Slam, joked beforehand about making an ace and winning the par-3 event. Rory McIlroy can join the career Grand Slam club by winning the upcoming Masters.

• Multiple storms triggered tornado sirens across Kansas on Wednesday night, with a twister reported 6 miles northwest of Goddard, just west of Wichita.  
• The storm moved northeast, sparing Wichita but threatening other communities; additional tornado reports came from southwestern Kansas near Aetna.  
• A possible tornado also struck Potosi, Missouri, causing wind damage, flooding, roof damage and fallen trees; large hail was reported in nearby Farmington.  
• CNN severe-weather expert Chad Myers warned that nighttime tornadoes are especially dangerous and that storms could develop throughout the night.  
• More storms are forecast Thursday for the Midwest, Mississippi and Tennessee river valleys, and southern Great Lakes region.

Reserve Tulsa County deputy Robert Bates, 73, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for the April 2 shooting death of Eric Harris, whom he says he meant to stun with a Taser but mistakenly shot. A judge allowed Bates to take a family vacation to the Bahamas, drawing criticism from Harris’ family, who said it shows apathy toward the killing.  

Key dates and legal steps:  
• Preliminary hearing: 10 a.m., July 2.  
• Bates and Sheriff Stanley Glanz have apologized for the shooting.  

Contested qualifications:  
• The Harris family’s lawyer claims Bates was unqualified and benefited from donations and friendship with the sheriff; the Tulsa World reported supervisors were told to forge Bates’ training records, a charge the sheriff’s office denies.  
• Bates’ attorneys released training documents they say confirm he was properly trained.  

Other fallout:  
• Two deputies present at the arrest have been reassigned after receiving threats.

• Conor McGregor, the 26-year-old Irish fighter, is preparing to challenge José Aldo for the featherweight title in Las Vegas on July 11, Aldo’s eighth title defence.

• McGregor has added a new tattoo—a tiger’s face on his stomach—to accompany the gorilla-eating-a-heart design on his chest, sharing the image on Instagram with the message, “If you see the tiger, it’s too late. You’re food.”

• He contends that Aldo lacks his level of motivation, saying the champion “doesn’t want the belt in his presence.”

• Their rivalry intensified during a March promotional stop in Dublin when McGregor snatched Aldo’s belt before 5,000 home fans, underscoring the pair’s already fractious relationship ahead of the bout.

At a University of Technology Sydney Australian-rules function, Prime Minister Tony Abbott downed a schooner of beer in about six seconds while players chanted “skol” and “Tony.”  

• Supporters: The 50-strong crowd cheered and Health Minister Sussan Ley said there was “nothing wrong,” praising Abbott’s general fitness.  
• Critics: Cultural-studies professor Julie Robert and other anti-drinking advocates said the stunt glorified binge drinking, linked masculinity to rapid alcohol consumption, and ignored the PM’s duty to discourage risky drinking.  
• Wider reaction: Opposition leader Bill Shorten mocked Abbott good-naturedly, but Robert warned such commentary reinforces the idea that heavy drinking makes one a “true blue Aussie bloke.”  
• Context: While past leaders like Bob Hawke were famed for skolling, Robert noted public concern about binge drinking is now greater and expects leaders to set a different example.

• Indiana’s largest‐ever HIV outbreak centers on Scott County, where cases have climbed to 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positives—up from 106 a week earlier—among intravenous Opana users (the county normally sees about five cases a year).

• Governor Mike Pence authorized a 30-day emergency needle-exchange program (March 26–April 25). In its first 2+ weeks it has given out 5,322 sterile syringes to 86 participants and collected about 1,400 used ones; use has risen since a mobile unit began visiting neighborhoods.

• Health officials expect more infections as testing expands and are urging Pence to extend the exchange. He will decide early next week.

• A broader House bill, authored by Rep. Ed Clere, would let the 23 Indiana counties with the highest hepatitis-C rates (a key HIV-risk indicator) run exchanges. The House passed it 54-39; a conference committee meets Monday, but Senate leaders and Pence remain uncertain, arguing exchanges might encourage drug use.

• Since 1989 federal law bars public funding for needle programs; Pence’s order supplied no money, leaving state agencies to cover costs. Critics question the sustainability and call the exchange a proven harm-reduction, not pro-drug, strategy.

• An unnamed, Arsenal-obsessed boyfriend made his girlfriend, Saskia (@saskiaisabxlla), sit a 50-mark written “Arsenal exam” complete with multiple-choice, tables and “in-your-own-words” sections and school-style instructions such as “read every question twice” and “calculators may be used.”  
• Marking the paper in red pen he awarded her 43.5/50 – 87 % – an A grade. On the script he wrote: “Well done Saskia! As a result I will not be dumping you! (Lucky you).”  
• His feedback noted she “could have performed better on Q17,” must “learn all player positions” and understand “Tottenham are scum.”  
• Sample questions included: meaning of “FC” in Arsenal FC, nickname for Arsenal fans, name of the current manager, starting XI in their positions, 2014 FA Cup final score and winning goalscorer, top two scorers this season, why Alexis Sánchez is better than Eden Hazard, and why Arsenal are “the best team to ever grace English football.”  
• Saskia missed defender Laurent Koscielny in the XI and muddled some positions; her answer that “Hazard is a p***k” earned double marks.  
• She posted photos of the test on Twitter with a laughing-crying reaction.  
• Many users hailed the boyfriend a “legend” and called Saskia “proper GF material,” while others thought the stunt went too far, branding him a “biff-head” and saying “football fans are nuts.”

Carlos Toro, now 66, fled Colombia in the 1980s after working mid-level in the Medellín Cartel and soon became a key undercover informant for the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration. For 27 years he carried out worldwide stings that helped bring down major figures such as cocaine lord Carlos Lehder and Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. He was never paid, but the DEA repeatedly assured him he would receive U.S. citizenship.  

Retired and in poor health, Toro still has neither a green card nor a passport; his last visa expired January 1, leaving him in the country illegally and unable to collect Social Security. After he publicized his plight, the DEA refused further help, and he now faces deportation to Colombia—where he believes he would be killed within hours. Former handler DEA agent Mike McManus, who once arrested trafficker George Jung, calls the situation “government bureaucracy at its worst,” and personally gave Toro $5,000 for medical bills. Toro, prepared to go into hiding if necessary, says he only wants the citizenship he was promised.

• In Kosi Kalan, Mathura district (Uttar Pradesh), a 14-year-old girl was allegedly gang-raped by five men from her village while she went outside to relieve herself.  
• After her family reportedly urged silence, she poured kerosene over herself on Tuesday and set herself alight; her brother extinguished the flames.  
• She suffered 70 % burns and is in critical condition at Delhi’s Safdarjung Hospital.  
• All five accused men have been arrested.  

Wider context in India:  
• The case arises amid intense public anger over sexual violence. Authorities recently banned the documentary “India’s Daughter,” which examined the 2012 Delhi bus gang-rape and murder of 23-year-old student Jyoti Singh that led to nationwide protests and death sentences for four attackers.  
• Separate lynch-mob killings of suspected rapists in Nagaland illustrate growing vigilante justice linked to these tensions.

• Louis van Gaal says he is “dreaming” of a win over Manchester City in Sunday’s Old Trafford derby, which would push Manchester United toward a possible 2nd- or 3rd-place finish and likely secure a direct Champions League spot.

• Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw will both miss the match; Van Gaal insists neither has reached the fitness level he requires, despite van Persie’s own claim that he was ready.

• Most other players are available and trained on Friday, including Wayne Rooney, David de Gea, Ángel Di María, Radamel Falcao, Juan Mata and Ander Herrera.

• Van Gaal stresses the need to control aggression after United’s 1-0 loss in the reverse fixture, downplays talk of revenge, and praises United supporters for their strong backing.

At Arsenal’s sold-out lunchtime Premier League match against Liverpool, supporters from both clubs left their seats empty for the first ten minutes and displayed banners to protest “extortionate” ticket prices.  Triggered by the league’s new £5.14 billion TV-rights deal, the joint action—organised by Arsenal’s Black Scarf Movement and Liverpool groups Spirit of Shankly and Spion Kop 1906—highlighted that the cheapest seats for the game cost £64.  Fans outside and inside the 60,000-capacity Emirates Stadium unfurled slogans such as “£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket” and “Football without fans is nothing,” warning, as organisers Kelvin Meadows and Roy Bentham put it, that rising costs could drive away a generation of working-class supporters.  Further protests were planned for after full-time.

• Newborn Star Reader from Barnsley, West Yorkshire developed persistent jaundice days after birth and was diagnosed with the rare, life-threatening condition biliary atresia, in which the bile ducts are blocked or absent (incidence: about 1 in 16,000 births).  
• An initial operation to unblock the ducts failed, leaving a liver transplant as her only chance of survival.  
• Parents Jade Reader and Matthew Bygrave were not suitable donors, but Jade’s identical twin sister, Shanell Reader, was an ideal match and immediately volunteered.  
• In November Shanell donated part of her liver; Star spent six weeks in hospital and has since recovered well, though she will need lifelong anti-rejection medication and regular blood tests.  
• Both baby and aunt are now doing well, and the family credit Shanell’s donation with giving Star the chance of a normal life.

Chelsea’s Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy and Willian took part in Audi’s three-round “Football Challenge.”

1. Round 1 – Close-range shots into a car boot: Hazard/Ake beat Remy/Willian 5-3.  
2. Round 2 – Tennis-style rally over a £127,000 Audi R8 V10 Plus: Hazard/Ake win again, taking a 6-0 aggregate lead.  
3. Round 3 – Long-range attempts to drop balls into a convertible Audi: Remy/Willian claim the final round, though Willian accidentally smashes a wing mirror with one shot, drawing a shocked reaction from Remy.

Overall: Hazard and Ake dominate the first two challenges; Remy and Willian salvage the last, but damage an Audi in the process.

• Incident: On December 7 2013, Robert Dellinger, 54, a former high-level executive at PPG, Sprint, Delphi and GE, drove his pickup across a Lebanon, New Hampshire highway median at more than 100 mph, went airborne, and sliced the roof off an oncoming SUV.

• Victims: The crash instantly killed Vermont couple Amanda Murphy, 24, who was eight months pregnant, and her fiancé Jason Timmons, 29; the fetus (to be named Reagan Elizabeth) also died.

• Prosecution claim: Investigators said Dellinger told them he was attempting suicide after arguing with his wife and feeling “depressed and loopy.”

• Defense position: At sentencing Dellinger stated he has “never been suicidal.” Lawyers blame Ambien withdrawal, a psychiatric-drug overdose, Prozac, and advanced multiple sclerosis.

• Legal status: Dellinger pleaded guilty in February to two counts of negligent homicide and one count of assault for the fetus’s death; he faces 12–24 years in prison when the two-day sentencing concludes. The estate of Amanda Murphy has also filed a wrongful-death lawsuit.

• Courtroom notes: His wife described him as ethical and expressed condolences to the victims’ families; Dellinger wept as she spoke.

• Background: Dellinger left PPG in 2011 with a severance of over $1 million and family trusts hold about $3 million in Sunapee, New Hampshire real estate.

Lacey Spears, of Scottsville, Kentucky and later Chestnut Ridge, New York, was found guilty of second-degree murder for fatally poisoning her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, by putting a massive dose of salt into his feeding tube while he was hospitalized. On Wednesday she received 20 years to life in prison (five years short of the maximum) and showed no emotion as the sentence was read.  

Prosecutors said Spears repeatedly fabricated illnesses for the boy to gain attention, subjected him to needless surgeries, continued blogging during his final hospitalization and ultimately caused his “tortured death.” The judge called the crime “unfathomable in its cruelty” and noted Spears’ mental illness.  

The child’s father, Chris Hill, reacted on Facebook, urging that Spears be placed in the general prison population and saying he hoped she would be killed there. Spears’ attorney, maintaining her innocence and blaming hospital negligence, plans to appeal.

An updated flu vaccine, delayed by a month so it could be reformulated, will soon reach Australia. It now protects against three strains: the newly problematic Influenza A (H3N2), Influenza B (B/Phuket), and the existing Influenza A (H1N1). The change follows a sharp rise in deaths in Europe and the United States last winter, where vaccines did not cover H3N2 and B/Phuket. Free, government-funded shots will be available from 20 April for high-risk groups (young children, the elderly and most Indigenous Australians). Experts urge everyone to book vaccinations promptly, arguing the improved match should reduce deaths and will also be used in the next northern-hemisphere winter.

• On the eve of ceremonies marking the 150th anniversary of Abraham Lincoln’s assassination, caretakers of his Springfield, Illinois tomb are fending off two problems:
  1. A National Geographic article by historian Adam Goodheart calls the Art-Deco-style interior “a disappointment” with “all the historical character of an office lobby.”
  2. Governor Bruce Rauner, citing a state budget crisis, proposes abolishing the Illinois Historic Preservation Agency that oversees the tomb and folding it into another department. Last year’s $1.1 million legislative cut had already shortened visiting hours and reduced staff.

• Preservation supporters say the magazine’s criticism is unfair and note that more than $2.5 million has recently been spent on repairs, including plaster, paint, bronze and marble work plus lighting upgrades; a $390,000 waterproofing and landscaping project is under way. They describe the tomb’s physical condition as excellent.

• Built on a poor foundation in 1874, the Larkin Mead–designed monument was reconstructed in 1899 and again in 1930 to allow public access to the burial chamber. The circular, marble-lined interior leads to the family crypt where Lincoln rests beneath the inscription “Now he belongs to the ages.”

• Volunteers and visitors worry that further budget cuts could jeopardize operations of this signature “Land of Lincoln” historic site.

A 1990s fashion revival is underway—chokers, berry lips, round sunglasses and Calvin Klein tees are popular again—and even JNCO’s ultra-wide “rave” jeans are slated to return. The article singles out nine other 1990s/2000s trends it says are best left in the past, citing then-and-now celebrity examples for each:

1. Bucket hats  
2. Camouflage print clothing  
3. “Maxed-out” looks such as head-to-toe designer prints or double denim  
4. Sheepskin Ugg boots  
5. Extra-short “Daisy Duke” denim shorts  
6. Juicy Couture velour tracksuits  
7. Brightly colored or mirrored sunglasses  
8. Corsets worn as outerwear  
9. Baggy, ankle-tapered harem trousers

Despite periodic celebrity attempts to revive them, the piece argues these items remain impractical, unflattering or overdone.

Highlights of the week’s most-shared stories:

• A rare quadruple rainbow was photographed over the New York area.  
• China has begun cracking down on the growing practice of hiring exotic dancers for funeral wakes.  
• Robert Downey Jr. cut short a U.K. interview after personal questions irritated him.  
• The #KylieJennerChallenge—lip-plumping by sucking on a jar—became the Kardashians’ latest viral fad.  
• Former chorus girl Alice Barker, 102, watched filmed performances of her younger self for the first time.  
• A high-school “prom-posal” that mentioned bombs was rejected; the student claims racial bias.  
• Ewan McGregor will voice Lumiere in Disney’s live-action “Beauty and the Beast.”  
• Johnny Depp’s drastic transformation in the “Black Mass” trailer surprised viewers.  
• A couple announced a pregnancy with a “Fresh Prince of Bel-Air” spoof, and a military father photobombed his son, earning online applause.

At the Miami Open, Serena Williams earned her 700th career victory—defeating Sabine Lisicki 7-6, 1-6, 6-3—and celebrated with a giant cake, echoing Andy Murray’s cake for his 500th win the day before. The win put world No 1 Williams into the semi-finals, where she will face third seed Simona Halep, who beat Sloane Stephens 6-1, 7-5. A hoped-for clash with sister Venus ended when Venus lost to Carla Suárez Navarro.

Sabeen Mahmud, a prominent Pakistani human-rights activist and founder of Karachi’s arts-and-discussion café The Second Floor (T2F), was shot dead by two gunmen late Friday as she left the venue. Her mother was also hit but is expected to recover. Moments earlier Mahmud had hosted a talk on the enforced disappearances in Baluchistan—a discussion Lahore University of Management Sciences had been forced to cancel. Long celebrated for promoting liberal debate, technology, women’s entrepreneurship and the arts, Mahmud had previously received death threats yet continued her work. Police have not identified the attackers or a motive. Her killing has sparked nationwide grief for a woman widely regarded as a fearless voice for free speech, tolerance and progressive values in Pakistan.

About 100,000 “West Pakistan Refugees” (WPRs) ­– Hindu families who fled to Jammu-and-Kashmir during the 1947 Partition – have never been given full state citizenship.  
• They cannot buy land, vote in state elections, enter state colleges or hold state-government jobs, leaving three generations in slum-level poverty around Jammu.  
• A pre-independence law limits these rights to people descended from the former Kingdom of Kashmir; successive Kashmir governments have kept the overwhelmingly Hindu WPRs excluded for fear of altering the Muslim-majority state’s demography.  
• By contrast, about 35,000 Hindus who fled Pakistan-controlled Kashmir do enjoy full rights.  
• The refugees, represented by activists such as Labha Ram Gandhi, say they are ready to protest if denied again.  
• Hopes have risen after Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s Hindu-nationalist BJP won its first share of power in the state and pledged to “normalise” WPR status.  
• Meanwhile the region remains volatile: suspected militants recently killed three policemen and wounded another.

• Chelsea have made an offer of about £4 million for FC Tokyo’s 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto and would loan him to partner club Vitesse Arnhem next season.  
• Muto is undecided, saying he will only move where he can “play and develop” regularly.  
• Former FC Tokyo coach Ranko Popovic calls Muto unusually intelligent, fast, strong and confident, and believes he could thrive at Stamford Bridge.  
• José Mourinho confirms he knows of Muto but will not discuss another club’s player; he notes that transfers must balance both footballing quality and the club’s commercial and Financial Fair Play considerations, citing Chelsea’s recent £200 million Yokohama Rubber sponsorship.

The article argues that England Rugby should scrap its rule barring overseas-based players, just as Australia has done.  

Key points:  
• Australia’s change lets stars like Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell, now with Toulon, return for the World Cup.  
• England coach Stuart Lancaster is still blocked from picking talents such as Toulon flanker Steffon Armitage and Clermont full-back Nick Abendanon, whose games have improved in France.  
• Other sports (e.g., football) and other nations (South Africa with Bryan Habana, Wales with Leigh Halfpenny) freely select players abroad.  
• World Cups are about fielding the very best; restricting selection by club location weakens the team, leaves fans asking “what if,” and could cost England on home soil.  
• Winning benefits clubs and the RFU alike, so the governing bodies should not “tie hands behind backs” with outdated eligibility rules.

FireChat, created by Open Garden, is a mobile app that lets users send messages without internet or cellular service by turning nearby phones into a wireless mesh network. It relies on Apple’s Multipeer Connectivity Framework (or Android Bluetooth/Wi-Fi Direct), linking devices within roughly 30 ft and relaying messages node-to-node up to about 200 ft. Users pick a screen name and chat in “Nearby” (local) or “Everyone” (wider mesh) rooms; messages move securely and anonymously across the mesh.  

To extend the network’s reach, Open Garden has built Greenstone—an egg-shaped beacon/booster that stores and forwards messages. Greenstone works only with FireChat for now, has about a 20 ft range per device, can hold 1,000 recent messages, and runs for a year on its battery. Intended uses include festivals, protests, hospitals, or any place where regular networks are unavailable or overloaded. Greenstone is still in development while Open Garden seeks manufacturing partners.

New Jersey burlesque performer Lillian Bustle uses the word “fat” as a neutral, body-positive description—just like “short” or “wife.” In a 2014 TED talk (posted to YouTube only recently), she argues that “fat” need not equal “ugly,” noting:

• Size discrimination at work has risen 66 % in 30 years, and girls’ top “magic wish” from ages 11–17 is to be thinner.  
• Studies show that the more people see varied bodies, the more they accept and even prefer them. Burlesque lets her present a “fat” body as glamorous and helps shift perceptions.

Bustle, 5'3" and 240 lbs, began performing in 2012; overcoming anxiety about her “jiggling arms” was empowering and serves as her “courage reference” when insecurity returns.

The video has ~38,000 views; apart from a few negative comments, responses—thank-you notes, personal stories, and a message from teenage sisters—have been overwhelmingly supportive. Bustle believes “nice people and body-positivity are winning.”

• Theo Walcott, who has spent much of the season on Arsenal’s bench (17 of 33 Premier League games, six-minute cameo vs Chelsea), joined teammates Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini and Mesut Ozil in a Lanvin photoshoot with model Olga Sherer.  
• Lanvin has been Arsenal’s official tailor since 2013 and will dress the squad for the FA Cup final against Aston Villa at Wembley on 30 May.  
• Walcott hopes to make his first start since the 3-0 win over West Ham (14 March) when Arsenal visit Hull on Monday.

Legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker is selling 417 original props and puppets from more than 50 film and music-video productions. Valued in total at about $746,100, the collection will be auctioned with no reserve on 29 May at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and online via Propstore.com. Highlighted lots include:

• Edgar Bug alien (Men in Black) – est. $40,000  
• Mikey alien suit (Men in Black) – est. $30,000  
• Worm Guy (Men in Black II) – est. $10,000  
• Two-Face mask (Batman Forever) – est. $1,500  
• Bat puppet (Batman Forever) – est. $6,000  
• Grinch costume (How the Grinch Stole Christmas) – est. $8,000  
• Frozen “Frosty” thug statue (Batman & Robin) – est. $4,000  
• Harry suit (Harry and the Hendersons) – est. $6,000  
• Bat Gremlin and other Gremlins 2 puppets – est. $6,000–$8,000  
• Hero Joe head (Mighty Joe Young) – est. $6,000  
• Michael Jackson robotic face (Moonwalker) – est. $3,000  

Baker, 64, is known for work spanning three decades on titles such as An American Werewolf in London, Planet of the Apes, Hellboy and others. Propstore’s Brandon Alinger calls the sale “an exciting opportunity” for fans to own pieces of Baker’s cinematic creations.

Seven-year-old Carwyn Scott-Howell from Talybont-on-Usk, Wales, died while skiing with his family in Flaine, France. During the final run of their holiday he became separated when his mother stopped to help his sister. Believing he could see the resort through the trees, Carwyn left the piste, removed his skis and walked into dense woodland, apparently sliding down steeper sections, before falling 164 ft to his death. Police found his body by following his footprints. Described by relatives as a daring, caring boy whose smile “lit up any room,” Carwyn had skied since age three and loved adventure, modelling himself on Bear Grylls. His family say the loss has left “a vast void in their hearts”; friends, school and local community are mourning the “lively, likeable” pupil. His body is ready to be repatriated while the family remains in the Alps.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, became fixated on being “size-zero” after bullying about her weight. She cut her intake to roughly one piece of fruit (about 100 calories) a day, hid uneaten food, and lost weight until her heart rate slowed and she collapsed, spending a week on a heart monitor. With help from eating-disorder teams (EDICT) and CAMHS she has been recovering, and her renewed confidence has taken her to the semi-final of Miss Teen GB, a contest that promotes healthy body image. The story underscores the intense pressure on teenage girls and outlines the dangers and prevalence of anorexia in the UK.

Liverpool unveiled their 2015/16 home kit at Anfield on Friday.  
• The strip, a red gingham design with white branding and a Hillsborough ‘96’ tribute, is the first produced by New Balance, who have replaced Warrior in a record-breaking £300 million, four-year deal.  
• Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Škrtel and Simon Mignolet modelled the kit for fans; club legends Robbie Fowler and Ian Rush also attended.  
• Supporters loudly urged Sterling—who recently rejected a £100,000-a-week extension and admitted interest in Arsenal—to remain at Liverpool. The club insists the 20-year-old, under contract until 2017, will not be sold this summer.  
• Players spoke of the boost they receive from the fans and looked ahead to next week’s FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley, hoping a cup win can spark further success.

Researchers from the University of Manchester have produced the largest high-definition map yet of dark matter. Using 130 million galaxy images taken with the 570-megapixel Dark Energy Camera on the 4-m Victor M. Blanco telescope in Chile, the team inferred the distribution of dark matter through gravitational lensing—the tiny distortions that the unseen mass induces in galaxy shapes.  

Key facts  
• Map size: 0.4 % of the sky (about 150 times the area of the full Moon); red areas mark dense clumps, blue mark sparse regions.  
• Project: First instalment of the five-year Dark Energy Survey (DES), which aims to chart 12.5 % of the sky by 2018 and create a 3-D dark-matter/energy map.  
• Purpose: Examine how dark-matter “filaments” and voids govern where galaxies form, and use the evolving “clumpiness” of dark matter to probe the nature of dark energy.  
• Technique & effort: Shape-measuring each galaxy to 0.1 % precision required supercomputing power equivalent to 500 desktops running for two weeks per data release.  
• Context: Dark matter, invisible but making up roughly 80–85 % of cosmic matter, is detectable only through its gravitational effects.  

The map, unveiled at the American Physical Society meeting in Baltimore, inaugurates a series that will ultimately deliver the first large-scale, three-dimensional view of the Universe’s dark component.

• PSV Eindhoven confirm Manchester United have made a formal move for 21-year-old winger Memphis Depay, whom Louis van Gaal knows from the Netherlands’ 2014 World Cup squad.  
• United face competition from Paris-Saint Germain and another major European club; Tottenham’s rejected £15 m bid last summer is now considered far below his current value.  
• Depay has 20 goals in 26 Eredivisie matches this season and helped PSV clinch their first Dutch title in seven years with a 4-1 win over Heerenveen, scoring a free-kick in the game.  
• Career path: VV Moordrecht (age 6) → Sparta Rotterdam (age 9) → PSV youth (age 12) → PSV first team debut 2011; now over 100 senior appearances.  
• Playing profile: rapid left-sided attacker who dribbles, cuts inside onto a powerful right foot, shoots from distance; still prone to occasional poor decision-making.  
• Comparisons: manager Phillip Cocu likens his potential to Arjen Robben, while former United scout Ed van Steijn claims he is ahead of Cristiano Ronaldo at the same age.  
• International record: first capped in 2013; scored twice at the 2014 World Cup and was shortlisted for the tournament’s Best Young Player award.

Chelsea’s youngsters left Manchester with a 3-1 first-leg advantage in the Youth Cup final.  
• Tammy Abraham struck two first-half volleys (goals 35 and 36 of his season) to put Chelsea 2-1 up after City’s Isaac Buckley-Ricketts had briefly levelled.  
• Dominic Solanke added a late third to “kill” the tie.  

Player snapshots:  
Manchester City – GK Kjetil Haug looked nervous under high balls; captain Tosin Adarabioyo and Cameron Humphreys-Grant battled hard; Brandon Barker was lively but wasteful; Aaron Nemane, Kean Bryan and Manu García missed key chances.  

Chelsea – Centre-backs Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke-Salter were dominant; full-back Ola Aina repeatedly raided forward; Ruben Sammut shielded midfield; captain Charlie Colkett controlled the game; Isaiah Brown threatened despite an early miss; Charly Musonda was quiet.  

Overall: Chelsea’s clinical finishing and solid defending outshone a talented but profligate City side, giving the Blues a commanding cushion for the return leg in West London.

• Marco Rubio, newly declared Republican presidential candidate, told CBS’s Face the Nation that:  
  – He believes people are born with their sexual preference.  
  – He still views marriage as “between one man and one woman” and says same-sex marriage should not be deemed a constitutional right.  
  – Decisions on marriage definitions should be left to individual state legislatures, not the courts.

• Rubio added that, although he disagrees with same-sex marriage, he would attend a gay wedding of a family member or staffer out of love and respect—similar to how he treats divorced loved ones despite his Catholic opposition to divorce.

• His campaign is reported to have already secured more than the $51 million likely needed for the primary season.

Spanish cyclist Pablo Mandado (27) and Latvian cyclist Ilze Zebolde (31) left their restaurant jobs in Manchester to pursue an open-ended, low-cost bicycle journey around the world.

Key facts:
• Time on the road so far: 356 days.  
• Distance covered: almost 7,000 miles (≈11,132 km).  
• Countries visited: 16 – starting in London and travelling through France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, Turkey, Georgia and Armenia.  
• Budget: less than €3 per person per day (≈€0.10 per kilometre); about €2.74 each goes on food.  
• Living arrangements: 161 nights camping, 66 via Couchsurfing, 44 via WarmShowers, plus occasional stays offered by strangers; showers range from daily to weekly.  
• Diet/cost-saving: pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, seasonal produce, foraged fruit, free meals, and dumpster-dived food in Western Europe.  
• Gear: about 130 kg including the bicycles.  
• Motivation: no agenda—just “discover different parts of this planet a pedal at a time,” taking days as they come and pausing for scenery.  
• Future route: continue across Asia, cross the Pacific, then ride the length of the Americas; they expect to remain on the road for years.

• A Texas couple who married in 2012 rented a photo booth from James Evans’s company, Premiere Photos, for their reception at the Bell Tower in northwest Houston.  
• Some photo-strip prints allegedly carried the caption “poor n***** party.”  
• The bride’s sister, who saw the slur at the wedding, waited months to tell the couple so as not to ruin the day.  
• On learning of it, the groom phoned Evans, who reportedly refused to apologize and said, “Sue me.”  
• Represented by attorney Cathy Hale, the couple is suing Premiere Photos under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act for negligence and breach of contract; they principally want an apology.  
• Evans denies any involvement, noting 103 guests and “no sign of mental anguish.”  
• Mediation is set for the following morning; absent a settlement, trial is scheduled for July.

• England and Harlequins full-back Mike Brown is still sidelined after his latest concussion; he withdrew from last weekend’s Premiership match against Saracens and does not know when he will return.

• Brown, previously knocked out against Italy in February, felt headaches after the France match and is following a careful, stage-by-stage recovery (e.g., 20-minute bike test) to avoid a long lay-off like Johnny Sexton, Geoff Parling or George North.

• Heightened awareness from World Rugby’s online concussion modules prompted Brown to pull out of England-Ireland on March 1 and reinforces his view that players must be honest about symptoms and not play on.

• Northampton wing George North, after four recent concussions, has been told by specialists to miss the rest of the season and will see a neurosurgeon.

• Brown discussed these issues while promoting Land Rover’s “We Deal in Real” Rugby World Cup 2032 campaign.

• Professor David Spiegelhalter’s new book “Sex by Numbers” shows that the average heterosexual couple in Britain now has sex three times a month, down from four times in 2000 and five times in 1990.  
• He links the decline to the rise of the internet and smartphones: constant email-checking and blurred boundaries between work and home leave less “quiet, empty time” for partners.  
• Other contributing factors he notes include more people living alone and the general crowding of daily schedules.  
• Researcher Catherine Mercer adds that evening work emails keep people mentally connected to the outside world at bedtime, pushing sex further down the list of priorities.

• Tibetan mastiffs can weigh up to 80 kg and were once a coveted status symbol in China; a puppy sold for £1.2 million just 13 months ago.

• Their value has collapsed: anti-corruption measures mean officials no longer accept the dogs as gifts, several big cities now ban ownership of dogs over 50 kg, and rapid urbanisation has shown the breed is ill-suited to city life.

• Profit-driven cross-breeding has flooded the market with poor-quality animals that cannot be sold.

• As a result, mastiffs are being stolen or sold to slaughterhouses; their meat goes into cheap hotpots and their skins are made into leather belts.

• Animal-welfare workers recently found 20 mastiffs crammed into cages en route to an abattoir—one-third were dead, none had food or water for three days, and several had broken bones—highlighting widespread cruelty now facing the once-prized breed.

• A survey of 600 female public-transport users in the Paris area found that every respondent had suffered some form of gender harassment or sexual assault, with half experiencing their first incident before age 18.  
• Incidents range from verbal intimidation (whistling, comments, insistent “flirting”) to groping, sex attacks and rape; 60 % of women, versus 30 % of men, now fear using public transport.  
• Most abuse goes unreported, forcing many women to change routes, schedules, clothing or behaviour, effectively limiting their freedom and “excluding women from the public arena.”  
• The findings, compiled by the High Council for Gender Equality for the women’s rights ministry, prompted calls for a campaign to curb sexist or threatening behaviour, remind offenders that groping alone can mean five years in prison and a €75,005 fine, and help women recognize that such treatment is not “normal.”

• Insurance firm Direct Line launched the #EverydayFix design-makeathon with London design collective Makerversity.  
• A survey of 2,000 people identified the 10 most stressful “everyday emergencies”; the top three were:  
  1) Not being able to sleep (46 %),  
  2) Losing keys (37 %),  
  3) Being stuck in traffic when late (35 %).  

• Three prototypes were shortlisted:  
  – “Snooze” (by Instruments): an alarm clock that links to a phone and blocks notifications to aid sleep.  
  – “Forget Me Lock” (by Onn Studio): a key-mounted indicator that shows green when the door is open and red when it is locked, so users can check remotely.  
  – “Nipper” (by Impulse): billed as the world’s smallest mobile-phone charger; it clips onto any household battery to give a quick power boost.  

• Twitter users vote by retweeting posts that include #everydayfix; the design with the most retweets by 46 April will be crowdfunded on Kickstarter and manufactured.  

• Other ideas that did not make the final cut include:  
  – “Hat Nav” cycling helmet with bone-conduction audio directions,  
  – “Parking Pin” that marks and monitors a parking space,  
  – “Relay” app that redirects messages when a phone battery dies.

Northumbria Police and Crime Commissioner Vera Baird has allocated more than £500,000 of public money to Victims First Northumbria, a new victims-support charity of which she and Northumbria Chief Constable Sue Sim are directors. The Ministry of Justice has opened an investigation to determine whether this arrangement breaches conflict-of-interest rules introduced when PCCs were allowed to commission victims’ services. Critics, including Home Affairs Committee chair Keith Vaz, label the move “totally inappropriate.” Baird insists all MoJ protocols were followed. Sim, who will retire in June and has previously faced a bullying inquiry led by Baird, sits on the charity’s board as well, raising further concerns among observers. The MoJ can halt the funding if a conflict is confirmed.

In late-March 2014, 53-year-old Greg Valecce was held captive for about 42 hours in the basement of a Mayfair, Philadelphia row-house. Ringleader Corry “Corey” Campbell, 21, his girlfriend Sandra Ng, 19, and friend Carl Halin, 18, beat, spat on and filmed Valecce, tied him to a chair and tattooed his body with messages such as “RIP Pebbles,” swastikas and racial slurs. Campbell believed Valecce had broken his cat Pebbles’ leg and stolen money and marijuana. Valecce escaped on April 1 with broken ribs, wrists and facial bones; the tattoos have since been removed.

Police recovered a tattoo gun, drug paraphernalia, 155 g of marijuana and Valecce’s stolen debit card. All three assailants pleaded guilty to aggravated assault, conspiracy and false imprisonment. Sentences: Campbell – 20 years in state prison; Halin – 20 years; Ng – 23 months. Two other alleged participants, David Thomas, 28, and Jennifer Pratt, 40, are awaiting sentencing and trial respectively.

• PSV Eindhoven have confirmed that Manchester United have made a formal approach for 21-year-old winger Memphis Depay, a player Louis van Gaal knows well from picking him in the Netherlands’ 2014 World Cup squad.  
• United face competition from Paris Saint-Germain and another major European club; Tottenham’s rejected £15 million bid last summer is now considered far below Depay’s current valuation.  
• Depay is enjoying a breakthrough campaign: 20 goals in 26 league matches and a key free-kick in Saturday’s 4-1 win over Heerenveen that clinched PSV’s first Eredivisie title in seven years (their 22nd overall).  
• Career path: VV Moordrecht (age 6) → Sparta Rotterdam → PSV youth (age 12) → PSV first-team debut 2011; now 100-plus appearances.  
• Playing style: rapid left-winger who dribbles, cuts inside and shoots powerfully with his right foot; still prone to occasional poor decisions.  
• Comparisons and praise: PSV coach Phillip Cocu likens his potential to Arjen Robben; United scout Ed van Steijn says he is ahead of Cristiano Ronaldo at the same age.  
• International record: debuted for the Netherlands in 2013; scored against Australia and Chile at the 2014 World Cup and was nominated for the tournament’s Best Young Player award.

FA Youth Cup Final, first-leg – Academy Stadium, Manchester  
• Result: Manchester City U-18s 1 – 3 Chelsea U-18s.  
• Goals:  
  – Tammy Abraham (Chelsea) 2 first-half volleys – his 35th & 36th of the season.  
  – Isaac Buckley-Ricketts (City) equalised briefly for 1-1.  
  – Dominic Solanke (Chelsea) late strike sealed the 3-1 win.  

Chelsea highlights  
• Front-pair Abraham and Solanke dominated; Solanke’s late finish “killed” the tie.  
• Midfield captain Charlie Colkett and holding man Ruben Sammut controlled the game.  
• Back-line of Aina, Tomori, Clarke-Salter and Dasilva largely subdued City; keeper Bradley Collins solid.  

City highlights  
• Keeper Kjetil Haug uncertain under high balls; little chance with goals.  
• Centre-backs Tosin Adarabioyo & Cameron Humphreys-Grant battled well but were stretched.  
• Kean Bryan limped off briefly; Brandon Barker lively yet wasteful; Manu Garcia quiet; Aaron Nemane dangerous but final ball lacking.  

Context  
Chelsea carry a commanding two-goal cushion to the second leg at Stamford Bridge after out-playing City’s youngsters in Manchester.

• Marco Rubio told CBS’s “Face the Nation” that he believes people are born with their sexual preference.  
• Despite this, he says marriage should be defined as between “one man and one woman” and that same-sex marriage is not a constitutional right; state legislatures—not courts—should decide the matter.  
• Rubio said he would attend a same-sex wedding of a relative or staffer out of love and respect, even though he disagrees with the union.  
• He compared the stance to his Catholic view on divorce: he believes it is wrong but would not stop loving someone who is divorced.  
• Rubio recently announced his presidential run and, according to donors, already has pledges exceeding the roughly $47 million needed for the Republican primary race.

Spanish‐Latvian couple Pablo Mandado (27) and Ilze Zebolde (31) left their restaurant jobs in Manchester to fulfil a dream of seeing the world “a pedal at a time.”  
• Time on the road so far: 356 days.  
• Distance covered: almost 7,000 miles (≈11,100 km) through 16 European and Caucasus countries, starting in London and travelling via France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, the Balkans, Greece, Turkey, Georgia and Armenia.  
• Budget: under €3 per person per day – roughly €0.10 per kilometre.  
  – Main spend is food (€2.74/day each): pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, seasonal produce, supplemented by gifts, foraging and occasional dumpster-diving.  
  – No transport costs; accommodation is usually free: 161 nights camping, 66 via Couchsurfing, 44 via Warmshowers, plus hospitality from strangers.  
• Gear: about 130 kg carried on their two bicycles.  
• Purpose and plans: no set agenda beyond exploration; they intend to keep riding for years, continue across Asia, cross the Pacific and cycle the length of the Americas.

England and Harlequins full-back Mike Brown, still feeling headaches after the Six Nations match against France, has withdrawn from recent games and says he has no fixed date for a comeback.  Having been knocked out against Italy in February and missing the Ireland fixture, he is adopting a careful, step-by-step return programme and will only resume once symptom-free, aiming to avoid long lay-offs like those suffered by George North, Johnny Sexton and Geoff Parling.  Brown credits World Rugby’s online concussion modules for making him recognise the warning signs and stresses the importance of players being honest about symptoms, even for high-profile matches.  He spoke while promoting Land Rover’s “We Deal in Real” Rugby World Cup 2028 campaign.

British couples are having sex less often than in previous decades—about three times a month today versus four times in 2000 and five in 1990—according to Cambridge statistician Professor David Spiegelhalter’s book “Sex by Numbers.” He and researcher Catherine Mercer link the drop to increased internet and smartphone use, which blurs work-home boundaries, keeps people constantly checking emails, and leaves less uninterrupted time for partners; more people living alone may also play a role.

Tibetan mastiffs, once luxury status symbols that sold for up to £1.2 million and can weigh as much as 80 kg, have lost their value in China. An anti-corruption campaign has curbed the practice of giving the dogs as gifts to officials, several major cities now ban ownership of dogs over 50 kg, and rapid urbanisation has shown the breed is ill-suited to city life. Over-breeding and cross-breeding for profit have further lowered quality, creating a glut of unwanted animals. As a result, many mastiffs are being stolen or sold to slaughterhouses where their meat is used in cheap hotpots and their skins made into leather; rescuers recently found 20 crammed in cages, a third already dead. Animal-welfare groups fear hundreds more face the same fate.

Direct Line’s #everydayfix contest asked 2,000 people to list the “everyday emergencies” that cause them most stress. The top ten included:  
1. Not being able to sleep (46%)  
2. Losing keys (37%)  
3. Being stuck in traffic when late (35%)  
4. Losing an important document (33%)  
5. Nowhere to park (32%)  
6. Printer not working (31%)  
7. Phone battery running out (31%)  
8. Discovering no toilet roll (30%)  
9. Dealing with automated customer-service lines (26%)  
10. Forgetting a bank card when paying (25%)  

Designers from London’s Makerversity then built prototypes to fix these problems; three reached the final shortlist:

• Snooze – an alarm clock/phone dock by team Instruments that mutes all phone notifications to help users sleep.  
• Forget Me Lock – a key-mounted indicator from Onn Studio that shows green when the door is open and red when it is locked, allowing owners to check later whether they secured the house.  
• Nipper – a match-box-size mobile‐phone charger by Impulse that uses any household battery to give a quick power boost.

Twitter users vote by retweeting their preferred product’s tweet, tagged #everydayfix; the item with the most retweets by 40 April will be launched as a Kickstarter project and produced by Direct Line.

Other prototype ideas (not shortlisted) included: a navigation cycling helmet using bone-conduction audio, a “parking pin” that reports when a space frees up, and “Relay,” an app that forwards messages when a phone dies.
